questions.question: Identify the scienti ﬁ c name of sea pen that belongs to phylum Cnidaria.
questions.explanation: Pennatula. Sea pens are colonial marine cnidarians that have a feather-like appearance and are found in deep-sea environments. Gorgonia (Sea-fan) is the genus of a type of soft coral, also in phylum Cnidaria. Adamsia is a genus of sea anemones. Obelia is a genus of colonial hydroids, also in phylum Cnidaria.

questions.question: What is the scienti ﬁ c name of the banyan tree, a large evergreen tree of Asia characterised by its trunk-like aerial roots?
questions.explanation: Ficus benghalensis : Family - Moraceae, Order - Rosales, Kingdom - Plantae. Gossypium herbaceum : Levant cotton. Santalum album : Indian Sandalwood. Ananas comosus : Pineapple.

questions.question: Match the columns.Column-A (Class)Column-B (Common name) i. Chlorophyceae a. Brown algae ii. Phaeophyceae b. Green algae iii. Rhodophyceae c. Blue-green algae iv. Cyanophyceae d. Red algae

options.a: i - b, ii - c, iii - a, iv - d
options.b: i - b, ii - a, iii - d, iv - c
options.c: i - d, ii - c, iii - b, iv - a
options.d: i - a, ii - b, iii - c, iv - d

questions.explanation: i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c. Divisions of Algae and their Main Characteristics : Chlorophyceae (Green algae) : Major pigments - Chlorophyll, Stored Food - Starch, Ex - Spirogyra. Phaeophyceae (Brown algae) : Pigment - fucoxanthin, Stored food - Mannitol, Laminarin, Ex - Sargassum, Laminaria. Rhodophyceae (Red algae) : Pigment - Phycoerythrin, Stored Food - Floridean starch, Ex - Gracilaria and Gelidium. Cyanophyceae are prokaryotic and play a signi ﬁ cant role in nitrogen ﬁxation.

questions.question: Which of the following is anothername for starch found mainly in the pulp of seeds, fruits, tubers, roots and stems of plants, especially in corn, potatoes, wheat and rice?
questions.explanation: Amylum - A polymeric carbohydrate consisting of numerous glucose units joined by glycosidic bonds. Olestra (Olean) - Fat substitute that doesn't add any calories to products. Saponins - They are naturally occurring compounds that are widely distributed in all cells of legume plants. Xanthan (polysaccharide) produced from simple sugars using a fermentation process. Uses - common food additive, thickening agent, emulsi ﬁ er, and stabiliser that prevents ingredients from separating.

questions.question: What is the common term for Ancylostoma?
questions.explanation: Hookworm. Ancylostoma is a genus of parasitic nematodes (roundworms) that primarily infect mammals. These worms are intestinal parasites and are transmitted to humans through contact with contaminated soil or sand where the larvae are present. Tapeworm : genus - Taenia, Examples - Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) and Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm). Filaria worms belong to the family Filarioidea.

questions.question: Solanum lycopersicum L. is the scienti ﬁ c name of which of the following highly consumed vegetables?
questions.explanation: Tomato. Tomato is a major contributor of lycopene and is also a considerable source of vitamins K, A, C, ﬁber , and carbohydrates, besides some amounts of iron, potassium, phosphorus, and sulfur. Potato - Solanum tuberosum, Onion - Allium cepa, and Garlic - Allium sativum.

questions.question: What is the common name of Parthenium hysterophorus?
questions.explanation: Carrot Grass. This plant causes milk disease in livestock and is also responsible for respiratory malfunction in humans. Lemon grass - Cymbopogon, Lawn Grass - Poaceae, Horsetails -Equisetum.

questions.question: Oleo gum resin (Asafoetida) can be obtained from:

options.a: dried latex from the stem of ferula
options.b: dried latex from the roots of mango tree
options.c: dried latex from the banana leaves
options.d: dried latex from the tap root of ferula

questions.explanation: Oleo-gum-resin (Asafoetida) can be obtained from the exudates of the roots of the Iranian endemic medicinal plant, Ferula asafoetida. It has cytotoxic, antiulcer, anti-neoplasm, anti-cancer, and anti-oxidative effects.

questions.question: Which food is a good source of complete protein ?
questions.explanation: Eggs. Proteins, made of about 20 amino acids, are essential for building muscles, bones, enzymes, and hormones. Protein-rich foods include poultry, seafood, ﬁsh, eggs, and dairy products like milk, yogurt, and cheese. Eggs are naturally rich in vitamin B2 (ribo ﬂ avin), vitamin B12, vitamin D, selenium and iodine.

questions.question: If the Glycemic Index (GI) of a speci ﬁ c food is from 70 to 100, then the type of that food is:
questions.explanation: High-GI food causes a rapid increase in blood sugar levels after consumption. These foods are typically processed or re ﬁ ned carbohydrates, like white bread or sugary snacks. Foods with a GI of 55 or lower are classi ﬁ ed as low-GI, and those with a GI between 56 and 69 are considered medium-GI.

questions.question: Which is the most important protein component in milk, both quantitatively and nutritionally, that accounts for about 80% of the total protein in bovine milk ?
questions.explanation: Casein. It exists in milk in complex groups of molecules called micelles. Pepsin converts proteins into proteoses and peptides (peptides). The mucus and bicarbonates present in the gastric juice play an important role in lubrication and protection of the mucosal epithelium from excoriation by the highly concentrated hydrochloric acid. HCl provides the acidic pH (1.5 to 3.5) optimal for pepsins. Fibrinogen, globulins and albumins are the major proteins. Albumins help in osmotic balance. Q.12 . Which of the following is another name for vitamin C ? SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Pyridoxine (b) Pyridoxal (c) Pyridoxamine (d) Ascorbic acid Sol.12.(d) Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C), a water-soluble vitamin, aids collagen production, wound healing, and bone formation. Its de ﬁ ciency causes scurvy with symptoms like bleeding gums and delayed healing. Found in citrus fruits (lemons, oranges) and others like strawberries and amla. Types of vitamins include A (Retinol), B1 (Thiamine), B6 (Pyridoxine), E (Tocopherol), and K (Phytonadione).

questions.question: Which essential amino acid enhances calcium absorption and also plays an important role in the formation of collagen?
questions.explanation: Lysine is an essential amino acid that must be obtained from food sources like meat, ﬁsh, dairy, and eggs. Collagen contains hydroxylysine, derived from lysine. Amino acids are classi ﬁ ed as acidic, basic, or neutral. L-arginine helps build proteins, histidine is essential for protein biosynthesis, and tyrosine is a non-essential amino acid found in proteins and freely in organisms.

questions.question: Which non-essential amino acid is synthesised by the hydroxylation of phenylalanine in a reaction catalysed by phenylalanine hydroxylase ?
questions.explanation: Tyrosine. Amino acids are the building blocks of proteins. When proteins are broken down, amino acids are released. It facilitates various bodily functions such as: breaking down food, repairing tissues, and supporting overall growth and maintenance. Essential amino acids are: histidine, isoleucine, leucine, lysine, methionine, phenylalanine, threonine, tryptophan, andvaline. Non-essential amino acids are: alanine, arginine, asparagine, aspartic acid, cysteine, glutamic acid, glutamine, glycine, proline, serine, and tyrosine.

questions.question: Which vitamin is involved in red blood cell formation, neurological function and DNA synthesis ?
questions.explanation: Vitamin B12. Vitamins (scienti ﬁ c name) and function: Vitamin B1 (Thiamin) - Growth and development. Vitamin B2 (Ribo ﬂ avin) - Red cell production. Vitamin B3 (Niacin) - Healthy skin, digestion and nervous system. Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid) - Maintenance of ligaments, tendons. Vitamin K (Phylloquinone) - Clotting of blood. Vitamin E (Tocopherol) - Formation of RBC. Vitamin D (Calciferol) - Formation of strong bones and teeth. Vitamin A (Retinol) - Keep eyes and skin healthy.

questions.question: Which of the following groups represents essential amino acids ?
questions.explanation: Histidine, isoleucine, leucine, lysine. Amino acids are molecules that join together to form proteins, which are the building blocks of life. When proteins are digested or broken down, they yield amino acids. Histidine, isoleucine, leucine, lysine, methionine, phenylalanine, threonine, tryptophan, and valine are classi ﬁ ed as essential amino acids, as the body cannot produce them. Therefore, they must be obtained from food.

questions.question: Select the INCORRECT statement with regards to vitamins.

options.a: Plants can synthesise almost all vitamins.
options.c: Some bacteria in the gut do not produce vitamins.
options.d: Most of the vitamins cannot get synthesised in su ﬃ cient amounts in our body.

questions.explanation: Gut bacteria helps in supplying essential nutrients, synthesizing vitamin K, aiding in the digestion of cellulose. Vitamins A, D, E and K are fat-soluble and vitamins C and B (complex groupvitamins) are water- soluble.

questions.question: Which essential micronutrient plays a clear role in the synthesis, storage and secretion of insulin in the hexameric form as well as in the conformational integrity of insulin?
questions.explanation: Zinc. Micronutrients are vitamins and minerals needed by the body in very small amounts. Role of some micronutrients in our body : Fluoride inhibits the initiation and progression of dental caries (tooth decay) and stimulates new bone formation. Selenium (Se) plays a critical role in reproduction, thyroid hormone metabolism, DNA synthesis, and protection from oxidative damage and infection. Phosphorus is a component of bones, teeth, DNA, and RNA.

questions.question: Which of the following was the ﬁrst B vitamin discovered in 1897 that is essential in amino acid and carbohydrate metabolism and is active in energy production reactions ?
questions.explanation: Thiamine. Casimir Funk is considered as the 'Father of vitamin therapy'. Vitamin B : B1(thiamin), B2 (ribo ﬂ avin), B3(niacin), B5(pantothenic acid), B6(pyridoxine), B7(biotin), B9(folic acid), B12 (cobalamin). Fat-soluble Vitamins : A, D, E, and K. Water-Soluble Vitamins - B and C.

questions.question: What is the most important health bene ﬁ t of Vitamin D ?
questions.explanation: Vitamin D (Calciferol) : Source- Oily ﬁsh, egg yolks, red meat, etc. Deﬁ ciency Diseases - Rickets. Symptoms- weak and painful bones, Deformities in teeth, Pain in the bones.

questions.question: The food component present in sugar is:
questions.explanation: Carbohydrates. Sugar molecules found in foods and drinks. The body breaks down carbohydrates into glucose (main source of energy for the body). Source - Breads, beans, milk, popcorn, potatoes, cookies, spaghetti, soft drinks, corn, etc. Vitamins - Group of substances that are needed for normal cell function, growth, and development. Proteins are made up of amino acids.

questions.question: Milk, seafood, nuts and whole grains contain high amounts of which mineral that supports bone health and our body's repair process?
questions.explanation: Phosphorus. Other Minerals found in Milk : Calcium, Magnesium, Potassium, Selenium and Zinc. Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is absent in Milk. Minerals and their sources : Iron - Spinach, dry nuts and seeds, Legumes (chickpeas and lentils). Zinc - Pumpkin seeds, Eggs, Whole Grains.

questions.question: What is the monomer unit of glycogen?
questions.explanation: Glucose (C6H12O6).Glycogen : The carbohydrates are stored in the animal body as glycogen. Also known as animal starch because its structure is similar to amylopectin and is rather more highly branched. It is present in the liver, muscles and brain. When the body needs glucose, enzymes break the glycogen down to glucose. Found in yeast and fungi. Fructose - It is a natural monosaccharide found in fruits, honey and vegetables.

questions.question: Which essential amino acid is necessary for the production of our brain’s chemical messengers including melatonin, dopamine, noradrenaline and thyroxine?
questions.explanation: Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid to make proteins and other vital molecules such as neurotransmitters and hormones. Leucine amino acids can be used by skeletal muscle to give energy during exercise. Tryptophan is an amino acid needed for normal growth in infants and for the production and maintenance of the body's proteins, muscles, enzymes, and neurotransmitters.

questions.question: Which of the following is thecorrect match of column-A with column-B? Column-A (Nutrients)Column-B (Source) i. Protein rich food. a. Wheat ii. Fat rich food b. Lemon iii. Carbohydrate rich food c. Egg white iv. Vitamin C rich food d. Butter and cheese

options.a: i - c, ii - a, iii - b, iv - d
options.b: i - c, ii - d, iii - b, iv - a
options.c: i - c, ii - d, iii - a, iv - b
options.d: i - d, ii - c, iii - b, iv - a

questions.explanation: i-c, ii-d, iii-a, iv-b. Important Nutrients in Food and their functions : Carbohydrates - One of the main sources of energy for human beings. Three types of carbohydrates in food - Fiber, Sugar, and Starch. Iron - It is a constituent of our red blood cells whose function is to carry oxygen from our lungs to organs, muscles, and cells.

questions.question: Which of the following vitamins helps to keep our skin and eyes healthy?
questions.explanation: Vitamin A. Deﬁ ciency Diseases - Night blindness, Irregular growth of teeth.

questions.question: Which among the following vitamins in ﬂ uences iron absorption?
questions.explanation: Vitamin C (Water soluble). Scienti ﬁ c name : Ascorbic acid (C6H8O6) or ascorbate. It acts as an antioxidant and helps wound healing. It also helps in the formation of collagen. It is used to purify water after it has been Iodine - treated.

questions.question: Which of the following vitamins helps our body to use calcium for bones and teeth?
questions.explanation: Vitamin D (Calciferol) - It helps prevent Osteoporosis (a disease that thins and weakens the bones and makes them brittle and more likely to break). Source - Oily ﬁsh, egg yolks, red meat, etc.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of 'mineral - source' is correct ?I. Vitamin A - Papaya II. Iron - Spinach
questions.explanation: Both I and II. Vitamin A - Milk, Eggs, Fish, Butter, Forti ﬁ ed Margarine, Cheese, Green & Yellow fruits and Vegetables, etc. Vitamin E - Meats, Poultry, Eggs, Vegetable oils, Nuts, Olives, Tomatoes, etc. Zinc - Liver, Eggs, Cereals and Seafood.

questions.question: Which among the following vitamins is known as Niacin ?
questions.explanation: Vitamin B3. Niacin is the generic name for nicotinic acid (pyridine - 3-carboxylic acid), nicotinamide (niacinamide or pyridin - 3 - carboxamide).

questions.question: Match the columns.Nutrients Examples a. Protein i. Calcium, Phosphorous b. Carbohydrate ii. Cholesterol c. Fat iii. Glucose d. Minerals iv. Myosin
questions.explanation: a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i. Carbohydrate : It consists of sugar, starch, and ﬁber . Two types - Simple Carbohydrates (Monosaccharides, Disaccharides, Oligosaccharides) and Complex Carbohydrate. Fat - It is a macronutrient essential for energy storage, insulation, and the absorption of certain vitamins.

questions.question: Nuts, vegetable oil and ﬁsh are rich sources of__________.
questions.explanation: Omega-3. Most common forms of carbohydrates are sugars, ﬁbers and starches. Minerals which are essential for health : iron, calcium, magnesium, zinc, potassium etc.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of minerals – need is correct? I. Iron – formation of hemoglobin II. Sodium – proper functioning of thyroid
questions.explanation: Only I. Iodine is needed to make a hormone called thyroxine. Biological Importance of Sodium : For the generation of nerve impulses, For maintenance of electrolyte balance and ﬂuid balance, For heart activities and certain metabolic functions.

questions.question: Which amino acid is essential for healthy skin and teeth, as it is a component of tooth enamel, collagen and elastin?
questions.explanation: Threonine used in the biosynthesis of proteins. Leucine is an essential amino acid for protein synthesis. Arginine is used for the treatment of heart and blood vessel conditions including congestive heart failure (CHF), chest pain, high blood pressure, etc. Phenylalanine is used for a disorder that causes white patches to develop on the skin (vitiligo).

questions.question: Which of the following is a micronutrient, and plays a role in cell division, cell growth, wound healing and the breakdown of carbohydrates?
questions.explanation: Zn. Functions of Macronutrients in Plants : Nitrogen (required in large amounts, taken in the form of ions, required for the division of cells), Phosphorus (a constituent of cell membranes), Magnesium (involved in the activation of enzymes in respiration and photosynthesis and helps in the synthesis of DNA and RNA), Sulfur (an important constituent of amino acids, coenzymes, and vitamins), Potassium (required for the opening and closing of stomata).

questions.question: Which is a major essential lipophilic (fat-soluble) vitamin required for the protection of cell membranes and the formation of red blood cells (RBCs)?
questions.explanation: Vitamin E (Tocopherol) is a nutrient that's important to vision, reproduction, and the health of blood, brain and skin.

questions.question: When the breakdown of food (glucose) occurs without the use of oxygen, it is called:
questions.explanation: Anaerobic respiration . Aerobic respiration - The process by which organisms use oxygen to turn fuel, such as fats and sugars, into chemical energy.

questions.question: Which of the following causes enlargement and extension growth of cells ?
questions.explanation: Turgor pressure. Pressure potential is controlled by solute potential (when solute potential decreases, pressure potential increases) and the opening and closing of stomata. Osmotic pressure is the minimum pressure which needs to be applied to a solution to prevent the inward ﬂow of its pure solvent across a semipermeable membrane. Imbibition is a special type of diffusion that takes place when liquid is absorbed by solids-colloids causing an increase in volume.

questions.question: Identify a carbohydrate but does notﬁt into the deﬁ nition.
questions.explanation: Rhamnose (C6H12O5). Carbohydrates are primarily produced by plants and form a very large group of naturally occurring organic compounds. Some common examples of carbohydrates are cane sugar, glucose, starch, etc. Most of them have a general formula, Cx(H2O)y.

questions.question: Which protein is found in grains?
questions.explanation: Gluten. It is a protein naturally found in grains like wheat, barley, and rye. Proteins are large biomolecules made of long chains of amino acids, which are the building blocks of life. Digestion of proteins yields amino acids. Out of 20 amino acids, 9 are essential : phenylalanine, valine, tryptophan, threonine, isoleucine, methionine, histidine, leucine, and lysine. Newly discovered amino acids includeselenocysteine and pyrrolysine.

questions.question: What is pro-vitamin A or the anti-cancer compound present in carrots called?
questions.explanation: Beta - carotene. It is a yellow-orange pigment found in fruits and vegetables. It converts to Vitamin A in the body, supporting healthy vision, immune function, and skin. As an antioxidant, it protects cells from damage, reducing cancer and heart disease risk. Food sources include carrots, sweet potatoes, dark leafy greens, and squash.

questions.question: Garlic is a good source of :
questions.explanation: manganese (Mn) and selenium (Se) are essential micronutrients that are important elements of cell metabolism. Garlic is a valuable source of macro and microelements, especially potassium, calcium, magnesium, phosphorus, ferrum, manganese, selenium, vanadium, copper and zinc. The characteristic odour of garlic is due to a sulphur compound.

questions.question: On which of the following components of chloroplast is chlorophyll arranged ?
questions.explanation: Thylakoids. Chloroplasts contain the thylakoid membrane which is the site of photosynthesis. The thylakoid membrane contains light-absorbing pigments called the chlorophyll. The thylakoids are arranged in stacks termed grana. The space limited by the inner membrane of the chloroplast is called the stroma. The chloroplasts contain chlorophyll and carotenoid pigments which are responsible for trapping light energy essential for photosynthesis.

questions.question: Compounds like gingerol, paradol, shogaols and zingerone are:

options.d: antimicrobial compounds found in citrus fruits

questions.explanation: Antimicrobial compounds found in ginger. Gingerol is derived from ginger (Zingiber o ﬃ cinale Roscoe), which also belongs to the Zingiberaceae family. Ginger has multiple bioactive constituents including gingerols, shogaols, zingerone, paradol and gingerdiol. Gingerols possess an alkyl moiety which imparts anti-oxidative potential to it.

questions.question: Which natural bioactive water - soluble phenolic compound is present in Fruits, vegetables and grains with red, purple, blue or black hues ?
questions.explanation: Anthocyanin (Pigment found in plants). They’re part of a larger category of plant-based chemicals called ﬂa vonoids. Foods with high anthocyanin : Fruits - Pomegranates, Black plums, Cherries, black and red grapes etc; Vegetables - Red cabbage, Red onions, Purple corn etc; Legumes and Rice - Black rice, Black beans etc. Coumarins - colourless crystalline solid, sweet odor, bitter taste. Quercetin - bitter ﬂa vor, used in dietary supplements, beverages and foods. Naringenin - Anti-obesity, anti-diabetic ﬂa vonoid.

questions.question: Which of the following nutrients is available mainly in apples?
questions.explanation: K (Potassium). Potassium-rich fruits and vegetables : Bananas, oranges, cantaloupe, apricots, grapefruit (some dried fruits, such as prunes, raisins, and dates, are also high in potassium). Malic acid : Found primarily in apples. It is a dicarboxylic acid that is also present in grapes, wine and rhubarb.

questions.question: Which of the following grains contain oryzenin ?
questions.explanation: Rice - A source of protein and contains various vitamins, such as thiamin and niacin, and minerals, such as zinc and phosphorus. Oryzenin - A rice glutelin, is an important constituent of rice protein. Glutelin comprises the major protein fraction of the rice grain andconstitutes up to 80% of the total protein. Wheat contains protein, B vitamins, dietary ﬁber , and phytochemicals. Soyabean is high in protein and contains vitamin K1, folate, copper, manganese, phosphorus, and thiamine.

questions.question: What happens to the guard cells when water ﬂows into them?
questions.explanation: Stomatal pores open. Guard cells - They are specialized plant cells in the epidermis of leaves, stems and other organs that are used to control gas exchange. It is a kidney shaped cell that surrounds the stomata. It contains chloroplasts, which are not present in other epidermal cells. Function - To open and close the stomata, help regulate transpiration, and protect the stomatal pore.

questions.question: Plants that are adapted to live under plenty of sunlight are called :
questions.explanation: Heliophytes. Examples - Sunﬂ owers, thyme, white clover, soft velcro, mullein. Xerophytes - A group of plants that are adapted to survive in arid regions like desert and snow - covered areas. Example - Cacti, pineapple. Pteridophytes - That plants have a vascular system and reproduce through spores. Example - Whisk Fern, Dicksonia, Selaginella. Neophytes - A plant which is not native to a geographical region and was introduced in recent history. Example - Sweet ﬂag, small balsam, cranberries.

questions.question: The leaves have a green pigment called ____________, which helps leaves to capture the energy from the sunlight.
questions.explanation: Chlorophyll - Element present in chlorophyll is magnesium. Cytoplasm - The ﬂuid inside the cell. It functions as a cellular metabolism, transport, and storage medium while providing structural support and facilitating signal transduction within the cell. Cladophyll - Shoot system in which leaves do not develop. Xanthophylls are yellow pigments that are one of the importantdivisions of the carotenoid group.

questions.question: Which plant tissue is responsible for the transportation of water and minerals from the soil to the stems and leaves?
questions.explanation: Xylem. Xylem and phloem are the two vascular tissues that are responsible for the transport of substances in plants. Phloem helps in the bidirectional transport of food.

questions.question: The mode of nutrition in which organisms make food themselves from simple substances is called ________.
questions.explanation: Autotrophic nutrition. Examples - Plants, algae and some bacterias. Heterotrophic nutrition - Depends upon plants or other organisms for nutrition. Examples - Humans, animals, Cuscuta (Amarbel). Saprotrophic nutrition - This mode of nutrition in which organisms take in nutrients from dead and decaying matter. Examples - Fungi, yeast, and several bacteria. Phototrophic nutrition - Organisms that can obtain nutrition using light. Examples - Green plants, blue-green algae.

questions.question: Plants require nutrients for their growth which can be supplied through _______ .
questions.explanation: Soil, water and air. Three elements (carbon, oxygen and hydrogen) are essential to plant growth. Soil - Supplies not only minerals but also harbours nitrogen - ﬁxing bacteria, and other microbes, holds water, supplies air to the roots and acts as a matrix that stabilises the plant.

questions.question: Water comes out of the leaves in the form of vapour by a process called ______.
questions.explanation: Transpiration. Three types of Transpiration : Stomatal transpiration - Evaporation of water through stomata. Lenticular Transpiration - Evaporation of water through lenticels (small minute openings present on the stem), Cuticular Transpiration - Loss of water from the cuticle (waxy layer on the surface of leaves).

questions.question: The broad, green part of the leaf is called .
questions.explanation: Lamina. The venation of leaves is the process of arrangement of veins and veinlets. They are crucial for both systemic and pulmonary circulation. The middle part of the vein of lamina is called the midrib. Petiole (mesopodium) - Lifts the lamina above the level of the stem.

questions.question: The green plants in a terrestrial ecosystem capture about _______ percent of the energy of sunlight that falls on their leaves and convert it into food energy.
questions.explanation: 1. Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants produce carbohydrates by absorbing carbon dioxide, water, and sunlight in the presence of chlorophyll and liberating chemical energy. This energy is converted into chemical energy as food.

questions.question: Which nutrient is chlorella rich in ?
questions.explanation: Protein. Chlorella is known as space alga. It is used for the consumption of carbon dioxide provided by the astronauts and the production of oxygen in the spacecraft.

questions.question: Iron, iodine and zinc can be considered as which of the following?
questions.explanation: Micronutrients are nutrients that are required by the body in lesser amounts for its growth and development. Examples - Magnesium, vitamin B6, vitamin C, vitamin E, etc. Non-essential nutrients can be synthesized in the body in su ﬃ cient quantities for normal functioning. They can be obtained from food as well. Examples : Alanine ,Arginine, Asparagine, Aspartic acid, etc.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of plastids- thing stored is NOT correct? I. Amyloplasts - oils and fats II. Aleuroplasts - carbohydrates
questions.explanation: Plastids are found in plants and algae. Functions : perform photosynthesis, attract pollinators, restore total leaf protein and synthesize starch along with the storage of proteins, fats, and oils. Types of Plastids - Chloroplasts (used for photosynthesis), Chromoplasts (used for pigment synthesis and storage), and Leucoplasts (non-pigmented plastids that can sometimes differentiate).

questions.question: How is food stored in brown algae?

options.b: In the form of complex carbohydrates that may be in the form of laminarin or mannitol.
options.c: In the form of complex lipids
options.d: In the form of oil droplets

questions.explanation: Brown algae store their food primarily in the form of complex carbohydrates. The two main storage forms are laminarin (a polysaccharide) and mannitol (a sugar alcohol). These compounds serve as energy reserves for the algae and are utilized during periods of low light or other environmental stress.

questions.question: Pneumatophores are specialised ______ in hydrophytes.
questions.explanation: Roots. Hydrophytes are aquatic plants that are especially suited for living in aquatic environments. Examples - Lotus (Nelumbo), Vallisneria, Potamogeton, Salvinia, hydrilla, water hyacinths etc.

questions.question: Which of the following does NOT ﬁgur e among the main functions of the root system of a plant ?

options.a: Supply of food to plant parts
options.b: Providing a proper anchorage to the plant parts
options.c: Absorption of water from the soil`
options.d: Absorption of minerals from the soil

questions.explanation: Supply of food to the plant parts. The main function of the root system is to transport water andminerals to the plant. Food is transported by phloem tissue in the vascular system of plants.

questions.question: Which of the following plant hormones regulates growth, particularly by stimulating cell elongation in stems?
questions.explanation: Auxin. Ethylene is the only plant hormone in gaseous form that regulates fruit ripening in plants. Cytokinin promotes cell division in plant roots and shoots. Gibberellin regulates various developmental processes, including germination, dormancy, ﬂowering, ﬂower development, and leaf and fruit senescence.

questions.question: Which of the below is a psychological disorder of refusal to eat food, caused by under- nutrition?
questions.explanation: Anorexia Nervosa. Kwashiorkor is a nutritional syndrome caused by protein de ﬁ ciency in the diet, meaning 'the disease of the displaced child'. Marasmus, or 'wasting,' is a form of severe malnutrition that results from a lack of protein and calories. Bulimia nervosa is a serious emotional eating disorder that involves eating excessive amounts of food in a short period (binging) followed by guilt and shame leading to self-induced vomiting, extreme exercise, or laxative abuse (purging).

questions.question: A disease like COVID-19 is a kind of:
questions.explanation: Zoonotic disease. COVID-19 is a zoonotic disease, meaning it can be transmitted between animals and humans. The SARS-CoV-2 virus, which causes COVID-19, is believed to have originated from an animal source before being transmitted to humans.

questions.question: Constipation could be a sign that the person is suffering from a lack of________.
questions.explanation: Dietary Fibre. Constipation is often associated with a lack of dietary ﬁber in the diet, as ﬁber helps to promote regular bowel movements by adding bulk to stool and aiding its passage through the digestive system. Fiber-rich foods include fruits, vegetables, whole grains, beans, peas, and lentils.

questions.question: Which condition, also known as icterus, causes a yellowing of your skin and the whites of your eyes?
questions.explanation: Jaundice. This yellowing occurs due to high levels of bilirubin in the blood. Bilirubin is a yellow pigment produced during the normal breakdown of red blood cells. Ichthyosis is a group of genetic skin disorders that cause dry, scaly, thickened skin. Eczema is a common skin condition that causes itchiness, rashes, dry patches, and infection. Pemphigus is a rare group of autoimmune diseases that cause blisters on the skin and mucous membranes.

questions.question: What are the ﬁv e Fs of indirect transmission?

options.a: Flies, ﬁngers, fomites, food and ﬂuid
options.b: Fruit, ﬁngers, ﬂu, food and ﬂuid
options.c: Flies, ﬁngers, friends, food and fruit
options.d: Flies, ﬁngers, fomites, food and fruit

questions.explanation: Indirect transmission of communicable diseases occurs through various means, commonly referred to as the "5Fs" : ﬂies,ﬁngers, fomites (objects like towels and handkerchiefs that can carry infections), food, and ﬂuids. Some diseases can spread through contaminated water, food, ice, blood, and even body tissues or organs. Examples of such diseases include typhoid, diarrhea, polio, intestinal parasites, and infective hepatitis.

questions.question: Which of the following plants is used to cure cold and cough ?
questions.explanation: Tulsi (Ocimum sanctum). It is an herb commonly used in Ayurvedic medicine to treat various ailments, including respiratory issues (bronchitis, asthma), fever, sore throat, and infections. Babool (Acacia nilotica) is utilized for skin conditions (wounds,eczema), digestive issues, and oral health. Jamun (Syzygium cumini) is bene ﬁ cial for diabetes management, digestive issues, and possesses antioxidant properties. Arjun (Terminalia arjuna) is used to promote cardiovascular health, address heart conditions, and provide anti-in ﬂ ammatory beneﬁ ts.

questions.question: Name a common electrolyte disorder that occurs when the amount of sodium in your blood becomes abnormally low.
questions.explanation: Hyponatremia: It is a common electrolyte disorder characterized by an abnormally low concentration of sodium ions (Na+) in the blood, typically less than 135 mmol/L. Hyperkalemia : Elevated potassium levels in the blood. Hypokalemia: Low potassium levels in the blood. Hypernatremia: Elevated sodium levels in the blood.

questions.question: Which set of diseases are caused by bacteria?

options.d: Malaria, Common cold, In ﬂ uenza

questions.explanation: Typhoid, Cholera, Tuberculosis. Typhoid fever is caused by the bacteria Salmonella Typhi. Cholera is caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. Tuberculosis (TB) is caused by a bacterium (or germ) called Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Viral Disease : Common cold (rhinovirus), Inﬂ uenza (Inﬂ uenza), HIV infection (human immunode ﬁ ciency virus), Dengue (transmitted by the bite of an infected mosquito, and is spread by the Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus species).

questions.question: Which is a serious contagious bacterial infection that usually affects the mucous membranes of the nose and throat ?
questions.explanation: Diphtheria. Meningococcal disease is a serious bacterial illness that can lead to severe swelling of the tissues surrounding the brain and spinal cord or infection of the bloodstream. Shigellosis is an infection of the intestines caused by Shigella bacteria. Chlamydia is acommon sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacteria Chlamydia trachomatis.

questions.question: What is the other name of tetanus caused by toxin producing bacteria called clostridium tetani ?
questions.explanation: Lock jaw. Tetanus, also called lockjaw, is a bacterial infection that causes our neck and jaw muscles to lock up. It occurs when a bacteria found in the environment called Clostridium tetani enter our body through a break in our skin. Other dangerous bacterial diseases include cholera, meningitis, tuberculosis (TB), and Lyme disease.

questions.question: Match the points under Column A with those under Column B.Column A (Disease)Column B (Organism Responsible) i. Malaria a. Vibrio ii. Diarrhoea b. Salmonella iii. Typhoid c. Rotavirus iv. Cholera d. Plasmodium

options.a: i - b, ii - a, iii - c, iv - d
options.b: i - d, ii - c, iii - b, iv - a
options.c: i - a, ii - c, iii - b, iv - d
options.d: i - a, ii - b, iii - c, iv - d

questions.explanation: i-d, ii-c, iii-b, iv-a. Malaria is a disease caused by a parasite. The parasite is spread to humans through the bites of infected mosquitoes. Typhoid is a bacterial disease that spreads through contaminated food and water. The cholera- causing microbes will enter a healthy person through the water they drink and cause disease in them. Diarrhoea is the abnormal frequency of bowel movement and increased liquidity of the faecal discharge. It reduces the absorption of food.

questions.question: What is the name of the inﬂ ammatory condition that causes cracks, crusting and scaling at the corners of the mouth due to vitamin B2 deﬁ ciency ?
questions.explanation: Cheilosis also known as angular cheilitis or perleche. Psoriasis is a chronic proliferative and in ﬂ ammatory condition of skin. It is characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales. Atopic dermatitis (eczema) is a condition that causes dry, itchy and in ﬂ amed skin. Hives (urticaria) is a skin reaction that causes itchy welts. Chronic hives are welts that last for more than six weeks and return often over months or years.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a mutation - based disease ?
questions.explanation: Malaria is an infectious disease caused by a parasite. Down syndrome: It is caused by a chromosomal mutation, speci ﬁ cally trisomy 21, where an individual has an extra copy of chromosome 21. Sickle cell anemia: It is caused by the hemoglobin-β gene. Phenylketonuria (PKU): PKU is caused by a mutation in the PAH gene, which affects the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase.

questions.question: Which of the following is a food - borne disease caused by the consumption of contaminated food or beverages ?
questions.explanation: Cholera. It is an acute diarrhoeal infection caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. Malaria is spread to humans through the bite of an infected female Anopheles mosquito. Tuberculosis (TB) is caused by the bacteria Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which spreads through the air from person to person. Chickenpox is caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which is a member of the herpesvirus family.

questions.question: Which of the following is a rare group of genetic disorders caused by mutations of certain genes affecting the colour (pigmentation) of the skin, hair and eyes ?
questions.explanation: Albinism. Alagille syndrome is a genetic disorder that can affect the liver, heart, and other parts of the body. Alkaptonuria is an inherited condition that causes urine to turn black when exposed to air. Angelman syndrome is a complex genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system.

questions.question: Identify the reason for formation of dental plaque.

options.a: When acids stick to the teeth
options.b: When bacteria acting on sugars produce acids
options.c: Masses of bacterial cells together with food particles stick to the teeth

questions.explanation: Dental caries or tooth decay causes gradual softening of enamel and dentine. It begins when bacteria acting on sugars produce acids that softens or demineralises the enamel. Saliva cannot reach the tooth surface to neutralise the acid as plaque covers the teeth. Microorganisms invade the pulp, causing inﬂ ammation and infection.

questions.question: Which of the following foods generally increase blood pressure?

options.b: Food high in salt, sugar and saturated or trans fats
options.c: Food with low salt and low sugar

questions.explanation: Foods high in salt, sugar, and saturated or trans fats contribute to the retention of ﬂuids and increase the workload on the heart. High Blood Pressure (Hypertension): Hypertension is the term for blood pressure that is higher than normal (120/80). If repeated checks of blood pressure of an individual is 140/90 (140 over 90) or higher, it shows hypertension. High blood pressure leads to heart diseases and also affects vital organs like the brain and kidney.

questions.question: Which vitamin prevents the neural tube defect in new-born babies ?
questions.explanation: Folic acid. It is also known as vitamin B9, plays a crucial role in preventing neural tube defects (NTDs) in newborn babies. NTDs are birth defects that affect the brain and spine, such as Spina bi ﬁ da, Anencephaly. Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) is a water soluble vitamin well known for its role in supporting a healthy immune system. Ribo ﬂ avin (Vitamin B2) and Niacin (Vitamin B3) are water soluble vitamins essential for energy production and metabolism.

questions.question: Severe undernutrition due to the deﬁ ciency of food and energy is termed as _________.
questions.explanation: Marasmus - It occurs both in children and adults. Wasting - It is a type of undernutrition that causes low weight for height. Dementia - It is the group of symptoms used to describe impaired ability to remember, think, or make decisions. Alzheimer's disease is the most common type of dementia.

questions.question: Among the choices listed, which one is NOT a form of cancer?
questions.explanation: Glaucoma - A group of eye diseases that can cause vision loss and blindness by damaging a nerve in the back of your eye called the optic nerve. Carcinoma - Cancer that starts in tissue lining your skin, organs and internal passageways in your body. Lymphoma - Cancer that begins in cells of the lymph system. Sarcoma - Cancers that begin in the bones and in the soft (also called connective) tissues (soft tissue sarcoma).

questions.question: In what condition does the body's immune system attack the actual intrinsic factor protein or the cells in your stomach lining that make it ?
questions.explanation: Pernicious anemia is a relatively rare autoimmune disorder that causes diminishment in dietary vitamin B12 (cobalamin) absorption, resulting in B12 de ﬁ ciency and subsequent megaloblastic anemia. Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting in impaired functioning of transport protein in intestines and kidneys.

questions.question: What happens when old aged people get cataract ?

options.a: Crystalline lens of people in old age becomes milky and cloudy
options.b: Crystalline lens of people in old age becomes clear and shiny

questions.explanation: Eye defects and Corrections : Cataracts - Treated with surgery. Myopia (near-sightedness) - Can see nearby objects clearly but have di ﬃ culty seeing distant objects. Corrected with concave lenses. Hyperopia (far-sightedness) - Can see distant objects clearly but have diﬃ culty seeing nearby objects. Corrected with convex lenses. Presbyopia (age-related far-sightedness) - Lens of the eye becomes less ﬂexible as people age, making it di ﬃ cult to focus on near objects. Corrected with bifocals, progressive lenses, or surgery.

questions.question: In which of the following conditions is there severe physical and mental retardation due to de ﬁ ciency of iodine and thyroid hormones, especially during early pregnancy ?
questions.explanation: Cretinism. Toxoplasmosis - It is caused by the protozoan parasite Toxoplasma Gondii. Syphilis - It is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) that can be caused by Treponema pallidum bacteria. Preeclampsia - It is caused by the placenta not developing properly due to a problem with the blood vessels supplying it.

questions.question: Which of the following tests is used to con ﬁ rm the presence of typhoid fever ?
questions.explanation: Widal Test : This test was ﬁrst conducted in 1896 by Georges Ferdinand Widal and was named after him. It looks for O and H antibodies in a patient’s sample blood (serum). Pap smear - Used to screen for cervical cancer. C Reactive Protein (CRP) Test - A c-reactive protein test measures the level of c-reactive protein (CRP) in a sample of blood.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT the manifestation of Iron-de ﬁ ciency anemia (IDA) ?
questions.explanation: Blindness. Iron - de ﬁ ciency anemia (IDA): It is the most common nutritional disorder. Vulnerable groups : Women in child – bearing age, adolescent girls, pregnant women and school age children. IDA occurs when hemoglobin production is considerably reduced and it results in low levels of hemoglobin in blood.

questions.question: Lack of functional small intestinecan cause a malabsorption disorder leading to diarrhoea, malnutrition, weight loss etc. This particular condition is known as:
questions.explanation: short bowel syndrome. Hypoglycaemia, or a "hypo", is an abnormally low level of glucose in blood. Hyperglycaemia, or a hyper, can happen when blood glucose (sugar) levels are too high.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by the bite of an infected female phlebotomine sand ﬂ y, characterized by irregular fever, weight loss and enlargement of the spleen and liver?
questions.explanation: Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar). It is caused by protozoan parasites which are transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sand ﬂ ies. Japanese encephalitis virus is spread to people through the bite of an infected mosquito. Anaplasmosis is a disease caused by the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum. Other protozoan Diseases : Amoebiasis (Entamoeba Histolytica Protozoa); Malaria (Plasmodium). Other bacteria diseases : Salmonella Tuberculosis, Whooping cough (pertussis), Chlamydia, gonorrhoea, Cholera, etc.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is a potential contender for worldwide eradication ?
questions.explanation: Polio (poliomyelitis) {caused by a virus (poliovirus)} - This virus infects your throat and intestines, causing ﬂu-lik e symptoms. It can then spread to your brain and spine, causing paralysis. It mainly affects children under 5 years of age.

questions.question: An excessive amount of cadmium in the human body causes :
questions.explanation: itai itai. It is the severe form of chronic cadmium intoxication, which is characterised by osteomalacia with severe bone pain and is associated with renal tubular dysfunction. Minamata - A neurological disease caused by severe mercury poisoning.

questions.question: Which type of surveillance is speci ﬁ cally aimed at identifying missing cases of disease ?
questions.explanation: Sentinel surveillance - Conducted at speci ﬁ c sites or in speciﬁ c populations and may be passive or active.

questions.question: Sleeping sickness is a vector borne disease caused by the infection of which microscopic parasite of the species ?
questions.explanation: Trypanosoma brucei : A protozoan parasite that causes African trypanosomiasis, commonly known as sleeping sickness. This disease affects humans and animals, primarily in sub-Saharan Africa. Balantioides coli : A ciliated protozoan that inhabits the intestine of pigs, non-human primates and humans. Giardia : A single-celled parasite that causes diarrheal disease known as Giardiasis. Cyclospora cayetanensis : A parasite that causes gastroenteritis.

questions.question: Which is an inherited blood disorder that affects the hemoglobin gene and results in ineffective erythropoiesis ?
questions.explanation: Thalassemia - It is a hereditary blood disorder in which the amount of hemoglobin in the body decreases. Somatostatinoma - A type of neuroendocrine tumor (NET). Venous Thromboembolism - A condition when a blood clot forms in a vein in the body. Polycythemia vera - A type of blood cancer.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct match of column-A with column-B? Column - A (Name of Disease)Column -B (Affected Organs) i. Alzheimer's diseasesa. Salivary glands ii. Diphtheria b. Reproductive tract iii. Gonorrhoea c. Brain iv. Mumps d. Nose and throat
questions.explanation: i-c, ii-d, iii-b, iv-a. Diphtheria is an infectious bacterial disease caused by a bacterium called Corynebacterium diphtheriae that produces toxins that can cause breathing di ﬃ culties, heart rhythm problems, and even death. Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted infection disease. It most commonly affects the urethra, rectum or throat. Mumps is an infectious disease caused by a virus. This can cause painful in ﬂ ammation of our parotid salivary glands (parotitis).

questions.question: Select the correct option about Kwashiorkor. Statement A : It is a form of malnutrition caused by a lack of fat in the diet. Statement B : Children who develop Kwashiorkor may not grow or develop properly and may remain stunted for the rest of their lives.

options.b: Both statements A and B are correct
options.c: Both statements A and B are incorrect

questions.explanation: Kwashiorkor is caused by deﬁ ciency of protein in the diet which causes ﬂuid retention and a swollen, distended abdomen, and most commonly affected babies between 1-3 years of age, particularly in developing countries with high levels of poverty and food insecurity. In 1933, Cicely Williams was the ﬁrst in Africa who described Kwashiorkor.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs is INCORRECTLY matched ?
questions.explanation: Acromegaly is a disorder that occurs when the body makes too much growth hormone (GH); Produced mainly in the pituitary gland (a pea-sized gland just below the brain). In adults, too much of this hormone causes bones, cartilage,body organs, and other tissues to increase in size.

questions.question: Match the columns. Column-A (Disorder)Column-B (Hormone/Gland) i. Addison's disease a. Adrenal gland ii. Hashimoto's diseaseb. Thyroid gland iii. Acromegaly c.Growth hormone iv. SIADH d. Vasopressin
questions.explanation: i-a, ii-b, iii-c, iv-d. Glands and their secreted hormones : Hypothalamus gland - Gonadotropin hormone. Pineal Gland - Melatonin hormone. Thyroid gland - Triiodothyronine hormone. Pancreas - Somatostatin and pancreatic polypeptide hormone. Adrenal Glands - Adrenaline hormone. Pituitary Gland - thyroid (stimulating hormone), LH (Luteinizing Hormone), FSH (follicle stimulating hormone).

questions.question: Match the columns.Column-A (Disorder) Column-B (Enzyme i. Gaucher disease a. Phenylalanin hydroxylase ii. Hunter syndrome b. Hexosaminidase iii. Tay-Sachs disease c. Iduronate-2-sulfatase iv. Phenylketonuria d.Glucocerebrosidase
questions.explanation: i-d, ii-c, iii-b, iv-a. Gaucher disease is caused by a buildup of fatty substances in organs like the spleen and liver. Hunter syndrome affects males, preventing proper digestion of certain sugar molecules. Tay-Sachs disease is a rare genetic disorder caused by the absence of an enzyme that breaks down fatty substances. Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inherited disorder causing a buildup of phenylalanine in the body.

questions.question: Which disease is caused by excessive iron deposition within the reticuloendothelial cells of the liver, spleen and bone marrow?
questions.explanation: Hemosiderosis . Aribo ﬂ avinosis is caused by deﬁ ciency of Vitamin B2 (Ribo ﬂ avin) include skin disorders, hyperemia (excess blood) and edema of the mouth and throat, angular stomatitis, cheilosis (swollen, cracked lips), hair loss, reproductive problems,sore throat, itchy and red eyes. Paraesthesia - An abnormal touch sensation, such as burning or prickling that is caused by underlying neurological disease or traumatic nerve damage. Dermatitis (eczema) - Redness, and irritation of the skin caused by air pollution.

questions.question: Deﬁ ciency of which of the following vitamins in the human diet causes a disease called xerophthalmia?
questions.explanation: Vitamin A (Retinol). Vitamin was discovered by Casimir Funk (1912).

questions.question: Which among the following organs in the human body, is most affected by Pneumonia disease?
questions.explanation: Lungs. Pneumonia is an inﬂ ammation of lungs caused by a bacterial, viral or fungal infection. The most common cause is Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus bacteria). Cough, Fever, sweating, chest pain and Loss of appetite are the most common symptoms.

questions.question: What is added to toothpaste to reduce tooth decay?
questions.explanation: Fluoride - It is a mineral that strengthens tooth enamel and makes it more resistant to acid attacks from bacteria in the mouth.

questions.question: Which among the following is NOT a bacterial disease ?
questions.explanation: Rabies. It is a Zoonotic and viral disease. It is caused by Ribonucleic Acid (RNA) virus that is present in the saliva of rabid animals (dog, monkey, etc.). Rabies Vaccine was discovered by Louis Pasteur in 1885.

questions.question: Which of the following is 'NOT' an example of communicable diseases?
questions.explanation: Diabetes. Communicable diseases - Caused by viruses or bacteria, that spread to one another through contact with contaminated surfaces, bodily ﬂuids, blood products, insect bites, or through the air. Examples - HIV, hepatitis A, B, and C, measles, in ﬂ uenza, coronaviruses, and blood-borne illnesses.

questions.question: The disease-causing microbes are called ________.
questions.explanation: Pathogens. Examples of Pathogens - Bacteria (Tuberculosis), Viruses (Covid - 19), Fungi (Candidiasis), Protists (Malaria), Parasitic worms (Taeniasis). Toxins - Substances created by plants and animals that are poisonous to humans. Example - Anthrax lethal toxin (Produced by Bacillus anthracis).

questions.question: "Goitre" is a disease of which of the following glands?
questions.explanation: Thyroid gland - It is a ductless endocrine gland situated in the anterior/front portion of the neck. Pituitary gland - It is a small, pea-sized gland located at the base of the brain. It plays a crucial role in regulating various bodily functions by producing and releasing hormones that control the activities of other endocrine glands in the body.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is not caused by a mosquito bite ?
questions.explanation: Hepatitis : Caused by Virus, Effects Liver, World Hepatitis Day - 28 July. Elephantiasis - Also called Lymphatic Filariasis, it impairs the lymphatic system. Dengue - Caused by Dengue Virus, Carrier - Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. Malaria : Caused by Plasmodium parasite. Spread by female Anopheles mosquitoes, World Malaria Day - 25 April.

questions.question: Chikungunya is an infection caused by _______ mosquito.
questions.explanation: Aedes : It is a species of mosquito that causes dengue, yellow fever and zika virus. Anopheles Mosquito is a species of mosquito that causesmalaria. Culex Mosquito is a species of mosquito that spreads viruses that cause Japanese encephalitis, West Nile virus.

questions.question: Which among the following is a bacterial disease?
questions.explanation: Leprosy . Hansen's disease (leprosy) is an infection caused by slow - growing bacteria called Mycobacterium leprae. It can affect the nerves, skin, eyes, and lining of the nose (nasal mucosa). Bacterial disease - Typhoid, Cholera, Tuberculosis. Viral disease - Common cold, In ﬂ uenza, HIV infection, Dengue Covid-19, Ebola. Protozoal disease - Malaria, Kala azar.

questions.question: ____ diseases last for only shorter periods of time.
questions.explanation: Acute. Acute conditions are often caused by a virus or an infection. Example - Common cold, typhoid, jaundice, cholera etc. Genetic disorder : An inherited medical condition caused by a DNA abnormality. Eg; Congenital deafness, Cystic ﬁbr osis, Beta thalassemia and Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA). A chronic condition is a health condition or disease that is persistent or otherwise long-lasting in its effects or a disease that comes with time. Eg; Arthritis, Asthma, Cancer etc.

questions.question: Which of the following disease is caused by fungi?
questions.explanation: Ring Worm. Fungi are responsible for various diseases in human beings. Aspergillus infection, Athlete's foot, Jock itch, Ringworm, Coccidioidomycosis, Sporotrichosis, valley fever, histoplasmosis are a few of the many deadly diseases caused by fungi. Tuberculosis, Anthrax, Tetanus, Leptospirosis, Pneumonia, Cholera, Botulism are the diseases caused by bacteria.

questions.question: Which among the following is a viral disease ?
questions.explanation: Chickenpox is a highly contagious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Varicella vaccine (developed by Michiaki Takahashi in 1974) is a vaccine that protects against chickenpox. Whooping Cough is caused by Bacteria (Bordetella pertussis).

questions.question: Which of the following options is correct regarding sexually transmitted disease (STD)? Statement A: Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) are infections transmitted from an infected person to an uninfected person through sexual contact. Statement B: HIV, HPV and Hepatitis B virus is responsible for STD.

options.a: Both Statements A and B incorrect
options.c: Both Statements A and B correct

questions.explanation: STDs can be caused by bacteria, viruses, or parasites. Examples - gonorrhea, genital herpes, human papillomavirus infection, HIV (Human immunode ﬁ ciency virus)/AIDS (Acquired Immune De ﬁ ciency Syndrome), chlamydia, and syphilis.

questions.question: Deﬁ ciency of which of the following vitamins causes excessive bleeding from wounds?
questions.explanation: Vitamin K bene ﬁ ts include supporting bone, and heart health. Prothrombin is a vitamin K-dependent protein directly involved with blood clotting. Osteocalcin is another protein that requires vitamin K to produce healthy bone tissue.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of plant diseases – microorganisms is correct? I. Citrus canker – Virus II. Rust of wheat – Fungi
questions.explanation: Rust of wheat – Fungi . (Plant disease, Microorganisms) - (Yellow vein mosaic, Virus), (Aster yellows, Bacteria), (Crown gall, Bacteria), (Ergot, Fungi), (Anthracnose, Fungi), (Black knot, Fungi), (Snow mold, Fungi).

questions.question: Typhoid fever is caused by ______.
questions.explanation: Bacteria. Its diseases and their causative agents - Diphtheria (Corynebacterium diphtheriae), Cholera (Vibrio cholerae), Leprosy (Mycobacterium leprae), Pertussis (Bordetella pertussis), Tetanus (Clostridium tetani), Plague (Yersinia pestis), etc.

questions.question: How is tuberculosis spread in humans?
questions.explanation: Droplet infection. Tuberculosis (TB) - It is usually caused by the Bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared TB a "Global Health Emergency" in 1993.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a symptom of Beriberi caused due to the deﬁ ciency of Vitamin B1?
questions.explanation: Slowly healing wounds . Symptoms of Beri Beri - Di ﬃ culty walking, Loss of muscle function or paralysis of the lower legs, Mental confusion/speech di ﬃ culties, Loss of feeling (sensation) in hands and feet, Strange eye movements (nystagmus), Tingling, Vomiting.

questions.question: Which disease refers to the inﬂ ammation of the liver caused by a variety of infectious viruses and non - infectious agents leading to a variety of health problems ?
questions.explanation: Hepatitis. Hepatotropic viruses include A, B, C, D, and E. World Hepatitis Day - 28th July. Pneumonia can be caused by viruses, bacteria, and fungi. Diabetes is a disease that occurs when blood sugar becomes too high.

questions.question: What disease in adults means ‘soft bones’ that usually develops due to a de ﬁ ciency of vitamin D (often from not getting enough sunlight), or less often,digestive or kidney disease?
questions.explanation: Osteomalacia - a disorder of “bone softening” (common in women during pregnancy). Osteomyelitis is inﬂ ammation of the bone caused by infection, generally in the legs, arm, or spine. Osteopenia is a condition that occurs when the body doesn't make new bone as quickly as it reabsorbs old bone.

questions.question: Poor sanitation conditions may NOT be the likely reason behind which of the following diseases/conditions?
questions.explanation: Arthritis is caused by inﬂ ammation of the joints. Cholera is an acute diarrheal illness caused by infection of the intestine with Vibrio cholerae bacteria.

questions.question: _______ is a disorder resulting in abnormal electrical discharge from the brain cells causing seizures,
questions.explanation: Epilepsy . Prostatitis is a disorder of the prostate gland usually associated with in ﬂ ammation. A low blood sugar level, also called hypoglycaemia is where the level of sugar (glucose) in your blood drops too low. Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inﬂ ammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet.

questions.question: Which of the following factors is responsible for the disease called 'Mad Hatter Disease'?
questions.explanation: Mercury poisoning . The inhalation of mercury vapour can produce harmful effects on the nervous, digestive and immune systems, lungs and kidneys, and may be fatal.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is NOT caused by a ﬂa vivirus ?
questions.explanation: Polio (Poliomyelitis). It is adisease caused by the poliovirus. It invades the nervous system and can cause total paralysis in a matter of hours.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases marked by dementia, diarrhoea, and dermatitis, is also known as ‘the three Ds’?
questions.explanation: Pellagra is a disease that results due to severe Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deﬁ ciency. The disease can also develop due to : Gastrointestinal diseases, Weight loss (bariatric) surgery, Anorexia Excessive alcohol use, Carcinoid syndrome (group of symptoms associated with tumours of the small intestine, colon, appendix, and bronchial tubes in the lungs).

questions.question: Trachoma is a preventable disease that results from poor hygiene and sanitation. Which of the following body parts does it affect?
questions.explanation: Eyes. Trachoma - It is a disease of the eye caused by infection with the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. Blindness from trachoma is irreversible.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is caused by Helicobacter pylori ?
questions.explanation: Gastritis. Helicobacter pylori is a type of bacteria that causes infection in the stomach. It is the main cause of peptic ulcers, and it can also cause gastritis and stomach cancer.

questions.question: The cause of Siderosis is excessive deposition of ______in the body tissue.
questions.explanation: Iron. Siderosis is a type of occupational lung disease caused by inhaling iron particles through dust or fumes.

questions.question: Which of the following animals can change their gender during their lifespan
questions.explanation: Snail. Most land snails are hermaphrodites, meaning they have both male and female reproductive organs. They are able to produce sperm and eggs while mating with a partner. The male reproductive organ of the snail can never fertilize the female genitals of the snail. Animals who can change their sex during their life : Clown ﬁ sh, Bearded dragons, Banana slugs.

questions.question: In a dihybrid cross between two heterozygous fruit ﬂies with brown bodies and red eyes (BbEe BbEe), what × will be the probability of getting BBEE genotype ?
questions.explanation: 1/16. Each parent can produce four types of gametes: BE, Be, bE, and be, with equal probability (1/4 each). To obtain the BBEE genotype, the offspring must receive the B and E alleles from both parents. The probability of getting BB from Bb × Bb cross is 1/4, and the probability of getting EE from Ee × Ee cross is also 1/4. Therefore, the combined probability of getting BBEE is (1/4) * (1/4) = 1/16.

questions.question: In honey bees, _____

options.a: males are haploid and females are diploid.
options.b: males are tetraploid and females are triploid.
options.c: males are diploid and females are haploid.
options.d: males are triploid and females are tetraploid.

questions.explanation: males are haploid and females are diploid. The females are diploid having 32 chromosomes and males are haploid, i.e., having 16 chromosomes. This is called a haplodiploid sex determination system and has special characteristic features such as the males produce sperms by mitosis, they do not have father and thus cannot have sons, but have a grandfather and can have grandsons.

questions.question: Identify an organism that exhibits metagenesis.
questions.explanation: Obelia (sea fur) : A genus of hydrozoans. It forms a light-brown or whitish plant-like fur in the seas. Metagenesis - The phenomenon in which one generation of certain plants andanimals reproduce asexually, followed by the sexually reproducing generation. Spongilla - A genus of freshwater sponges. Sycon - A genus of calcareous sponges belonging to the family Sycettidae. Euspongia - The typical genus of ﬁbr ous sponges of the family Spongiidae, having a very elastic and homogeneous framework throughout.

questions.question: The stage of the embryo in which all the body parts can be identi ﬁ ed is called _________ .
questions.explanation: Foetus. Uterus - A pear - shaped and hollow muscular organ located in the female pelvis between the bladder and rectum. Ovulation - A phase of the female menstrual cycle that involves the release of an egg (ovum) from one of the ovaries. Zygote - A fertilized egg cell that results from the union of a female gamete (egg, or ovum) with a male gamete (sperm).

questions.question: The transformation of the larva into an adult through drastic change is called ___________.
questions.explanation: Metamorphosis - A biological process involving an abrupt change in the animal's body structure due to cell growth and differentiation .The new individuals which are born from the eggs continue to grow till they become adults. In some animals, the young ones may look very different from the adults. Metamorphosis cycle has four stages : Egg, Larva, Pupa and Adult. Examples : Butter ﬂ ies, moths, frogs, toads, etc.

questions.question: How many arteries are there in an umbilical cord?
questions.explanation: Two. The umbilical cord is a tube that connects the mother with the baby in her womb during pregnancy. It normally contains two arteries (the umbilical arteries ) and one vein ( the umbilical vein).

questions.question: ______ is the ability of a single cell to produce a fertile, adult individual.
questions.explanation: Totipotency .Pluripotency isdeﬁ ned as the capacity of individual cells to initiate all lineages of the mature organism. Cloning is a technique scientists use to make exact genetic copies of living things. A mutation occurs when a DNA gene is damaged or changed in such a way as to alter the genetic message carried by that gene.

questions.question: The phenomenon whereby the female gamete undergoes development to form new organisms without fertilisation in some organisms like honey bees, some lizards and birds is called :
questions.explanation: Parthenogenesis is a form of reproduction in which an egg can develop into an embryo without being fertilized by a sperm. Budding or blastogenesis is a type of asexual reproduction in which a new organism develops from an outgrowth or bud due to cell division at one particular site. Apomixis refers to the formation of the plant from a seed without fertilization or normal sexual reproduction.

questions.question: Which of the following statements best de ﬁ nes the monoecious?

options.a: A ﬂower with both androecium and gynoecium

questions.explanation: Monoecious plants bear both purely male and purely female ﬂowers. Examples include castor, cucumber, and maize. In contrast, dioecious plants have male and female ﬂowers on separate plants, such as papaya.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a component of a ﬂower ?
questions.explanation: Spines. They are modi ﬁ ed leaves or stems that serve as a defense mechanism in plants, particularly in cacti and succulents. Androecium : The male reproductive part of the ﬂower , consisting of stamens ( ﬁ laments and anthers). Corolla : The collective term for the petals of a ﬂower . Calyx : The collective term for the sepals (green, leaf-like structures) that protect the ﬂower bud.

questions.question: By which of the following methods do red algae reproduce?
questions.explanation: Fragmentation. Algae reproduce through vegetative, asexual, and sexual methods: Vegetative Reproduction: This occurs by fragmentation, where each fragment develops into a new thallus. Asexual Reproduction: This involves the production of various types of spores, with zoospores being the most common. Sexual Reproduction: in algae involves the fusion of gametes, which can be isogamous (fusion of similar gametes) or anisogamous (fusion of dissimilar gametes), leading to the formation of zygotes that develop into new individuals.

questions.question: Which types of gametes are found in Spirogyra?
questions.explanation: Isogamous and non - ﬂagellated. Repr oduction in Spirogyra: Spirogyra, a genus of green algae, reproduces sexually through isogamous (similar in size) and non- ﬂ agellated gametes. Two adjacent cells form a conjugation tube, allowing the male gametangium's contents to move into the female gametangium, resulting in the formation of a zygote.

questions.question: Which of the following is a part of apical meristem found in roots.
questions.explanation: Protoderm. Apical meristem is the region of plant tissue where growth occurs, and it's found in both roots and shoots. In roots, the apical meristem consists of three primary meristematic tissues: Protoderm (outermost layer) - Gives rise to the epidermis. Ground meristem (middle layer) - Gives rise to the cortex and endodermis. Procambium (innermost layer) - Gives rise to the vascular tissue.

questions.question: The reproduction process inwhich only a single parent is involved is called ___________.
questions.explanation: Asexual reproduction - Observed in both multicellular and unicellular organisms and does not involve any kind of gamete fusion. Offspring are genetically similar to their parents. Different types : Binary Fission - Cell divide (Archaea and Bacteria). Budding (Bacteria, yeast, corals, ﬂatworms, Jellyﬁ sh and sea anemones). Fragmentation (Spirogyra, Planaria). Vegetative Propagation (Potato tubers, runners, onion). Sporogenesis (Plants, Algae, Fungi).

questions.question: The innermost part of a ﬂower is called the _______.
questions.explanation: Pistil (the female reproductive part of a ﬂower). It has three parts which are stigma, style, and ovary. Sepals (collectively called the calyx) are modi ﬁ ed leaves that encase the developing ﬂower . Petals (collectively known as the corolla) are modi ﬁ ed leaves that surround the reproductive parts of ﬂowers. Stamen is the male part of the ﬂower . Generally, it is shaped like a bowling pin and is located in the ﬂower 's center. It consists of Anther and Filament.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an asexual form of reproduction in plants?
questions.explanation: Pollination. Flowering plants reproduce sexually through a process called pollination. It is the act of transferring pollen grains from the male anther of a ﬂower to the female stigma. The two types of pollination are self-pollination (if pollen is transferred to it from any ﬂower of the same plant) and cross-pollination ( if the pollen comes from a ﬂower of a different plant).

questions.question: Which part of a ﬂower is the sticky surface at the top of the pistil, it traps and holds the pollen?
questions.explanation: Stigma. It traps and holds the pollen. During the process of pollination, pollen moves from the male parts to the female parts i.e stigma where pollen germinates.

questions.question: A type of asexual reproduction in which new plants are produced from roots, stems, leaves and buds are known as :
questions.explanation: Vegetative propagation. Layering is a technique of plant propagation where the new plant remains at least partially attached to the mother plant while forming new roots.

questions.question: ________ are amoeboid (amoeba like movement, with pseudopodia) that can squeeze out through capillary walls.
questions.explanation: White blood cells (leukocytes) use amoeboid movement and pseudopodia to squeeze through capillary walls in a process called diapedesis and reach sites of infection or injury. Red blood cells (round and biconcave): Their main role is oxygen transport. Guard cells: Found in plants; they control stomatal opening and closing. Nerve cells (Branched and long): Specialized for transmitting electrical signals.

questions.question: In the context of cell organelles, a centriole is:

options.a: a membrane-bound cell organelle that contains digestive enzymes
options.b: a stack of small ﬂat sacs formed by membranes inside the cell's cytoplasm
options.c: a heterogeneous family of organelles found ubiquitously in plant cells
options.d: a paired barrel-shaped organelle located in the cytoplasm of animal cells near the nuclear envelope

questions.explanation: Centrioles play a role in organizing microtubules that serve as the cell's skeletal system. They help determine the locations of the nucleus and other organelles within the cell. Lysosomes are membrane-bound sacs containing digestive enzymes. The Golgi apparatus consists of stacked, ﬂat sacs involved in protein modi ﬁ cation and transport. Plastids, found in plant and algal cells, are responsible for food production and storage, and contain pigments essential for photosynthesis and color change.

questions.question: Identify another name of Choanocytes.
questions.explanation: Collar cells. These special cells are important for ﬁlter feeding in sponges, as well as in reproduction and circulation. Stem cells are the only cells in your body that make different cell types, like blood, bone and muscle cells. They also repair damaged tissues. Flame cells, also known as protonephridia or solenocytes, are specialized excretory cells found in freshwater invertebrates like ﬂatworms, rotifers, and ribbon worms. They function similarly to kidneys, removing waste from the organism's body through ﬁltr ation.

questions.question: A part of the cell other than the nucleus which has DNA and ribosomes and can thus make its own proteins is known as:
questions.explanation: Mitochondria (singular: mitochondrion) are found in nearly all eukaryotic cells and are known as the powerhouses of the cell. They have two membrane coverings. The outer membrane is porous while the inner membrane is deeply folded. Function: Primarily responsible for producing energy in the form of ATP (Adenosine triphosphate).

questions.question: The digestive enzymes inside lysosomes are made by:
questions.explanation: rough endoplasmic reticulum. Digestive enzymes are proteins that break down food so your body can absorb nutrients. Plastids are double membrane bound organellesfound in the cytoplasm of plant cells and some protists such as Euglena. Golgi apparatus is a central membrane organelle for tra ﬃ cking and post-translational modi ﬁ cation of protein and lipid in the cell.

questions.question: The cytoplasmic zone surrounding the Golgi complex possesses no cell organelles. This zone of clear cytoplasm is called:
questions.explanation: zone of exclusion. This clear space is observed due to the exclusion of organelles like mitochondria, ER, or other structures from the immediate vicinity of the Golgi complex. Cytosine found in nucleic acids, such as DNA and RNA, that are part of the macromolecular fraction of living tissue. Cytochromes are found in the mitochondria (cristae) and chloroplasts of eukaryotes, in the chloroplast of plants, in photosynthetic microorganisms, and bacteria. Cytosol is aﬂuid that is present in the cell membrane and is the primary component of the cytoplasm.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of mesosomes?

options.a: Increase the surface area of the plasma membrane and enzymatic content
options.d: DNA replication and distribution to daughter cells

questions.explanation: Locomotion. Mesosomes are infoldings of the plasma membrane in prokaryotic cells. They increase surface area for enzyme activity, aid in respiration, and are involved in DNA replication and distribution during cell division.

questions.question: Several biological processes are catalysed by enzymes. Digestive enzymes are present in which part of the cell?
questions.explanation: Lysosomes. These organelles are ﬁlled with hydrolytic enzymes that break down biological polymers like proteins, carbohydrates, nucleic acids, and lipids. Lysosomes are sometimes called the "suicide bag" of the cell because they disassemble cell molecules when the cell ismalfunctioning or nearing the end of its life cycle.

questions.question: The Krebs cycle of aerobic respiration is carried out within which of the following cell organelles?
questions.explanation: Mitochondria. Mitochondria are organelles that are known as the "powerhouses" of a cell because they produce energy. They convert oxygen and nutrients into adenosine triphosphate (ATP), which is used by the cell for energy-consuming activities. The Krebs cycle is also known as the citric acid cycle or the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle. It's a central part of cellular respiration, and it harvests energy from acetyl molecules in the form of ATP .

questions.question: Which of the following pairs is INCORRECT regarding the grade of organisation and its example ?

options.c: Cell-tissue grade organisation - Jelly ﬁ sh

questions.explanation: Euplectella, is a genus of glass sponges which includes the well-known Venus' Flower Basket, exhibits a cellular grade of organization rather than a tissue-organ grade. A cellular grade of organisation is an aggregation of cells that are functionally differentiated.

questions.question: Which of the following Illustrations shows the mitochondrion’s structural details?
questions.explanation: b. The mitochondrion is a double - membraned, rod - shaped structure found in both plant and animal cells. Its size ranges from 0.5 to 1.0 micrometre in diameter. The structure comprises an outer membrane, an inner membrane, and a gel-like material called the matrix.

questions.question: Which cell organelle is de ﬁ ned as the small round organelle that undergoes oxidation reaction to produce hydrogen peroxide?
questions.explanation: Peroxisomes. Peroxisomes have multiple functions like lipid metabolism, processing reactive oxygen species, oxidative processes, and catabolism of D-amino acids, polyamines, and bile acids, with enzymes like peroxidase and catalase converting harmful peroxides to water; in plants, peroxisomes facilitate photosynthesis, seed germination, and e ﬃ cient carbon ﬁxation.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of prokaryotic cells?
questions.explanation: Bacteria. Prokaryotic cells lack a well-organized nucleus, with their genetic material consisting of a single DNA molecule located in the cytoplasm. These cells do not have a nuclear membrane, and they also lack organelles such as mitochondria, lysosomes, endoplasmic reticulum, chloroplasts, and nucleolus. Examples of prokaryotic cells include blue-green algae. Yeast is an example of a eukaryotic unicellular fungi cell.

questions.question: Which of the following illustrations is related to chloroplasts?
questions.explanation: c. Plastids are classi ﬁ ed into chloroplasts, chromoplasts, and leucoplasts, based on their pigments. Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll and carotenoids, crucial for capturing light energy in photosynthesis. Chromoplasts have fat-soluble carotenoid pigments (like carotene and xanthophylls) that give plants yellow, orange, or red colors. Leucoplasts are colorless and vary in shape, storing nutrients within the plant.

questions.question: In the context of cell division, which chromosomal behaviour takes place at the leptotene stage?
