questions.explanation: Chromosomes begin to condense. The leptotene stage is theﬁrst ofﬁv e substages in prophase I of meiosis, a specialized cell division process that reduces the number of chromosomes by half. During this stage, chromosomes manifest as long, thin threads. Meiosis produces haploid gametes in sexually reproducing organisms, contrasting with mitosis, where a single cell divides into two identical daughter cells. Mitosis comprises several stages: Prophase, Metaphase, Anaphase, and Telophase.

questions.question: Which of the following enzymes are essential of DNA replication in an animal cell ?

options.b: Reverse transcriptase, DNA polymerase, DNA primase
options.c: Topoisomerase, DNA ligase, DNA polymerase, DNA primase

questions.explanation: The essential enzymes for DNA replication are: Topoisomerase: Relaxes the DNA molecule by cutting and rejoining it, reducing tension and supercoiling. DNA primase: Adds RNA primers to the template strands at speci ﬁ c regions, providing a starting point for DNA synthesis. DNA polymerase: Synthesizes new DNA strands by adding nucleotides to the primers, matching the base pairing rules. DNA ligase: Seals the gaps between the newly synthesized DNA segments, forming a continuous strand.

questions.question: What do you mean by semiconservative DNA replication ?

options.a: DNA is dependent on RNA for the synthesis of proteins
options.b: RNA is dependent on DNA for the synthesis of proteins
options.c: After the completion of replication, each DNA molecule would have one parental and one newly synthesised strand.
options.d: After the completion of replication, each DNA molecule would have two parental and two newly synthesised strand.

questions.explanation: Semiconservative DNA replication refers to the process by which DNA is replicated, resulting in two daughter DNA molecules, each containing: One parental strand (the original template strand) and One newly synthesized strand (created during replication).Q.167. In a symport: SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (4th shift) (a) both molecules cross the membrane in the same direction (b) a molecule moves across a membrane independent of other molecules (c) both molecules cross the membrane in the opposite direction (d) a molecule moves across a membrane dependent of other molecules Sol.167.(a) Symport: Two or more molecules move together in the same direction across the membrane using the same transport protein. Antiport: Two or more molecules move in opposite directions across the membrane. Uniport: A single molecule moves across the membrane independently of other molecules.

questions.question: The cell wall of bacteria is made up of:
questions.explanation: Peptidoglycan is a complex molecule made of sugars and amino acids. It provides structural support and shape to bacterial cells and protects them from environmental stress. Glycogen is a storage polysaccharide found in animals, not related to cell walls. Cellulose is a polysaccharide that makes up the cell walls of plants, not bacteria. Peptones are products of protein digestion used as nutrient sources in microbial culture media, not structural components of cell walls.

questions.question: Who was the ﬁrst person to conduct a systematic study of chromosomes during division and called this process mitosis ?
questions.explanation: Walther Flemming. He was a German biologist and a founder of cytogenetics. His key discoveries - Chromatin, Chromosomes. Thomas Hunt Morgan received the 1933 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his discoveries concerning the role of chromosomes in heredity.

questions.question: What are the thin ﬁlament ous extensions that the motile bacterial cells have from their cell wall called?
questions.explanation: Flagella. The bacterial ﬂagella are long (3 to 12 µm), ﬁlament ous surface appendages about 12 to 30 nm in diameter. The protein subunits of a ﬂagellum are assembled to form a cylindrical structure with a hollow core. A ﬂagellum consists of three parts: Filament, Hook, and Basal body. Pili are short and thin thread-like structures projecting out from the cell wall in some bacteria.

questions.question: Which is an integral membrane protein that forms the tetramer and facilitates the diffusion of water and some small, unmodi ﬁ ed solutes across cellular membranes?
questions.explanation: Aquaporins. Immunoglobulins (antibodies) are Y-shaped proteins that help the body ﬁght infections. Mucins are proteins found in epithelial tissues and provide lubrication and protection. Transferrin is a protein that transports iron throughout the body and is an important indicator of iron status.

questions.question: What is the fourth step in mitosis where non-kinetochore spindle ﬁbr es lengthen and elongate the cell?
questions.explanation: Anaphase. Mitosis is divided into four stages namely prophase, metaphase, anaphase and telophase. Prophase the chromosomes condense and centrosomes move to opposite sides of the nucleus, initiating formation of the mitotic spindle. Metaphase is a stage during the process of cell division (mitosis or meiosis). Telophase is the last phase of mitosis before cytokinesis, and is where sister chromatids separate, and the new nuclei are formed.

questions.question: Identify the organelle present in plant cells that is not there in an animal cell.
questions.explanation: Plastids. The plant cells have cell walls, plastids, and chloroplasts. These organelles are not present in animal cells. There are three types of plastids, which are thechloroplast, chromoplast and leucoplast. Animal cells have centrioles which are absent in almost all plant cells.

questions.question: Identify an organelle found both in eukaryotic as well as prokaryotic.
questions.explanation: Ribosomes. Within the cell, ribosomes are found not only in the cytoplasm but also within the two organelles - chloroplasts (in plants) and mitochondria and on rough ER. In prokaryotes, ribosomes are associated with the plasma membrane of the cell. They are about 15 nm by 20 nm in size and are made of two subunits - 50S and 30S units which when present together form 70S prokaryotic ribosomes. Ribosomes are the site of protein synthesis.

questions.question: Which chromosome is involved in the production of 'masked' mRNAs for early development?
questions.explanation: Lampbrush chromosome. These are found in oocytes of animals like sharks, amphibians, reptiles, and birds (most distinct during the Diplotene stage). Polytene Chromosomes - First seen by Balbiani (1881) in salivary glands of larva of Chironomus insect (midges — belongs to order Diptera). An autosome is one of the numbered chromosomes, as opposed to the sex chromosomes. Humans have 22 pairs of autosomes and one pair of sex chromosomes (XX or XY).

questions.question: The cell wall of spirogyra contains:
questions.explanation: cellulose. Each cell of Spirogyra is surrounded by two layered cell walls. Its inner layer is made up of cellulose and outer layer is made up of pectose but quantity of cellulosic substances is high in comparison to pectose. Lignin is a biopolymer that binds cellulose and hemicellulose ﬁbers and provides stiffness to plants. Suberin is a cell wall-associated biopolymer found in speci ﬁ c cell types, such as root epidermis, root endodermis.Q.177. Which of the following cell organelles is involved in apoptosis? Matriculation Level 26/06/2024 (Shift - 1) (a) Golgi (b) ER (c) Lysosome (d) Mitochondria Sol.177.(d) Mitochondria. Apoptosis, or programmed cell death, is a process where cells die through a series of molecular steps. Mitochondria play a crucial role in apoptosis (programmed cell death) by releasing cytochrome c, which triggers the activation of caspases, the enzymes that execute the cell death process. Q.178 . Chromosomes found in the salivary glands of Drosophila are : Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift - 4) (a) giant chromosome lampbrush (b) presence of fat digestive enzymes (c) presence of minute chromosomes (d) giant chromosome polytene Sol.178.(d) giant chromosome polytene. Saliva is mainly produced by three pairs of salivary glands, the parotids (cheek), the submaxillary or submandibular (lower jaw) and the sub-linguals (below the tongue). These glands situated just outside the buccal cavity secrete salivary juice into the buccal cavity. Q.179 . What are ribosomes made up of? Higher Secondary 26/06/2024 (Shift - 2) (a) Only RNA (b) Only proteins (c) Only DNA (d) Proteins and RNA Sol.179.(d) Proteins and RNA. Ribosomes are cell organelles involved in protein synthesis, earning them the name 'protein factories.' They consist of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and approximately 40 to 80 proteins, which provide structural support. Ribosomes have two subunits: large and small. The subunits remain separate when not synthesizing proteins and come together during the process of protein synthesis.

questions.question: In the context of movement of cells, exocytosis is the process by which :

options.a: cells absorb external material by engul ﬁ ng it with the cell membrane
options.b: cell death is brought about through a heavily regulated sequence of events
options.c: cells move waste materials from within the cell into the extracellular ﬂuid
options.d: a cell takes in the ﬂuids along with dissolved small molecules

questions.explanation: Exocytosis involves the fusion of intracellular vesicles with the plasma membrane, releasing their contents while adding hydrophobic components to the membrane. The ﬂexibility of the cell membrane also enables the cell to engulf in food and other material from its external environment. Such processes are known as endocytosis. Amoeba acquires its food through such processes. Pinocytosis is a type of endocytosis in which the living cells ingest ﬂuid substances.

questions.question: Identify the INCORRECT pair of cell shape types and their examples.
questions.explanation: Oblong – Nerve cells. Example of oblong cell shape type - Paramecium. Some shapes of cell : Oval, Round, Polygonal, Spherical, Elongated, Cuboidal, Disk-like, Oblong, and Irregular. Nerve cells (neurons) transmit messages throughout the body via electrical signals. Chlamydomonas is a single-celled green algae found in freshwater, known for its ﬂagella and photosynthesis. Muscle cells (myocytes) are the smallest units of muscle tissue.

questions.question: ________is associated with the production and metabolism of fats and steroid hormones.
questions.explanation: Smooth endoplasmic reticulum. The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a large network of membrane-bound tubes and sheets. There are two types of ER– rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) and smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER). RER looks rough under a microscope because it has particles called ribosomes attached to its surface.

questions.question: Which structural layer in some cell types is composed mainly of carbohydrates like cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin in the ratio 4 : 3 : 3 and some fatty substances like wax?
questions.explanation: Cell walls - They are found inmost of the plant cells, bacteria, algae, fungi, and some archaea. The cell wall is a rigid semi-permeable structure made up of cellulose or chitin.

questions.question: The primary function of which channel protein is to transport water across the cell membrane in response to the osmotic gradient created by active solute transport ?
questions.explanation: Aquaporins. These are a family of small, integral membrane proteins that are expressed broadly throughout the animal and plant kingdoms. Mucins : Heavily O-glycosylated linear glycoproteins that are secreted by higher organisms to protect and lubricate epithelial cell surfaces. Transferrin : A blood plasma glycoprotein that plays a central role in iron metabolism and is responsible for ferric-ion delivery. Cupredoxins : Small proteins that contain type I copper centers. They function as electron transfer shuttles between proteins.

questions.question: Most centrioles have a _________ structure of triple microtubules, which are present in pairs and arranged orthogonally after duplication.
questions.explanation: 9 + 0. The centrioles form the basal body of cilia or ﬂagella, and spindle ﬁbr es that give rise to spindle apparatus during cell division in animal cells. The central part of the proximal region of the centriole is also proteinaceous and called the hub, which is connected with tubules of the peripheral triplets by radial spokes made of protein. In animal cells, centrioles also form spindle apparatus during cell division.

questions.question: Which is a reversible, ﬂuor escent red, acidic dye used to stain cytoplasm, red blood cells, collagen and muscle ﬁbr es for histological examination?
questions.explanation: Eosin (the aniline dye) is an acid dye that stains cytoplasm, muscle, and connective tissues in various shades of pink and orange. Safranin is a lipophilic cationic dye which accumulates in mitochondria according to the inside negative potential inenergised mitochondria.

questions.question: Which cellular structure controls cell motility, adhesion, and polarity at interphase, and facilitates the organisation of spindle poles during mitosis ?
questions.explanation: Centrosomes - Membrane - free organelles that serve as main microtubule-organizing centers in distinct eukaryotic lineages.

questions.question: What is the percentage of proteins in the cell membrane?
questions.explanation: 40-60%. Cell membrane (plasma membrane) - It separates the interior of the cell from the outside environment. It is composed primarily of fatty-acid-based lipids and proteins. The cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all forms of life. It was discovered by a British scientist, Robert Hooke in 1665.

questions.question: What do you call the ﬂuid matrix ﬁlling in the cell ?
questions.explanation: Cytoplasm. It is composed of water, salts, and various organic molecules. Golgi bodies (Golgi apparatus) - It helps process and package proteins and lipid molecules, especially proteins destined to be exported from the cell.

questions.question: The main function of centriole is:

options.a: to maintain mineral composition in bacterial cell
options.b: to help plant cell for multiplication
options.c: to help cell division in animal cell
options.d: to maintain rigidity in plant cell

questions.explanation: Centrosome - An organelle containing two cylindrical structures called centrioles. Centrioles form the basal body of cilia or ﬂagella, and spindle ﬁbr es that give rise to spindle apparatus during cell division in animal cells. It plays a role in organizing microtubules that serve as the cell's skeletal system. They help determine the locations of the nucleus and other organelles within the cell.

questions.question: During which phase of the cell cycle does metabolic changes assemble the cytoplasmic material required for mitosis and cytokinesis?
questions.explanation: G2 phase. The different phases of a cell cycle include : Interphase (This phase includes the G1 phase, S phase and the G2 phase), M phase (This is the mitotic phase and is divided into prophase, metaphase, anaphase and telophase) and Cytokinesis (In this phase the cytoplasm of the cell divides). S phase - Cell synthesises a complete copy of the DNA. M phase - Cell divides its copied DNA and cytoplasm to make two new cells. G1 phase - First gap phase, the cell grows physically larger.

questions.question: How big are red blood cells in diameter ?
questions.explanation: 7.5 μm. Red blood cells (erythrocytes) - It is rich in hemoglobin, an iron rich molecule that can bind oxygen and also imparts red color to the blood. RBC is produced in the bone marrow (erythropoiesis process) and has a life cycle of 120 days. RBC is recycled by macrophages. RBC Disorders: Anemia (Lower than normal RBC), Polycythemia (Excess of RBC), Sickle Cell Disease (Genetic Disorder causes RBCs to take on a crescent shape), Thalassemia (Genetic blood disorders that result in abnormal hemoglobin production).

questions.question: What is the length of a bacterial cell?
questions.explanation: 3 to 5 μm. Bacteria are single - celled microorganisms. Bacterial cell - Prokaryotic cells, lacking well - de ﬁ ned nuclei and membrane-bound organelles, and with chromosomes composed of a single closed DNA circle. Length of cells in organisms : Human - 20-30 micrometres. Plants - 10 to 100 micrometers.

questions.question: What do you call a Glycocalyx that is a loose sheath type?
questions.explanation: Slime layer. It is a type ofglycocalyx that is loosely organized and notﬁrmly attached to the cell wall. It is a thin, diffuse layer of polysaccharides and proteins that surrounds some bacterial cells. The slime layer can help bacteria adhere to surfaces and protect them from dehydration. The glycocalyx is a dense, gel-like meshwork that surrounds the cell, constituting a physical barrier for any object to enter the cell.

questions.question: Which process is sometimes called "reduction division" because it reduces the number of chromosomes to half the normal number to form sperm and eggs?
questions.explanation: Meiosis. The cell cycle is divided into two basic phases : Interphase and M Phase (Mitosis phase). The M Phase represents the phase when the actual cell division or mitosis occurs and the interphase represents the phase between two successive M phases (Cytokinesis and Karyokinesis).

questions.question: By what name are the ﬂat membr ane-enclosed sacs present in the Golgi apparatus known?
questions.explanation: Cisternae - It is a membrane-bound cell organelle consisting of a series of ﬂattened membr anous sacs that look like stacked pouches. Organelles present in cells - Nucleus, Endoplasmic Reticulum, Mitochondria, Centriole, Ribosome, Vacuole, Lysosome.

questions.question: Which cell found in the bone marrow acts as a repair system for the body ?
questions.explanation: Stem cells - Unspecialised cells which divide to produce two daughter cells, one of which remains a stem cell and the other one becomes differentiated. The major sources of stem cells are embryos and adult tissues (adult stem cells). Stem cells are characterised into three types depending on their potency : Unipotent cells, pluripotent cells and multipotent cells.

questions.question: During cell division, the formation of a new cell wall is followed by the accumulation of:
questions.explanation: Phragmoplast is a plant cell specialized cylindrical structure formed during late cytokinesis. Periplasm - The space is the area between the cell wall and the plasma membrane. The term Protoplast was introduced by Hanstein. It refers to the entire cell, excluding the cell wall. The Peristome is a teeth-like projection that surrounds the mouth of the capsule in most of the members of Bryidae (Mosses) of bryophytes.

questions.question: Which part of a cell converts nutrients into energy ?
questions.explanation: Mitochondria - Double membrane-bound cell organelles present in most eukaryotic organisms (such as animals, plants and fungi). Chromosome - A thread - like microscopic structure formed by coiling of DNA packaged with protein containing all genetic material of an organism.

questions.question: Which cell analysis technique is used to rapidly analyse single cells or particles as they ﬂow through single or multiple lasers while suspended in a buffered salt-based solution?
questions.explanation: Flow cytometry - It is a laser-based technique used to detect and analyze the chemical and physical characteristics of cells or particles, It is to evaluate bone marrow, peripheral blood and other ﬂuids in your body. Mass spectroscopy - Used to identify and quantify molecules by measuring their mass-to-charge ratio. Electrochemical analysis - Used to measure the electrical properties of cells or particles. Multiple displacement ampli ﬁ cation - Used to amplify DNA.

questions.question: The division of cytoplasm is known as:
questions.explanation: Cytokinesis : It is a physical process which divides the cytoplasm of a parental cell into two daughter cells. Karyokinesis : Division of the nucleus during mitosis or meiosis. Cytoskeleton : It is a network of ﬁbr es forming the eukaryotic cells, prokaryotic cells and archaeans. Cytosol : The ﬂuid in which organelles of the cell reside. The primary component of cytosol is water.

questions.question: Which of the following cell organelles can make copies of themselves ?
questions.explanation: Mitochondria (Powerhouse of cells) .Vacuole - A membrane-bound cell organelle. In animal cells, vacuoles are generally small and help sequester waste products.

questions.question: Which type of haploid unicellular eukaryote cells has a diameter of ~10 μm, and about half of their volume is occupied by cup-shaped chloroplasts ?
questions.explanation: Chlamydomonas : Single -celled green algae found in both freshwater and marine habitats. It reproduces asexually by zoospores, hypnospores. Hydrodictyon (water net) : green algae, found in freshwater. Ulva (sea lettuce) : Green algae, found in marine environments. Oedogonium : Green algae, found in freshwater ponds, streams, and even in some terrestrial environments with high humidity.

questions.question: Which cell organelles are known as cell's post o ﬃ ce ?
questions.explanation: Golgi apparatus. It is responsible for processing and packaging proteins and lipid molecules, particularly those destined for export.

questions.question: Which of the following cells are found in the liver of mammals?
questions.explanation: Kupffer cells. They are resident liver macrophages and maintain liver functions. They are the ﬁrst innate immune cells and protect the liver from bacterial infections. Purkinje cells - They are a unique type of neuron, speci ﬁ c to the cerebellar cortex. Microglia cells are resident cells of the brain that regulate brain development,maintenance of neuronal networks, and injury repair. Sensory cells - They occur in specialized organs such as the eyes, ears, nose, and mouth, as well as internal organs.

questions.question: In a plant, ______ is present in the middle lamella, primary cell and secondary walls and accumulates in the initial stages of development during cell expansion.
questions.explanation: Pectin (polysaccharide) - A soluble ﬁbr e found in fruits. Chitin - A long chain polymer of N -acetylglucosamine, an amide derivative of glucose, forms a long chain polymer. Present in cell walls and septa of all pathogenic fungi and cyst walls of pathogenic amoebae. Gelatin - A food ingredient found in soups, broths, sauces, gummy candies, marshmallows, cosmetics, and medications. Alginate - Naturally occurring anionic polymer typically obtained from brown seaweed.

questions.question: Select the correct statement.

options.a: Mitochondria and nucleus are found in bacteria.
options.b: Ribosomes, mitochondria and lysosomes are found in animal cells.
options.c: Chloroplast, ribosomes and nucleus are present in fungal cells.
options.d: Mitochondria and nucleus are absent in plant cells.

questions.explanation: Bacteria do not have a nucleus or membrane-bound organelles. They have ribosomes. Fungal cells have ribosomes and a nucleus. They also have other organelles like endoplasmic reticulum, mitochondria, ribosomes, Golgi apparatus and vacuoles. Plant cells have ribosomes (Responsible for protein synthesis) mitochondria, nucleus, and chloroplasts (responsible for photosynthesis).

questions.question: Which form of leucoplast specialises in oil synthesis and storage and is mainly found in the layer of cells in pollen grains that develop pollen grains?
questions.explanation: Elaioplasts - These are plastids that are specialized in oil synthesis and found primarily in the layer of cells. Gerontoplasts - Type of plastid formed during leaf senescence (deterioration with age), Derived from - Chloroplasts. Proteinoplasts arespecialized organelles found in plant cells. Chloroplasts are organelle that contains the photosynthetic pigment chlorophyll that captures sunlight and converts it into useful energy, Found in green plants and algae.

questions.question: Which cells, also called neurilemma cells, are the main glial cells in the PNS and play an essential role in the survival and functions of neurons?
questions.explanation: Schwann cells. Peripheral Nervous System - Part of your nervous system that lies outside the brain and spinal cord. Central nervous system - Includes two organs, the brain and spinal cord. Bipolar cells - One of the main retinal interneurons that provide the main pathways from photoreceptors to ganglion cells.

questions.question: The cells having well-organized nuclei with a nuclear membrane are designated as__________ .
questions.explanation: Eukaryotic cells - Larger and more complex than prokaryotic cells. These possess a well-de ﬁ ned nucleus, enclosed within a nuclear membrane, and contain various membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, and others.

questions.question: Which component of the cell contains the hereditary material of the cell, the DNA?
questions.explanation: Nucleus (Discovered by Robert Brown) -It is a membrane - bound organelle found in eukaryotic cells. It contains the cell's genetic material, including DNA, which carries the instructions for cell function and inheritance. Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) - Discovered by James Watson and Francis Crick.

questions.question: Cells were ﬁrst observed in cork by __________ in 1665.
questions.explanation: Robert Hooke. Edward Jenner - Discovered the smallpox vaccine in 1796. Theophrastus - The father of botany. Anton van Leeuwenhoek (Father of Microbiology) - He discovered protists and bacteria.

questions.question: What is the jelly-like substance between the nucleus and the cell membrane called?
questions.explanation: Cytoplasm. It is the main area for all the activities taking place inside a cell. It is made of water, salts and proteins. Plasma is the ﬂuid that makes up the blood and other bodily ﬂuids.

questions.question: Which component of the cell organelles principally performs the function of packaging materials, to be delivered either to the intra-cellular targets or secreted outside the cell?
questions.explanation: Golgi Apparatus (Golgi complex or Golgi body).

questions.question: What is the major function of a cell wall?

options.a: It works as a storage for material
options.b: It provides shape and rigidity to the cell
options.c: It is responsible for cell division
options.d: It helps in synthesis of carbohydrate

questions.explanation: The cell wall in plants is composed mainly of cellulose and contains three layers in many plants. The three layers are the middle lamella, primary cell wall, and secondary cell wall. It is only found in Plant Cell.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a plant cell?
questions.explanation: Cell wall is present. Plant cells have a rigid cell wall that surrounds the cell membrane. This cell wall provides structural support and protection for the cell. Animal cells do not have a cell wall. Animal cells have lysosomes which are organelles that contain enzymes that break down cellular waste while Plant cells do nothave lysosomes.

questions.question: Plant cell have a big central ___ unlike a number of small ___ in animal cells.
questions.explanation: Vacuole, vacuoles. Plant cells - Eukaryotic cells that vary in several fundamental factors from other eukaryotic organisms. It is rectangular and comparatively larger than the animal cell. Tissue - A group of cells with similar structure and function. It forms a cellular organizational level, intermediate between the cells and organ system.

questions.question: Which of the following is a complex permanent plant tissue?
questions.explanation: Xylem - It is a complex permanent tissue found in vascular plants. It is responsible for conducting water, minerals, and nutrients from the roots to the other parts of the plant. Xylem and Phloem are the Complex Permanent tissues.

questions.question: At high doses, ________ kills cancer cells or slows their growth by damaging their DNA. Cancer cells whose DNA is damaged beyond repair, stop dividing or die. When the damaged cells die, they are broken down and removed by the body.
questions.explanation: Radiation therapy. The X-ray generating methodology is applied to cancer therapy. X-rays discovered in 1895 by W. C. Roentgen. Types of radiation therapy: 1. External beam radiation therapy comes from a machine to deliver radiation. 2. Internal radiation therapy uses implants or drugs to deliver radiation inside the body.

questions.question: ________ is the chemical process in which different types of chemical reactions are involved in controlling the living state of the cells in an organism.
questions.explanation: Metabolism. The circulatory system is the “transportation system” for the body, and blood serves as thetransport vehicle. Respiration - Process in which organisms exchange gases between their body cells and the environment. Excretion - Process by which animals rid themselves of waste products and of the nitrogenous by-products of metabolism.

questions.question: In Golgi apparatus, the maturing face is:
questions.explanation: Concave. The Golgi cisternae are concentrically arranged near the nucleus with distinct convex cis or the forming face and concave, trans or the maturing face. The Golgi apparatus (discovered by Camillo Golgi in 1898) is located close to the nucleus and can be very large in secretory cells, where it ﬁlls almost the complete cytoplasm.

questions.question: What is the outermost layer found in the cell envelope of the bacterial cell called?
questions.explanation: Glycocalyx. It is a network of polysaccharides attached to the cell wall.

questions.question: There are ____ main types of cell division.
questions.explanation: 2. Types -Mitosis : The process in which cells use to make exact replicas of themselves. Mitosis is observed in almost all the body’s cells, including eyes, skin, hair, and muscle cells. Meiosis : In this type of cell division, sperm or egg cells are produced instead of identical daughter cells as in mitosis.

questions.question: Identify an option that does NOT represent prokaryotic cells.
questions.explanation: Sperm. Prokaryotic cells - Do not have a true nucleus and membrane-bound organelles - single - celled microorganisms. Examples - Bacteria and Archaea, Mycoplasma (Pleuropneumonia-like organism, a genus of bacteria), Blue-green algae (cyanobacteria).

questions.question: A group of ribosomes attached to mRNA is known as __________.
questions.explanation: Polysomes. They include a piece of the genetic code that is translated by each ribosome and are employed in the synthesis of numerous copies of the same polypeptide. Polypeptide - short chains of amino acids linked by peptide bonds. Long chains of amino acids are called proteins. Polymer - materials made of long, repeating chains of molecules. Monomer - A molecule that forms the basic unit for polymers. Example - Sugar is a monomer of polymers like glycogen, starch, and cellulose.

questions.question: An undifferentiated layer, _________is present in between the ectoderm and the endoderm.
questions.explanation: Mesoglea. Coelenterata and Ctenophora show the scattered pouches in between ectoderm and endoderm. Animals in which the body cavity is absent are called acoelomates, such as Platyhelminthes.

questions.question: What happens to the decomposition rate when detritus is rich in lignin and chitin ?
questions.explanation: It is slower. Decomposition is faster if nitrogen and water soluble substances are present.

questions.question: Identify the function of plasmid DNA.

options.a: None of the given options are correct
options.c: To confer certain unique phenotypic characters to bacteria
options.d: To help in the formation of rRNA

questions.explanation: A plasmid is a small, circular, double-stranded DNA molecule that is distinct from a cell's chromosomal DNA. Plasmids naturally exist in bacterial cells, and they also occur in some eukaryotes. Often, the genes carried in plasmids provide bacteria with genetic advantages, such as antibiotic resistance.

questions.question: Match Column-A with Column-BColumn-A Column-Bi. Gl a. Cell synthesises a complete copy of the DNA ii. S b. First gap phase, the cell grows physically larger iii. G2 c. Cell begins to reorganise its contents in preparation for mitosis iv. M d. Cell divides its copied DNA and cytoplasm to make two new cells
questions.explanation: i-b, ii-a, iii-c, iv-d.

questions.question: What is the role of ribosomes of a polysome?

options.b: The ribosomes of a polysome translate the mRNA into proteins.
options.c: The ribosomes of a polysome translate the rRNA into proteins.
options.d: The ribosomes of a monosome translate the rRNA into proteins.

questions.explanation: The ribosomes of a polysome translate the mRNA into proteins. A ribosome is an intracellular structure made of both RNA and protein, and it is the site of protein synthesis in the cell.

questions.question: Which of the following is a plant tissue? I. Meristematic tissue II. Permanent tissue
questions.explanation: Meristematic tissues are cells or groups of cells that have the ability to divide. The tissues that are completely grown and have lost the ability to divide are known as Permanent tissues. Types of Plant Tissue - Meristematic Tissue ( Apical, Intercalary, Lateral) and Permanent Tissue {Simple (Parenchyma, Collenchyma, Sclerenchyma), Complex (Xylem and Phloem)}.

questions.question: Cells of meristematic tissue lack ________.
questions.explanation: Vacuoles. They are dividing rigorously so they need not store food or waste products.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT atype of chromosome, on the basis of the location of the centromere?
questions.explanation: Lophocentric. Chromosomes are bundles of tightly coiled DNA located within the nucleus of almost every cell in our body. Depending on the position of the centromere, chromosomes are categorized into the following types: Metacentric, Telocentric, Acrocentric, Submetacentric.

questions.question: Which thin ﬂexible barrier separates the internal environment of the cell from the extracellular ﬂuid?
questions.explanation: Plasma Membrane consists of both lipids and proteins and provides protection for a cell. Lipids are fatty, wax-like molecules found in the human body and other organisms.

questions.question: Which of the following cell organelles functions both as a passageway for intracellular transport and as a manufacturing surface?
questions.explanation: Endoplasmic Reticulum is a major site of protein synthesis and transport, protein folding, lipid and steroid synthesis, carbohydrate metabolism and calcium storage. Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) are of two types : Smooth ER and Rough ER. Function of lysosomes (digestion and removal of waste).

questions.question: In plant cell, ______ are primarily organelles in which materials such as starch, oils and protein granules are stored.
questions.explanation: Leucoplasts. The basic function of it is the storage of essential compounds such as starch, lipids, and proteins.

questions.question: Amoeba acquires its food through the process of ______.
questions.explanation: Endocytosis is a general term describing a process by which cells absorb external material by engul ﬁ ng it with the cell membrane. Exocytosis is the process by which cells move materials from within the cell into the extracellular ﬂuid. Diffusion is the movement of molecules from an area of high concentration of the molecules to an area with a lower concentration.

questions.question: What are the projections of varying lengths protruding out of an amoeba’s body, which can appear and disappear, known as?
questions.explanation: Pseudopodia are called the false feet as they are actually extensions of the cytoplasm or the thick liquid that is inside organisms like an Amoeba. The function of the contractile vacuole is to pump water out of the cell through a process called osmoregulation, the regulation of osmotic pressure. Paramecium is a genus of unicellular ciliated protozoa, commonly studied as a representative of the ciliate group.

questions.question: ______ is known as the energy currency of the cell.
questions.explanation: ATP (Adenosine triphosphate) is the source of energy for use and storage at the cellular level and has three phosphates. ADP is adenosine diphosphate and contains only two phosphate groups. DNA, or deoxyribonucleic acid, is the hereditary material in humans and almost all other organisms. Ribonucleic acid (RNA) is a nucleic acid present in all living cells.

questions.question: Which of the following are situated in the nucleus of a cell?
questions.explanation: Chromosomes and genes. Each cell in the human body has 23 pairs of chromosomes (46 total chromosomes) .Two of them are the X and the Y chromosome, determine sex as male or female when you are born.Q.241. Which cell theory proved that the quasi- ﬂ uid nature of lipids enables lateral movement of proteins within the overall bilayer? SSC CHSL 24/05/2022 (Afternoon) (a) Cell theory (b) Fluid mosaic model (c) Model of Golgi bodies (d) Vacuole theory Sol.241.(b) Fluid mosaic model describes the cell membrane as a tapestry of several types of molecules (phospholipids, cholesterols, and proteins) that are constantly moving. Cell theory states that the cell is the basic functional and structural unit of all living organisms.

questions.question: Under the electron microscope, which cell organelle is visible as either clusters or single, small dots that ﬂoat fr eely in the cytoplasm?
questions.explanation: Ribosome. It is an intracellular structure made of both RNA and protein, and it is the site of protein synthesis in the cell. Vesicles can be used to move molecules, secrete substances, digest materials, or regulate the pressure in the cell.

questions.question: Identify the cell that is amoeboid in shape.
questions.explanation: White Blood Cell. It is also known as leukocytes, are responsible for protecting your body from infection. The basic unit of communication in the nervous system is the nerve cell (neuron). Columnar epithelial cells are elongated and column-shaped and have a height of at least four times their width.

questions.question: In cell biology, what is a large double-membraned organelle that is sometimes referred to as the ‘central unit’ of the cell because it contains the chromosomes that bear genetic material?
questions.explanation: Nucleus. Peroxisomes are organelles that sequester diverse oxidative reactions and play important roles in metabolism, reactive oxygenspecies detoxi ﬁ cation, and signaling.

questions.question: In animal cells, which membrane -bound cell organelles are generally smaller and help to separate waste products?
questions.explanation: Vacuole. Cytosol is known as the matrix of the cytoplasm.

questions.question: Identify the component found only in a eukaryotic cell.
questions.explanation: Nuclear membrane. Ribosomes can be found in both prokaryote (bacteria) and eukaryote (animals and plants) cells.

questions.question: Which is the major microtubule - organising centre (MTOC) in eukaryotic cells involved in various cellular processes, including sensory reception, locomotion, and embryogenesis?
questions.explanation: Centrosome is a cellular structure involved in the process of cell division.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of active transport?
questions.explanation: Sodium-potassium pump present on the cell membrane, which transports 3 sodium ions outside and 2 potassium ions inside of the cell per ATP . Active transport (uphill transport) transports substances against the concentration gradient from lower to higher concentration. Passive transport (Glucose transporters) are a wide group of membrane proteins that facilitate the transport of glucose across the plasma membrane.

questions.question: Choose the correct sequence for central dogma.

options.a: Protein translation, DNA Replication, m-RNA transcription
options.b: DNA Replication, m-RNA transcription, Protein translation
options.c: m-RNA transcription, Protein translation, DNA Replication
options.d: m-RNA transcription, DNA Replication, Protein translation

questions.explanation: The 'Central Dogma' is the process by which the instructions in DNA are converted into a functional product. It was ﬁrst proposed in 1958 by Francis Crick, discoverer of the structure of DNA. The central dogma of molecular biology: DNA→RNA→protein.

questions.question: Which biological stain is used in histology and cytology to colour all cell nuclei red?
questions.explanation: Safranin. It is mostly utilized for the identi ﬁ cation of cartilage, mucin, and mast cell granules. Cresol red is a triarylmethane dye, used as an acid-base indicator, or pH indicator.

questions.question: Match column A with column B. Column - A Column - B i. Peptidoglycan a. Cell wall of plants ii. Pectin b. Bacterial cell wall iii. Chitin c. Cell wall of fruits iv. Cellulose d. Insect cell wall
questions.explanation: i-b, ii-c, iii-d, iv-a.

questions.question: What is the main sense organ that virtual reality displays are aiming for
questions.explanation: Vision. Virtual reality (VR) aiming to create an immersive visual experience that simulates a virtual environment. While some VR systems may also incorporate audio and haptic feedback to engage the senses of hearing and touch, the main focus is on visual stimulation.

questions.question: What is the shape of the eyeball ?
questions.explanation: Spherical. Parts of the human eye: Vitreous humour - This is a gel-like substance which maintains the shape of the eyeball. It is also a refractive media. Anterior chamber - It contains the iris and a ﬂuid called the aqueoushumour. Pupil - It is an aperture of variable size in the centre of the iris, which regulates the amount of light entering the eyeball. Retina - It is a transparent layer forming the inner coat of the eye, it supports the choroid layer.

questions.question: Identify the structure that controls the size of the pupil.
questions.explanation: Iris. Parts of the human eye: Iris is the coloured membrane behind the cornea and in the point of the lens with an aperture of variable size called pupil. Cornea - The rays of light enter this layer. Cornea accounts for two-thirds of the total optical power of the eye. Vitreous humour - This is a gel-like substance which maintains the shape of the eyeball. It is also a refractive media.

questions.question: Which type of muscles do the uterus, iris of the eye, and bronchi contain?
questions.explanation: Smooth muscles (involuntary muscles) are found in various organs and tissues that require automatic contraction and relaxation. The uterus, iris of the eye, and bronchi all contain smooth muscles. Characteristics of smooth muscles : Involuntary (not under conscious control), Non-striated (no visible striations), Found in internal organs (hollow organs). Cardiac muscles: Found exclusively in the heart, these muscles pump blood.

questions.question: Clove is an__________ indicator.
questions.explanation: Olfactory. Vanilla, clove and onion are examples of olfactory indicators. Clove - Scienti ﬁ c name - Syzygium aromaticum. Medicinal Properties - Antioxidant, Antimicrobial, Antinociceptive, Antiviral, etc.

questions.question: What do you call the transparent front part of the eye?
questions.explanation: Cornea. It covers the pupil (the opening at the centre of the eye), iris (the coloured part of the eye), and the anterior chamber of the eye (the ﬂuid- ﬁlled inside of the eye).Q.258. Which of the following body parts behaves like a stretched rubber sheet? SSC CGL 23/08/2021 (Evening) (a) Tongue (b) Eye lens (c) Nostril (d) Eardrum Sol.258.(d) Eardrum. The tympanic membrane (eardrum) which is a thin layer of tissue in the human ear that receives sound vibrations from the outer air and transmits them to the auditory ossicles, which are tiny bones in the tympanic (middle-ear) cavity.

questions.question: How many chambers are there in the heart of ﬁshes ?
questions.explanation: 2. Fish have a single circuit for blood ﬂow and a two-chambered heart that has only a single atrium and a single ventricle. The atrium collects blood that has returned from the body, while the ventricle pumps the blood to the gills where gas exchange occurs and the blood is re-oxygenated; this is called gill circulation. Amphibians and most reptiles have three-chambered hearts, with the exception of crocodiles, which have four-chambered hearts.

questions.question: ______ are the vessels which carry blood away from the heart to various organs of the body.
questions.explanation: Arteries - They carry oxygenated blood, which is rich in nutrients and oxygen. The tracheas are the tubes that carry air from the throat to the lungs. They are made of cartilage and have smooth muscles in their walls.

questions.question: _____ are the vessels which carry carbon dioxide - rich blood back to the heart.
questions.explanation: Veins - They carry deoxygenated blood (except pulmonary veins). Biggest vein - Vena Cava. Neurons : Fundamental unit of the nervous system specialized to transmit information to different parts of the body. Capillaries : They take waste products away from tissues.

questions.question: The blood platelets are also known as .
questions.explanation: Thrombocytes . They are cell fragments found in blood and spleen produced from megakaryocytes (special cells in the bone marrow). It helps to form blood clots, prevent bleeding and wounds healing. Blood normally contains 150,000 to 450,000 platelets per microliter of blood. Thrombin - An enzyme that helps in regulating hemostasis and maintaining blood coagulation.

questions.question: Muscles are of three types. Which of the following is NOT one of them ?
questions.explanation: Sesamoids. Muscles are tissues that can contract, and therefore they help in the movement of the other body parts. There are about 600 muscles in the human body. The three main types of muscle include skeletal (bones), smooth (organs) and cardiac (heart).

questions.question: What is the pH of human blood ?
questions.explanation: 7.4. pH (Potential of Hydrogen) is really a measure of the relative amount of free hydrogen and hydroxyl ions in the water.

questions.question: Which of the following is essential to form haemoglobin in blood?
questions.explanation: Iron. Haemoglobin (Hb) : It is a protein in red blood cells that binds to oxygen, enabling its transport throughout the body, crucial for oxygen delivery to tissues and organs. In its iron-bound state, haemoglobin gives blood its red colour.

questions.question: Lymph is a light clear ﬂuid made up of white blood cells that attack harmful ______ in the blood.
questions.explanation: Bacteria. The corpuscles found in the lymph are called lymphocytes. Diseases caused by Bacteria : Diphtheria, pneumonia, cholera, tetanus, tuberculosis, plague, and gonorrhea. Fungi : Ringworm and athlete's foot.Q.267. Which of the following is a large bean - shaped lymphoid organ in the human body ? SSC CHSL 16/04/2021 (Evening) (a) Thymus (b) Spleen (c) Lymph node (d) Tonsil Sol.267.(b) Spleen stores erythrocytes, lymphocytes, and phagocytes. It ﬁlters the bloodstream by trapping blood-borne pathogens in its cells.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about blood pressure is correct?

options.a: The normal systolic pressure is about 80 mm of Hg and diastolic pressure is 120 mm of Hg.
options.b: The normal systolic pressure is about 72 mm of Hg and diastolic pressure is 35 mm of Hg.
options.c: The normal systolic pressure is about 160 mm of Hg and diastolic pressure is 80 mm of Hg.
options.d: The normal systolic pressure is about 120 mm of Hg and diastolic pressure is 80 mm of Hg.

questions.explanation: The maximum pressure at which the blood leaves the heart through the main artery (Aorta) during ventricular contraction is called systolic pressure. The minimum pressure in the arteries during ventricular relaxation of the heart is called the diastolic pressure.

questions.question: Swollen bluish veins resulting from the valves that do not close properly are called ______.
questions.explanation: Varicose veins. These are abnormally dilated, tortuous super ﬁ cial veins caused by incompetent venous valves. They almost always affect the legs and feet.

questions.question: Filtration of waste products in humans happens in the kidneys. There is a large number of ﬁltr ation units present inside the kidneys to help them in doing this job. These ﬁltr ation units are called:
questions.explanation: nephrons. Each kidney has nearly one million complex tubular structures called nephrons, which are the functional units. Each nephron has twoparts – the glomerulus and the renal tubule. Glomerulus is a tuft of capillaries formed by the afferent arteriole – a ﬁne br anch of renal artery. Blood from the glomerulus is carried away by an efferent arteriole. The renal tubule begins with a double walled cup-like structure called Bowman’s capsule, which encloses the glomerulus.

questions.question: Identify a muscle responsible for the exit of waste material from the body.
questions.explanation: Sphincter. A muscular sphincter (gastro-oesophageal) regulates the opening of oesophagus into the stomach. The small intestine is distinguishable into three regions, a ‘C’ shaped duodenum, a long coiled middle portion jejunum and a highly coiled ileum. The opening of the stomach into the duodenum is guarded by the pyloric sphincter.

questions.question: Which is a specialised excretory cell found in Platyhelminthes that acts like a kidney, removing waste material through ﬁltr ation?
questions.explanation: Flame cell. Phylum Platyhelminthes - It belongs to the kingdom Animalia. The organisms are also known as ﬂatworms. They are triploblastic, bilaterally symmetrical, dorsoventra, acoelomate ﬂatworms with organ grade of construction without a deﬁ nite anus, circulatory, skeletal or respiratory system but with Protonephridial excretory system and mesenchyme ﬁlling the space between the various organs of the body.

questions.question: Which of the following chemicals is responsible for the yellow colour in urine?
questions.explanation: Urobilin or urochrome. It is generated from the degradation of heme. Heme is a precursor of hemoglobin. Albumin is a protein made by the liver. Bilirubin is a yellow pigment that is made during the normal breakdown of red blood cells. Creatinine is a waste product that comes from the normal wear and tears on the muscles of the body.

questions.question: Which gland gets enlarged in the goitre due to which there is a swelling in the front part of the throat?
questions.explanation: Thyroid Gland. It is located on either side of the trachea, inferior to the larynx. Hormone released - Thyroxine. Other Gland in body : Pineal Gland - Located on the dorsal side of the forebrain and it releases melatonin hormone. Adrenal gland - Located at the anterior of each kidney. Hormone released - Adrenaline and Norepinephrine.

questions.question: Which of the following is the largest gland in the human body?
questions.explanation: Liver . It is located in the upper right portion of the abdomen and is the only organ that has the ability to regenerate e ﬃ ciently. Pancreas is a composite gland which acts as both exocrine and endocrine gland.

questions.question: Proboscis gland for excretion is present in the phylum:
questions.explanation: Hemichordata . Examples - Balanoglossus, Saccoglossus, Protoglossus, Ptychodera.

questions.question: Which gland produces Cortisol often known as a 'stress hormone' in humans ?
questions.explanation: Adrenal gland . The thyroid gland uses iodine from food to make two thyroid hormones: triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4).

questions.question: Which of the following parts of the body/glands maintains the body temperature?
questions.explanation: Hypothalamus. It is located in the ventral brain above the pituitary gland and below the third ventricle. control of the pituitary gland, regulationof body temperature, food intake, ﬂuid intak e, control of the autonomic nervous system, control of stress, emotional expression and aggression, sleep and waking, sexual arousal and memory.

questions.question: ______ glands release tears from our eyes.
questions.explanation: The lacrimal gland produces tears which are secreted by the lacrimal ducts, and ﬂow over the ocular surface, and then into canals that connect to the lacrimal sac. From that sac, the tears drain through the lacrimal duct into the nose.

questions.question: What is a leaf-shaped ﬂap of cartilage located behind the tongue, at the top of the larynx or voice box called?
questions.explanation: Epiglottis. Its main function is to seal off the windpipe during eating, so that food is not accidentally inhaled. The larynx is a cartilaginous skeleton, some ligaments, and muscles that move and stabilize it .

questions.question: In boys, the growing 'larynx' is visible as a distinct bulge at the front of the throat called _______.
questions.explanation: Kanthamani (Adam's apple). Gullet (esophagus) - it is part of the digestive system, which is sometimes called the gastro-intestinal tract (GI tract). The esophagus is a muscular tube. It connects the mouth to the stomach.

questions.question: Breakdown of pyruvate into lactic acid and energy in lack of Oxygen takes place in Which of the following ?
questions.explanation: Human muscle cells. Anaerobic respiration - It is the partial breakdown of glucose into acid or alcohol along with carbon dioxide in the absence of oxygen. Anaerobic respiration in muscles - In this anaerobic process,glucose is partially oxidized to pyruvate, which further converts into lactic acids in muscles.

questions.question: Which of the following is correct regarding the respiration? I. Regular traditional breathing exercise (pranayama) can increase the capacity of lungs to take in more air. II. During inhalation, ribs move up and outwards and diaphragm moves down.
questions.explanation: Both I and II. The lungs and respiratory system allows us to breathe.They bring oxygen into our bodies (called inspiration, or inhalation) and send carbon dioxide out (called expiration, or exhalation). This exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide is called respiration.

questions.question: What is the percentage of carbon dioxide in the air exhaled by human lungs ?
questions.explanation: 4.4%. Composition of exhaled air : nitrogen (78%) oxygen (17%) carbon dioxide (4%) other gases (1%). Inhaled air is by volume: 78% nitrogen, 20.95% oxygen and small amounts of other gases including argon, carbon dioxide, neon, helium, and hydrogen.

questions.question: What is the network of air tubes for gas exchange in insects ?
questions.explanation: Tracheae . Gills are evaginated respiratory surfaces used for breathing in water. The diaphragm, located below the lungs, is the major muscle of respiration. Spiracles are the small opening on the lateral side of the body through which air enters the tracheal system.

questions.question: To get relief from constipation, which of the following is prescribed to be eaten in large amounts?
questions.explanation: Fibre is essential for maintaining healthy digestion. It adds bulk to the stool and helps it pass more easily through the intestines, thus providing relief from constipation. Foods high in ﬁbr e include fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and legumes.

questions.question: Digestion of food is an important function of the animal body. In animals like lions, cows, humans, etc., the process involves use of various organs starting from the mouth and ending with the anus. The longest part of this canal is known as the ________.
questions.explanation: Small intestine. It is a 20-foot tube in the digestive system, breaks down food and absorbs nutrients. It has three parts: the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum, and helps digest food from the stomach while absorbing vitamins, minerals, carbs, fats, proteins, and water. The large intestine, about 5 feet long, is wider but shorter than the small intestine. The oesophagus in adults is typically 10 - 13 inches long and about ¾ inch in diameter at its narrowest point.

questions.question: Which of the following is a medium-sized globular protein that acts as a pancreatic serine protease found in the digestive system of many vertebrates
questions.explanation: Trypsin. Globular proteins are a common type of protein that are spherical or globe-shaped and are somewhat soluble in water. They are also known as spheroproteins. Amylase: An enzyme found in saliva that breaks down starches into maltose. Lipase: An enzyme that breaks down fats, secreted by the pancreas and, in smaller amounts, by gastric glands. Pepsin: An enzyme in the stomach that converts proteins into proteoses and peptones.

questions.question: Which glands help in digestion in the stomach ?
questions.explanation: Gastric glands in the stomach lining secrete digestive juices, including hydrochloric acid (HCl) and pepsinogen, which help break down proteins and activate digestive enzymes. Pituitary gland : Regulates hormone secretion, growth, and development. Thyroid gland : Regulates metabolism, growth, and development. Pineal gland : Regulates sleep-wake cycles and melatonin production.Q.290. Identify the function of lipase in the process of digestion. SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (1st shift) (a) Breaking down roughage (b) Breaking down emulsi ﬁ ed fats (c) Secreting intestinal ﬂuids (d) Digesting proteins Sol.290.(b) Lipase is the enzyme that breaks down the lipids present in the form of emulsi ﬁ ed fat and converts them into fatty acids and glycerol. Digestion of protein is done by several enzymes such as Pepsin, Trypsin, Chymotrypsin.

questions.question: Liver gland secretes that are stored in a sac called the gallbladder.
questions.explanation: Bile juice - It is important for the total digestion of different types of fats (fats in food to fatty acids). It also helps in digesting carbohydrates and proteins to some extent. Estrogen - The female reproductive hormone secreted by the membranous granulosa of the Graa ﬁ an follicle. Mucus - A protective substance that is secreted from multiple areas in the body such as the mouth, sinuses, throat, lungs, and stomach. Produced by the goblet cell of the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.question: In humans, the digestion of carbohydrates like starch, begins in which of the following parts?
questions.explanation: Buccal cavity. Organs in the digestive system - mouth, pharynx (throat), oesophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine, rectum, and anus. Rectum is the terminal part of the intestine from the sigmoid colon to the anus. Small intestine is the longest part of the digestive system. Oesophagus is a muscular tube, which connects the mouth to the stomach.

questions.question: In ruminants like cattle, bacteria present in ______helps in digestion of cellulose.
questions.explanation: Rumen is the ﬁrst chamber of the stomach of ruminants like cattle. It is a large, muscular sac that is ﬁlled with bacteria, protozoa, and other microorganisms. These microorganisms help to digest the cellulose in the foodthat the ruminant eats.

questions.question: Which of the following animals have a single opening in their digestive system that serves both as a mouth and an anus?
questions.explanation: Platyhelminthes. These are also known as ﬂatworms belonging to Animalia Kingdom and they include many free-living and parasitic life forms. The term arachnid refers to a class of animals that includes spiders, scorpions, mites, and ticks.

questions.question: Which food requires a longer small intestine to digest food?
questions.explanation: Grass has cellulose (takes a long time to digest) so it requires longer intestines in organisms to digest. Meat (lamb, chicken, etc) is easy to digest so it requires a short intestine (in organisms) to digest. The function of the long intestine: absorbing water and electrolytes, producing and absorbing vitamins, and forming and propelling feces toward the rectum for elimination.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of calcium in our body?

options.a: It plays an important role in blood clotting.
options.c: It is associated with healthy bones and teeth

questions.explanation: Examples of digestive enzymes include amylase, gelatinase, lactase, lipase, maltase, peptidase, and protease.

questions.question: Which of the following is able to regenerate our digestive system with good microbes that will neutralize the harmful ones?
questions.explanation: Probiotics. Yogurt is one of the best sources of probiotics. Antibiotics are medicines that ﬁght bacterial infections in people and animals. Prosthesis or a prosthetic implant, is an arti ﬁ cial device that replaces a missing body part, which may be lost through trauma, disease, or a condition present at birth.

questions.question: Where are villi present in the human alimentary canal?
questions.explanation: Small intestine - It receives secretions from the liver and the pancreas. Villi are small ﬁnger-lik e projections found inside the inner walls of the small intestine. They increase the surface area for absorption of nutrients from the food.

questions.question: In human beings, the small intestine is coiled and is about ______ metres long.
questions.explanation: 7 to 7.5 (about 22 feet). The small intestine has three parts. The ﬁrst par t is called the duodenum. The jejunum is in the middle and the ileum is at the end. The large intestine includes the appendix, cecum, colon, and rectum. The large intestine is about ﬁv e feet (or 1.5 metres) long.

questions.question: Which type of carbohydrate CANNOT be broken down by the GI tract, does not provide energy, but helps the body get rid of wastes and keeps the intestinal tract healthy?
questions.explanation: Fibre. It is a type of carbohydrate that the body can't digest. Glycogen is the storage form of carbohydrates in mammals. Simple Sugars, also called monosaccharides, include glucose, fructose, and galactose.

questions.question: ______, a ﬂuid secreted by new mothers during the initial days of lactation, contains nutrients that boost a baby's immune system and helps ﬁght inf ection.
questions.explanation: Colostrum is the ﬁrst form of breastmilk that is released by the mammary glands after giving birth. Sebum is an oily, waxy substance produced by your body's sebaceous glands. Synovia is a lubricating ﬂuid r esembling the white of an egg, secreted by certain membranes, as those of the joints. Cerumen (Earwax), is a brown, orange, red, yellowish or grey waxy substance secreted in the ear canal of humans and other mammals.Q.302. Which of the following is the indigestible portion of our diet essential to the health of the digestive system? SSC MTS 08/10/2021 (Morning) (a) Fats (b) Roughage (c) Carbohydrates (d) Proteins Sol.302.(b) Roughage. It includes all plant products like grains, nuts, legumes, fruits, etc. They are indigestible but act as a source of food for the bene ﬁ cial bacteria present in our gut. Consumption of roughage maintains body weight and also reduces risk factors of heart disease.

questions.question: How do the muscle cells help in movement ?

options.a: The thickness of the cell layer helps in movement.
options.b: The lining of the vessels inside help in movement.
options.c: The blood ﬂow of the cells helps in movement.
options.d: The contraction and relaxation of these cells result in movement.

questions.explanation: Muscle cells are specialized cells that can contract and relax. This ability is crucial for movement in the body. When muscle cells contract, they shorten, which pulls on the bones or other structures they are attached to, causing movement. When they relax, they lengthen and return to their original state. This cycle of contraction and relaxation is what allows for various movements, such as walking, lifting objects, or even the beating of the heart.

questions.question: Identify the type of cell that is long and branched.
questions.explanation: Nerve cell. The neural system of all animals is composed of highly specialized cells called - neurons which can detect, receive and transmit different kinds of stimuli. This system is divided into two parts - the Central Nervous System (CNS) and the Peripheral Nervous System (PNS). The CNS consists of the brain and spinal cord. The PNS consists mainly of nerves.

questions.question: Which part of the human brain is responsible for walking in a straight line?
questions.explanation: Cerebellum (also called the little brain). It controls balance for walking and standing, and other complex motor functions. Cerebrum (largest part of the brain, initiates and coordinates movement and regulates temperature). Medulla (lowest part of the brain, It deals with the autonomic functions of breathing, heart rate, blood pressure, and sleep - wake cycle).

questions.question: The sensation of feeling full is because of a centre associated with hunger, which is in a separate part of the ______ .
questions.explanation: Forebrain. The brain is the central information processing organ of our body. The brain can be divided into three major parts : Forebrain consists of Hypothalamus (regulation of sexual behaviour, expression of emotional reactions), Cerebrum (controls memory, will power, knowledge etc), Thalamus (controls pain, cold and Heat). Midbrain consists of Tectum (vision and auditory reﬂ exes) and Hindbrain consists of Medulla oblongata (respiration, cardiovascular re ﬂ exes and gastric secretions), Pons (tract between brain and spinal cord) and Cerebellum (coordination of Movement, Posture etc).

questions.question: Our brain mainly depends on which of the following foods?
questions.explanation: Only glucose. Glucose is a type of sugar which comes predominantly from starchy foods (bread, rice, pasta and potatoes) as well as fruits, juices, honey, jams and table sugar. The body tightly regulates blood glucose levels; this is known as glucose homeostasis.

questions.question: In which part of the human body will you ﬁnd the 'superior rectus' ?
questions.explanation: Eye. The superior rectus is a muscle in the eye that helps to elevate the eye. This muscle is among four muscles - including the medial rectus, lateral rectus, and inferior rectus, which control the eye’s movement.

questions.question: Which one of the following is a degenerative disorder of the brain and one of several conditions that cause dementia, a progressive decline of mental functions resulting in memory loss and confusion ?
questions.explanation: Alzheimer's Disease. Schizophrenia is a mental disorder that affects a person's thoughts, emotions, and behavior. Amnesia can be caused by brain injury, stroke, and Alzheimer's Disease. Concussion is a mild traumatic brain injury that can cause temporary symptoms such as headache, dizziness, and memory loss.

questions.question: In humans the neck is joined by the head by which of the following joints?
questions.explanation: Pivotal joint. Hinge joints - Allow movement along one plane, Examples: Ankle, elbows, and knee joints. Fixed joints - Immovable joints, where bones are not ﬂexible, Examples: Upper jaw, rib cage.

questions.question: Which among the following is a ﬂat bone?
questions.explanation: Ribs are a set of twelve paired bones which form the protective 'cage' of the thorax. The ankle joint, also known as the talocrural joint, is a synovial joint that connects the bones of the leg, the ﬁbula and tibia, with the talus of the foot. Pelvic Bone is a basin shaped complex bone which connects the trunk and legs and supports the urinary bladder. The wrist is formed where the two bones of the forearm, the radius and the ulna meet the carpus. Other bones of the hand - metacarpals and phalanges.

questions.question: ‘The ﬂuid present between joints, that makes the movement of joints easy, is called:
questions.explanation: Synovial .It provides lubrication, reduces friction between bones and makes the joint movements smooth. Examples of such joints are ball and socket joint, pivot joint, gliding joint, hinge joint, and saddle joint.

questions.question: In which of the following parts of the human body is the masseter muscle located ?
questions.explanation: Jaw. The muscle masseter is a facial muscle that plays a major role in the chewing of solid foods. The three layers of the masseter are the super ﬁ cial layer, the intermediate layer, and the deep layer.

questions.question: The human shoulder joint is an example of a ______ joint.
questions.explanation: Ball and socket joint. It is a synovial joint, which means it allows for smooth movements between bones.

questions.question: The vertebrae are a part of which of the following body systems in humans
questions.explanation: Spinal cord. The spine is composed of 33 vertebrae, divided into ﬁv e sections: the cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine sections and the sacrum and coccyx bones.

questions.question: How many bones are there in the human hand ?
questions.explanation: The human hand has 27 bones : the carpals or wrist contains 8; the metacarpals or palm contains ﬁv e; the remaining fourteen are digital bones; ﬁngers and thumb.

questions.question: Which of the following is the largest dental tissue?
questions.explanation: Dentin. It is a composite substance of organic and inorganic material found in the tooth's interior. Pulp : This soft tissue forms the tooth's inner core, containing the blood vessels and nerves. Enamel : It acts as a protective barrier for the crown of the tooth. It is the hardest substance in the human body.Plant kingdom Q.318 . Match the columns. Column A (Plant Group)Column B (Example) i. Bryophyta a. Rose ii. Pteridophyta b. Pine iii. Gymnosperms c. Mosses iv. Angiosperms d. Selaginella SSC MTS 23/10/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) i-c, ii-a, iii-b, iv-d (b) i-c, ii-d, iii-b, iv-a (c) i-c, ii-d, iii-a, iv-b (d) i-d, ii-c, iii-b, iv-a Sol.318.(b) i-c, ii-d, iii-b, iv-a. Bryophytes - liverworts, hornworts. Pteridophytes - Equisetum, Fern, Salvinia. Gymnosperms - Cycas, Pinus, Ginkgo. Angiosperms - Orchids, Corn, Tomato, and Hibiscus.

questions.question: Which of the following groups of plants are categorised as cryptogams ?
questions.explanation: Bryophytes and Thallophyta. Thallophyta - Plants that do not have well-differentiated body design fall in this group. The plants in this group are commonly called algae. Bryophytes - These are called the amphibians of the plant kingdom. The plant body is commonly differentiated to form stem and leaf-like structures. Gymnosperms and Angiosperms are called ‘phanerogams’.

questions.question: Hubbardia heptaneuron, which has become endangered, is a species of which of the following?
questions.explanation: Grass. Hubbardia heptaneuron is nearing extinction due to its environmental insensitivity. Other endangered plant species include the Gran Canaria Drago Tree, Mandragora, Castela senticosa, Musli, and Assam Catkin. The IUCN's "Red Data Books" offer the most comprehensive global inventory of the conservation status of plant and animal species.

questions.question: Taxus wallichiana Zucc (Himalayan yew) is a medicinal plant found in which of the following states?
questions.explanation: Himachal Pradesh. The Himalayan yew grows in the high-altitude forests of the Western Himalayas, especially in the states of Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, and parts of Jammu & Kashmir.

questions.question: What is the reason for the similar size of the vascular bundle in monocot leaves ?
questions.explanation: Parallel venation. The leaves of monocots are long, elongated, and slender. Parallel venation refers to the arrangement of veins in parallel. They grow perpendicularly from the bottom to the end of the lea ﬂ et. Parallel venation is classi ﬁ ed into two types. They are pinnate parallel venation and palmate parallel venation.

questions.question: The growth form of a plant, comprising its size, shape and orientation is known as :
questions.explanation: habit. The environment is the sum of all living and non-living things, and the forces that affect them, that surround a person, animal, or plant. A habitat is the natural home of an organism, such as a plant or animal. It provides the organism with food, water, shelter, and space to survive. Q.324 . Which marine carotenoid is abundant in brown seaweed, macroalgae and diatoms ? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Fucoxanthin (b) Astaxanthin (c) Neoxanthin (d) β-cryptoxanthin Sol.324.(a) Fucoxanthin. It is an orange-colored pigment, along with chlorophylls a and c and β-carotene, present in Chromophyta, including brown seaweeds (Phaeophyceae) and diatoms (Bacillariophyta). Astaxanthin: It is a reddish pigment that belongs to a group of chemicals called carotenoids. Neoxanthin: It is a carotenoid and xanthophyll pigment found in plants, algae, and microorganisms. β-Cryptoxanthin, a carotenoid found in fruits and vegetables such as tangerines, red peppers, and pumpkin.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT related to reticulate venation ?
questions.explanation: Maize. Reticulate venation : Arrangement of veins in a leaf blade that resembles a net or web, present on both sides of the midrib. Examples of plants with reticulate venation include China rose, Tulsi, and Coriander. Parallel Venation: Arrangement of veins in a leaf blade that run parallel to each other. Plants with parallel venation include Maize, Grass, and Wheat.

questions.question: Which of the following is related to neem ?
questions.explanation: Pinnately. Compound leaves are classi ﬁ ed into two types: pinnately and palmately compound leaves. In pinnately compound leaves, lea ﬂ ets are arranged along a common axis called the rachis, as seen in neem. In palmately compound leaves, lea ﬂ ets attach at a common point at the tip of the petiole, such as in silk cotton.

questions.question: Which of the following is responsible for the red colour of beetroot?
questions.explanation: Betanin. The red color in beetroot is due to betacyanin, a water-soluble pigment located in the cell vacuole, not in chloroplasts. Curcumin : A yellow-orange pigment found in turmeric (Curcuma longa). Beta carotene : A yellow-orange pigment converted to vitamin A in the body, found in carrots and sweet potatoes. Lycopene is the red colored pigment abundantly found in red colored fruits and vegetables such as tomato, papaya, pink grapefruit, pink guava and watermelon.

questions.question: The loss of water in the form of water droplets from leaves of plants is called _____.
questions.explanation: Guttation. Translocation is the movement of materials from leaves to other tissues throughout the plant. Plasmolysis is de ﬁ ned as the process of contraction or shrinkage of the protoplasm of a plant cell and is caused due to the loss of water in the cell. Pressure gradient refers to the differencein air pressure between two points in the atmosphere or on the surface of the earth.

questions.question: In which of the following plants do roots arise from parts of a plant other than the radicle ?
questions.explanation: Monstera. Three types of roots are found in Monstera deliciosa: aerial roots, aerial roots that have entered the soil (aerial-subterranean roots), and lateral roots that form on aerial-subterranean roots (lateral - subterranean roots). The three root types differed in anatomical development and in growth. It is an example of adventitious roots, which grow from parts of the plant other than the radicle. These roots can be aerial or underground and may develop from nodes (money plant, bamboo), stem cuttings (rose), branches (banyan), or the stem base (ﬁ brous roots in monocots).

questions.question: Which of the following organisms can initiate ecological succession even in bare rocks ?
questions.explanation: Lichens. The species that are ﬁrst to invade a bare area are called pioneer species. Lichens are able to secrete acids to dissolve rock, helping in weathering and soil formation. These later pave the way to some very small plants like bryophytes.

questions.question: What is the root-like structure at the base of an algae (seaweed) that binds the algae to a hard substrate like a stone?
questions.explanation: Holdfast. Algae are a diverse group of photosynthetic, eukaryotic organisms, representing a polyphyletic grouping that includes species from various clades. The midrib, or midvein, is the central, thick vein running from the base to the tip of a leaf, providing support and structure. A stipe is the stalk or stem that supports a structure in plants, algae, or fungi. A frond refers to a large, divided leaf, typically associated with ferns and some palm trees, but can also denote the leaves of ﬂowering plants like mimosa or sumac.

questions.question: Flowerless plants, naked seeds, needle like leaves and cones as reproductive structure are the characteristics of:
questions.explanation: gymnosperms. The gymnosperms (gymnos : naked, sperma : seeds) are plants in which the ovules are not enclosed by any ovary wall and remain exposed, both before and after fertilisation. Examples are Cycas, Pinus and Ginkgo. Angiosperms: The seeds are enclosed in fruits. They are divided into two classes : the dicotyledons and the monocotyledons. Pteridophytes are seedless, and they reproduce through spores. Bryophytes are amphibians of plant kingdom as they complete their life cycle in both water and on land. These mainly grow in damp, shady places, especially in the hills.

questions.question: The structure that produces and holds sperm cells in bryophytes (non - vascular plants) and ferns is called :
questions.explanation: Antheridium - A saclike structure and male sex organ that produces and stores gametes or sex cells called sperm. They produce biﬂ agellate antherozoids. Located on: A thin stalk attached to the gametophyte.

questions.question: The blue green alga Anabaena lives in the leaves of Azolla, a freshwater fern, forming which of the following relationships ?
questions.explanation: Symbiotic relationships are the close associations formed between pairs of species. They come in a variety of forms, such as parasitism (where one species bene ﬁ ts and the other is harmed), commensalism (where one species bene ﬁ ts and the other is neither harmed nor helped) and Mutualism (where all species involved bene ﬁ t from their interactions). Examples : Nitrogen- ﬁ xing bacteria and leguminous plants such as clover, alfalfa, and soybeans.

questions.question: Which of the following are cryptogram ?
questions.explanation: Pteridophyta. It belongs to the vascular plant family. They reproduce through spores rather than seeds. Examples - ferns, horsetails and lycophytes. Four classes of pteridophyta - Psilopsida, Lycopsida, Sphenopsida, Pteropsida. Cryptogams - Aﬂowerless and seedless group of plants having hidden sex organs. Three main divisions - Thallophyta, Bryophyta and Pteridophyte. They are the ﬁrst-e ver terrestrial plants to possess vascular tissues.

questions.question: Which of the following is a perennial herbaceous plant in the nightshade family Solanaceae that is used in alternative medicine as an aid in treating arthritis pain, colds or hay fever?
questions.explanation: Atropa belladonna - It is a perennial herbaceous plant in the nightshade family Solanaceae. It is native to Europe, North Africa, and Western Asia.
