Arachis hypogaea is the peanut plant. Cynodon dactylon is Bermuda grass, a major tropical grass found in all tropical and subtropical areas. Cicer arietinum is the chickpea plant.

questions.question: Which is the only living representative of Sphenopsida that has an underground, creeping and perennial rhizome that gives off aerial as well as underground branches?
questions.explanation: Equisetum - The aerial branches are herbaceous and usually grow to a height of 10-60 cm, but they can attain more height in some species. The pteridophytes are classi ﬁ ed into Psilopsida (Psilotum), Lycopsida (Selaginella, Lycopodium), Sphenopsida (Equisetum) and Pteropsida (Dryopteris, Pteris, Adiantum).

questions.question: Match column A with column B. Column A (Type of algae)Column B (Proper Name) a. Blue-green algae i. Sargassum b. Red algae ii. Chlamydomonas c. Green algae iii. Rhodophyta d. Brown algae iv. Cyanobacteria
questions.explanation: a - iv, b - iii, c - ii, d - i.

questions.question: Select the incorrect statement about Gymnosperms.

options.a: Gymnosperms are found as woody shrubs, trees or lianas and include no true aquatics and few epiphytes.
options.c: Gymnosperms are typically slow in terms of reproduction; up to a year may pass between pollination and fertilization and seed maturation may require 3 years.
options.d: Gymnosperms exhibit cones or storbili and naked seeds, but not ﬂowers.

questions.explanation: Gymnosperms are ﬂowerless, seed - producing plants. They belong to the subkingdom Embophyta. Examples - Cycas, Pinus, Araucaria, Thuja, Cedrus, Picea, Abies, Juniperus.

questions.question: Sporophyte stage is dominant in which plant group?
questions.explanation: Vascular plants (Tracheophytes) are land plants containing specialized vascular conducting tissues (xylem and phloem). Examples - Trees, shrubs, grasses, ﬂowering plants, and ferns.

questions.question: Which water-soluble pigment belonging to a phenolic group is present in pomegranate, eggplant, black carrots and red cabbage ?
questions.explanation: Anthocyanins. These are blue, red or purple pigments found in plants, ﬂowers, fruits, and tubers. It appears as red pigment in acidic conditions and blue pigment in alkaline conditions. Phenolics - These are chemical components that occur as natural color pigments responsible for the color of fruits of plants.

questions.question: Plants which are grown under shade are known as:
questions.explanation: Sciophytes. Examples : Java Moss, Mountain Fern Moss. Monocots - A group of ﬂowering plants belonging to the class Liliopsida or Monocotyledonae. Examples - Palms, Grasses, Orchids, and Lilies. Halophytes - Any perennial marsh plant that bears its overwintering buds in the mud below the surface. Examples - Salicornia europaea, Big Saltbush. Psammophytes - A plant that grows in sandy and often unstable soils. Examples - Agriophyllum squarrosum, Haloxylon ammodendron.

questions.question: Which is a multicellular ﬁlament ous green alga consisting of thin unbranched chains of cylindrical cells and found in ﬂoating masses near the surface of streams and ponds ?
questions.explanation: Spirogyra. Sargassum and Laminaria are the brown seaweed/algae found in brackish or salt water (rarely found in freshwater). Polysiphonia are red algae which are found in salt water. Ectocarpus is a genus of ﬁlament ous, marine brown algae. Chlorella is a genus of about 13 species of single-celled green algae of the division Chlorophyta.

questions.question: Which is a ﬂowerless, spore - producing plant that is usually a thin, horn - like, or needle - like a capsule with spores that develops from a ﬂat, green leaf ?
questions.explanation: Hornworts (bryophytes) .It grows on rocks in tropical and temperate regions. Scienti ﬁ c Name - Anthocerotophyta. Chara (A green algae) - It belongs to the Characeae family, A multicellular organism usually thrives in freshwater. Celandine - It is a botanical extract derived from a plant of the Poppy family. Genus - Stylophorum. Riccia - It is a genus of liverworts.

questions.question: Fungi can grow on which of the following items? I. Bread II. Pickles III. Leather IV. Clothes Select the correct option.
questions.explanation: I, II, III and IV. Fungi are eukaryotic (organisms whose cells contain a nucleus and other membrane - bound organelles) organisms. They grow in moist climatic areas where they get enough nutrition for their growth. The fungal spores are generally present in the air and grow on articles. Examples : Yeasts, smuts,mildews and mushrooms.

questions.question: Plants with green and tender stems are called .
questions.explanation: Herbs. Examples - Cabbage, Tomato, Mustard, Radish, Sun ﬂ ower, Carrot. Trees have their branches in the upper part of the stem, much above the ground. Examples - Neem, mango, coconut. Shrubs have the stem branching out near the base. Examples - Rose, jasmine, lemon.

questions.question: Which among the following is Phanerogams, ﬂowering and seed -bearing plants?
questions.explanation: Gymnosperms - whose seeds are completely naked and lack an ovary. characteristic - well developed tap root, Needle-like leaves, seeds but no fruits. Examples - Pine, Ginkgo, Pinus Tree. Reproduction - sexually and asexually.

questions.question: Which among the following is an example of Angiosperm in Plant Kingdom?
questions.explanation: Tomato. The plant kingdom is classi ﬁ ed into ﬁv e subgroups - Thallophyta, Bryophyta, Pteridophyta, Gymnosperms, Angiosperms.

questions.question: Which among the following plant kingdoms are divided into liverworts and mosses ?
questions.explanation: Bryophytes. It is also called amphibians of the plant kingdom because these plants can live in soil but are dependent on water for sexual reproduction. Spermatophytes - A subset of the embryophytes or land plants.

questions.question: Which among the following are called the amphibians of the plant kingdom ?
questions.explanation: Bryophyte. These are land plants which require water for sexual reproduction. Hence, these are found mostly in moist places in close proximityto water.

questions.question: Which among the following plant kingdoms are divided into dicotyledons and monocotyledons ?
questions.explanation: Angiosperms - Seed-bearing vascular plants with a well-differentiated plant body. The seeds are enclosed within the fruits. Examples - Mango, rose, tomato, onion, wheat and maize.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a subgroup of the plant kingdom?
questions.explanation: Hemichordata . Kingdom - Animalia, Subkingdom - Eumetazoa. Plant Kingdom is further classi ﬁ ed into subgroups of Thallophyta, Bryophyta, Pteridophyta, Gymnosperms and Angiosperms.

questions.question: Certain plants have green and tender stems. They are usually short and may not have many branches. What are they called as?
questions.explanation: Herbs. Creepers are plants with weak stems that cannot stand upright and spread readily on the ground. Examples - Pumpkin, Watermelon and Muskmelon.

questions.question: Plants that do not have well - differentiated body design fall in this group. The plants in this group are commonly called algae. These plants are predominantly aquatic.
questions.explanation: Thallophyta. Thallophyta is classi ﬁ ed into two subdivisions : Algae and Fungi. Examples - Spirogyra, Chara, Ulothrix, Ulva, Cladophora. Kingdom Plantae includes algae, bryophytes, pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms.

questions.question: Identify the correct statement about green algae.

options.a: Green algae usually have a soft cell wall made up of an inner layer of pectose.
options.b: Green algae usually have a rigid cell wall made of an inner layer of protein and an outer layer of ﬁbr e.
options.c: Green algae usually have a rigid cell wall made of an inner layer of cellulose and an outer layer of pectose.
options.d: Green algae usually have a rigid cell wall made of an inner layer of fat and an outer layer of protein.

questions.explanation: Green algae have chloroplast and chlorophyll in their cells. Examples are Chlamydomonas, Volvox, Spirogyra, Ulothrox, Oedogonium and Chara.

questions.question: In which of the following groups, are all plants monoecious ?
questions.explanation: Maize, Cucumber, Fig and Melon. Monoecious plants have both male and female reproductive parts in the same plant. Examples - cucurbits and coconuts, etc. Dioecious plants are referred to when the male and female reproductive organs are distinct. Examples - Cottonwood, plum pine, etc.

questions.question: Identify a marine alga that is used as food.
questions.explanation: Sargassum (gulfweed, sea holly) is a seaweed (macroalgae, family - Phaeophyceae (brown algae)). It is an edible, nutritious and rich source of bioactive compounds (vitamins, carotenoids, dietary ﬁbr es, proteins, and minerals). It is found in the Sargasso Sea in the north - central Atlantic.

questions.question: Most of the Chlorophyceae have one or more storage bodies called_____located in the chloroplasts.
questions.explanation: Pyrenoids are a protein body in the chloroplasts of algae and hornworts that are involved in carbon ﬁxation and starch formation and storage of Chlorophyceae.

questions.question: Which of the following is a diverse group of aquatic organisms capable of photosynthesising?
questions.explanation: Algae (photosyntheticeukaryotic organisms) Yeasts are eukaryotic, single celled microorganisms. Protozoa are one - celled animals. A fungus (eukaryotic organism that includes microorganisms such as yeasts, molds and mushrooms).

questions.question: What is the name of a protein that polymerizes into long chains or ﬁlaments that form microtubules, hollow ﬁbr es that act as the skeletal system for living cells?
questions.explanation: Tubulin ("heterodimer" protein). Elastin (protein) allows the skin to be ﬂexible and bounce back to its original shape. Fibrinogen (protein involved in forming blood clots in the body). Ferritin is a blood protein that contains iron.

questions.question: Which of the following is a type of bryophyte that lives in many environments and is characterised by its small, ﬂattened leaves, root-like rhizoids, and peristome ?
questions.explanation: Funaria is known as common moss or green moss or cord moss. Ulothrix, a genus of ﬁlament ous green algae (family Ulotrichaceae) found in marine and fresh waters. Cladophora, a genus of green algae (family Cladophoraceae). Ulva is a small genus of marine and brackish water green algae.

questions.question: What do you call the water holding compounds produced in large quantities by marine brown and red algae?
questions.explanation: Hydrocolloids. Algin (red algae) and carrageen (brown algae) are some important sources of natural hydrocolloids.

questions.question: What is the mode of adaptation done by aquatic plants and animals where the osmotic concentration of the body ﬂuids changes with that of the ambient air and water osmotic concentration?
questions.explanation: Conform. Plant Hormones and its Function: Ethylene - Fruit Ripening and Abscission, the dropping of leaves, fruits and ﬂowers. Gibberellins - Break the dormancy of seeds and buds, promote growth. Cytokinin - Promote Cell Division. Abscisic Acid - closing of stomata and maintaining dormancy. Auxins - Involved in tropisms and apical dominance.

questions.question: Which is a perennial carnivorous plant of the sundew family that attracts prey and usually traps insects and then breaks them down with digestive enzymes?
questions.explanation: Venus ﬂytr ap.It is native to North Carolina and South Carolina. Phytoplankton is the autotrophic component of the plankton community and a key part of ocean and freshwater ecosystems. Bladderwort is an aquatic carnivorous plant with highly divided, underwater leaf-like stems and numerous small "bladders".

questions.question: Identify the component that is unique only to prokaryotes.
questions.explanation: Mesosome is a special membrane structure, which is formed by the extension of the plasma membrane into the cell in a prokaryotic cell.

questions.question: Identify the plant that shows adaptation through leaves that are reduced to spines.
questions.explanation: Opuntia (cactus). Hibiscus (Orhul) can help boost your immune system. Mimosa (“Touch me not”) helps in the treatment of many disorders like piles, insomnia, diarrhea, etc.

questions.question: Which phylum of the plant kingdom consists of vascular plants, leaves (known as fronds), roots and sometimes true stems and entire trunks in tree ferns?
questions.explanation: Pteridophytes are also called vascular cryptogams. Smallest Pteridophyte is Azolla (an aquatic fern) and largest is Cyathea (tree fern).

questions.question: Which of the following are non - vascular ﬂowerless plants in the taxonomic division of Bryophyta?
questions.explanation: Mosses. A pine is any conifer tree or shrub in the genus Pinus of the family Pinaceae, it is the sole genus in the subfamily Pinoideae. Pea, (Pisum sativum), an herbaceous annual plant in the family Fabaceae.

questions.question: What is the nut of an oak tree called?
questions.explanation: Acorn , or oaknut, is the nut of the oaks and their close relatives (genera Quercus and Lithocarpus, in the family Fagaceae). The kola nut is the fruit of the kola tree (Cola acuminata and Cola nitida), indigenous to West Africa. Macadamia is a genus of four species of trees in the ﬂowering plant family Proteaceae. The chestnuts are the deciduous trees and shrubs in the genus Castanea, in the beech family Fagaceae.

questions.question: Camellia sinensis is a plant that produces ______.
questions.explanation: Tea. Jute is extracted from the bark of the white jute plant (Corchorus capsularis) and to a lesser extent from tossa jute (C. olitorius). Sugarcane, (Saccharum o ﬃ cinarum), perennial grass of the family Poaceae, primarily cultivated for its juice from which sugar is processed. The two most popular coffee are - Coffee arabica (commonly known simply as "Arabica"), and Coffea canephora (known as "Robusta").

questions.question: Which of the following is the middle layer in the root apical meristem that gives rise to the cortex?
questions.explanation: Periblem. Calyptrogen is a layer of rapidly dividing cells at the tip of a plant root, from which the root cap is formed. Dermatogen is the outer primary meristem of a plant or plant part that, according to the histogen theory, gives rise to epidermis. Plerome is the centralcore of the primary meristem of a plant or plant part that according to the histogen theory gives rise to the stele. The term meristem was coined by C. Nageli 1858.

questions.question: Identify a structure that plays a role in motility.
questions.explanation: Flagella are long, whip-like structures that protrude from the cell surface of certain bacteria and eukaryotic cells. Flagella are composed of a protein called ﬂagellin and are powered by the rotation of motor proteins. The other options are not directly involved in motility: Pili are short, hair-like structures involved in bacterial attachment and DNA transfer. Villi are ﬁnger-lik e projections found in the small intestine, involved in nutrient absorption. Fimbria are short, hair-like structures involved in bacterial attachment and adhesion.

questions.question: In the case of reptiles, their heart is not properly divided into four chambers i.e., it consists of two auricles and an incompletely divided ventricle. Which of the following is an example of a reptile having a four-chambered heart?
questions.explanation: Crocodile. Reptiles are terrestrial animals known for their creeping or crawling mode of locomotion, characterized by dry, corni ﬁ ed skin or scales. They typically have a three-chambered heart, though crocodiles possess a four-chambered heart. Reptiles are poikilothermic, meaning they rely on external temperatures to regulate body heat. They have internal fertilization, are oviparous, and undergo direct development. Examples include turtles, lizards, crocodiles , and venomous snakes like cobras and vipers.

questions.question: Which organisms are classi ﬁ ed as Aves ?
questions.explanation: Birds. Aves, commonly known as birds, are a class of endothermic vertebrates under the phylum Chordata. They are characterisedby features such as toothless beaks and laying hard-shelled eggs.

questions.question: Which species is known as black lipped pearl oyster found in the Indo - Paci ﬁ c, within tropical coral reefs?
questions.explanation: Pinctada margaritifera. This species is prized for its pearls and is widely cultivated for pearl production. Aplysia dactylomela : This is a black sea hare, a large sea slug found in tropical waters. Dentalium neohexagonum: This is a deep-sea tusk shell species native to the Indo-Paci ﬁ c region. Chaetopleura apiculata: This is a type of chiton, a marine mollusk with an armored shell.

questions.question: Which of the following options is associated with the class of cold - blooded animals ?
questions.explanation: Chameleons are reptiles. Cold - Blooded Animals : Cold-blooded animals, like reptiles and amphibians, have a body temperature that varies with their environment. Examples : Snakes, Lizards, Turtles, Frogs, Fish.

questions.question: Which of the following characteristics is NOT of Aves ?

options.b: They give birth to live young ones with some exceptions that lay eggs.

questions.explanation: The characteristic features of Aves (birds) are the presence of feathers and most of them can ﬂy except ﬂightless birds (e.g., Ostrich). The forelimbs are modi ﬁ ed into wings. The hind limbs generally have scales and are modi ﬁ ed for walking, swimming or clasping the tree branches. Endoskeleton is fully ossi ﬁ ed (bony) and the long bones are hollow with air cavities (pneumatic). Examples- Corvus (Crow), Columba (Pigeon), Psittacula (Parrot), Struthio (Ostrich), Pavo (Peacock), Aptenodytes (Penguin), Neophron (Vulture).

questions.question: Match the points under Column A with those under Column B. Column A Column B i. Annelida a. Tapeworm ii. Arthropoda b. Sea star iii. Echinodermata c. Ant iv. Platyhelminthes d. Earthworm
questions.explanation: i-d, ii-c, iii-b, iv-a. Annelida (Latin, annulus meaning "little ring") includes animals that can live in water (both marine and freshwater) or on land. They may be free-living or, in some cases, parasitic. Examples include Nereis, and Hirudinaria (blood-sucking leech).

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of Phylum Arthropoda?
questions.explanation: Butter ﬂ y.Phylum Arthropoda is the largest phylum in the animal kingdom, ﬁrst classiﬁ ed by Von Seibold in 1845. Approximately two-thirds of all named species belong to this phylum. Arthropods have a chitinous exoskeleton, jointed appendages, and various respiratory organs, including gills, book gills, book lungs, or a tracheal system. They possess an open circulatory system, and excretion occurs through Malpighian tubules. Examples include cockroaches, prawns, crabs, scorpions, house ﬂ ies, and mites.

questions.question: Which of the following classes includes the family of turtles?
questions.explanation: Reptilia. Turtles belong to the order Testudines. Reptiles are cold-blooded, have scaly skin, typically lay eggs, and possess lungs. This class includes snakes, lizards, crocodiles, and turtles. Chondrichthyes consist of cartilaginous ﬁshes like sharks and rays. Amphibia includes frogs and salamanders, which undergo aquatic larval stages. Aves (birds) are warm-blooded, have feathers, and lay eggs.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of both mammals and birds?
questions.explanation: Warm blooded. Warm-blooded animals can maintain a constant body temperature regardless ofenvironmental conditions by regulating their metabolic processes. Examples : Mammals, Birds. Cold-blooded animals, or poikilotherms, such as reptiles, snakes, ﬁsh, and amphibians, cannot generate their own body heat. Instead, they depend on their environment to regulate their temperature. Examples of cold-blooded animals include ﬁsh, amphibians, reptiles, insects, worms, crocodiles, sharks, and tortoises.

questions.question: Match the points under Column A with those under Column B. Column A Column B (Subphylum) (Animal) i. Hexapoda a. Daphnia ii. Crustacea b. Mosquito iii. Myriapoda c. Limulus iv. Chelicerata d. Julus
questions.explanation: i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c. Hexapods, the largest clade of arthropods, include most existing arthropod species. Crustaceans, part of the subphylum Crustacea, are invertebrates with about 45,000 species worldwide. Myriapods, from the subphylum Myriapoda, consist of terrestrial arthropods like millipedes and centipedes, with around 13,000 species. Chelicerata, another arthropod subphylum, includes both terrestrial and marine species.

questions.question: Which group of animals has a segmented spinal column together with a few primitive forms in which the backbone is represented by a notochord
questions.explanation: Vertebrata. These animals have a segmented spinal column and, during embryonic development, a notochord that is replaced by a vertebral column in adults. Vertebrates are chordates but not all chordates are vertebrates. They also have a muscular heart, kidneys, and paired appendages.

questions.question: Identify the INCORRECT statement regarding invertebrates from the options given below.

options.a: They have radial or bilateral body symmetry.
options.b: They have a pair of solid nerve cords, situated ventrally and bearing segmentally arranged ganglia.
options.c: They have an open circulatory system as there is no organisation in thedistribution.
options.d: They possess a backbone and an internal skeleton.

questions.explanation: An invertebrate is an animal that doesn't have a backbone or any bones at all. Bilateral Symmetry is found in most vertebrates and some invertebrates. The body of an organism can be divided into two equal halves by a single plane only. Spider and crab are examples of arthropods that demonstrate bilateral symmetry. The circulatory system is a system of organs that includes the heart, blood vessels, and blood which is circulated throughout the entire body of a human or other vertebrate.

questions.question: Which of the following statements most accurately describes the Cyclostomata group ?

options.a: Their skin is covered with scales/plates and their hearts have only two chambers.
options.b: They are ectothermic animals having mucus glands in the skin, and a three-chambered heart.
options.c: They are warm-blooded, oviparous, bipedal, feathered, winged and toothless vertebrates.
options.d: They are characterised by having an elongated eel-like body, circular mouth, slimy skin and are scaleless.

questions.explanation: The Cyclostomata group is a subclass of jawless ﬁshes. They are marine but migrate for spawning to fresh water. After spawning, within a few days, they die. Their larvae, after metamorphosis, return to the ocean. They have an elongated body bearing 6-15 pairs of gill slits for respiration. Examples: Petromyzon (Lamprey) and Myxine (Hag ﬁ sh).

questions.question: Which hairpin-like structure serves to anchor and stabilise the tick's mouthparts to its host's skin and to channel the exchange of ﬂuids?
questions.explanation: Hypostome is a structure found in certain arthropods, particularly ticks and some crustaceans. Located on the underside near the mouth, it aids in anchoring the organism to its host during feeding. In ticks, it has backward-facing spines that prevent detachment while feeding on blood. The hypostome also plays a role in the ingestion of ﬂuids from the host.

questions.question: Identify the largest phylum in the animal kingdom.
questions.explanation: Arthropoda . It includes insects (More than two-thirds of all species on earth). Respiratory organs include gills, book gills, and book lungs. They are mostly oviparous. Examples: Laccifer (Lac insect) Vectors – Anopheles, Culex and Aedes (Mosquitoes). Mollusca - Second largest animal phylum. Examples: Sepia (Cuttle ﬁ sh), Loligo (Squid), Octopus (Devil ﬁsh). Annelida - Example: Pheretima (Earthworm), Hirudinaria (blood-sucking leech). Platyhelminths - Have dorso-ventrally ﬂattened bodies; hence, called ﬂatworms. Example: Fasciola (liver ﬂuk e).

questions.question: The body of the phylum _______ is unsegmented and dorsoventrally ﬂattened.
questions.explanation: Platyhelminthes: They are known as ﬂatworms due to their dorsoventrally ﬂattened bodies. Examples include Taenia (tapeworm) and Fasciola (liver ﬂuk e). Coelenterata - Generally known as Cnidaria. Examples: Pleurobrachia; Ctenoplana. Arthropoda - The largest phylum of Animalia, and includes insects (More than two-thirds of all species on earth). Examples: Apis (Honey bee); Bombyx (Silkworm). Mollusca - Second largest animal phylum. Body covered with a calcareous shell. Example: Pila (Apple snail); Pinctada (Pearl oyster).

questions.question: Identify the organism that shows bioluminescence.
questions.explanation: Ctenoplana commonly known as sea walnuts or comb jellies are exclusively marine, radially symmetrical, diploblastic organisms with tissue level of organisation. The body bears eight external rows of ciliated comb plates, which help in locomotion. Sexes are not separate. Bioluminescence (the property of a living organism to emit light) is well-marked in ctenophores. Examples: Pleurobrachia and Ctenoplana. Q.390 . Biotic potential can be de ﬁ ned as: Matriculation Level 25/06/2024 (Shift - 1)(a) the minimum number of individuals of a species that can survive but cannot reproduce (b) the maximum number of individuals a species can produce (c) the minimum number of individuals a species can produce (d) the maximum number of individuals of a species that cannot survive after birth Sol.390.(b) Biotic potential, also known as reproductive potential, refers to the maximum rate at which a population of a species can increase under ideal conditions, with unlimited resources and no environmental limitations. Biotic potential differs from one species to another e.g., bacterial populations can grow faster than populations of oak trees. Q.391 . ____ is an example of acoelomate. Higher Secondary 24/06/2024 (Shift - 2) (a) Echinoderms (b) Platyhelminthes (c) Molluscs (d) Arthropods Sol.391.(b) Platyhelminthes. They have a dorso-ventrally ﬂattened body, hence are called ﬂatworms. Examples: Taenia (Tapeworm), Fasciola (Liver ﬂuk e). The animals in which the body cavity is absent are called acoelomates. Echinoderms comprise a group of marine invertebrates that includes sea stars, sea urchins, sea cucumbers, brittle stars, and crinoids.

questions.question: In which of the following animals are the stinging capsules located around the mouth and on the tentacles?
questions.explanation: Adamsia. Stinging capsules (nematocysts) are the organs which act as offense and defense. These nematocysts help Sea Anemones: Capture prey, Defend against predators, Compete for space. They belong to phylum Coelenterata. Other animals with stinging capsules include: Jelly ﬁ sh, Corals, Hydra, Portuguese Man-of-War.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a member of the Arthropoda phylum?
questions.explanation: Pila - It belongs to the phylum Mollusca and class Gastropoda.

questions.question: Which of the following choices is related to the phylum Coelenterata ?
questions.explanation: Aurelia. Coelenterata (Cnidaria) : They are aquatic, mostly marine, sessile or free-swimming, radially symmetrical animals. Phylum (Porifera) : Members of this phylum are commonly known as sponges. They are generally marine and mostly asymmetrical animals. These are primitive multicellular animals and have cellular level of organisation. Examples : Sycon (Scypha), Spongilla (Freshwater sponge) and Euspongia (Bath sponge).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a Protozoan?
questions.explanation: Scypha (Kingdom: Animalia) . Protozoans (Kingdom: Protista) - All protozoans are heterotrophs and live as parasites. Major groups of protozoans : Amoeboid protozoans - These organisms live in freshwater, sea water or moist soil. Flagellated protozoans - The members of this group are either free-living or parasitic. Ciliated protozoans - These are aquatic, actively moving organisms because of the presence of thousands of cilia. Sporozoans - This includes diverse organisms that have an infectious spore-like stage in their life cycle.

questions.question: Identify the third germinal layer found in triploblastic animals.
questions.explanation: Mesoderm. A triploblastic animal has three main layers of tissue during embryonic development. Ectoderm (upper layer) - It forms the brains, spinal cord, lens of the eye and hairs. Mesoderm (Middle layer) - It is responsible for the formation of notochord, bone, muscles, connective tissue and circulatory systems. Endoderm (lower layer) - It leads to the formation of the stomach, liver, colon, urinary bladder and lungs.

questions.question: Which of the following is a roundworm ?
questions.explanation: Ascaris - It belongs to phylum Nematoda. It is known as the small-intestinal roundworms, a type of parasitic worm. Its Infection causes haemorrhage, insomnia, peritonitis, diarrhoea, ulcer, tumour and even death. Other Examples - Hookworms, pinworms, ﬁlariasis and whipworms.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms belongs to phylum Apicomplexa?
questions.explanation: Plasmodium. Apicomplexa is a large phylum of parasitic protists belonging to the Alveolata group, together with ciliates and dino ﬂ agellates. The Apicomplexa are a diverse group that includes organisms such as the coccidia, gregarines, piroplasms, haemogregarines, and plasmodia. Diseases caused by Apicomplexa : Babesiosis (Babesia), and Malaria (Plasmodium).

questions.question: What is Typhlops?
questions.explanation: Blind snake. Phylum - Chordata, Family - Typhlopidae. Typhlops is a genus of blind snakes (nonpoisonous snakes). Some other types of snakes - Sea snake : Family - Elapidae, Genus - Hydrophis. Grass snake : Family - Colubridae, Genus - Natrix. Glass snake : Family - Anguidae, Genus - Ophisaurus.

questions.question: Match the animals in column A with the phylum they belong to in column B.Column-A Column-B i. Jelly ﬁ sh a. Mollusca ii. Cray ﬁ sh b. Mammal iii. Whale ﬁsh c. Insect iv. Devil ﬁsh d. Coelenterat
questions.explanation: i-d, ii-c, iii-b, iv-a.

questions.question: Which from the following is a phylum of animals found in fresh water ponds, lakes and swamps provides setae or parapodia for locomotion?
questions.explanation: Annelida. Some other members of this phylum: Oligochaeta (earthworms) and class Hirudinea (leeches), polychaete worms.

questions.question: Identify an organism that has awell-de ﬁ ned muscular pharynx.
questions.explanation: Ascaris. Adamsia - It is a species of sea anemone in the family Hormathiidae. It is commonly known as the cloak anemone or the hermit-crab anemone. Ctenoplana - It is the genus of comb jellies and the only genus in the Ctenoplanidae family. Gorgonia - It is a genus of soft corals, sea fans in the family Gorgoniidae.

questions.question: Which type of liverworts form umbrella-shaped structures that raise gametangia above the main gametophyte body and sporophytes develop below these structures ?
questions.explanation: Marchantia (Genus of liverworts). Polytrichum (Genus of mosses) - These mosses are commonly known as haircap mosses found in forest and humid environments. Sphagnum : A genus of mosses known as "peat mosses" found in wetlands and peat bogs. Funaria - It is a genus of mosses commonly known as cord mosses. They have tall, slender stalks that bear capsules at their tips.

questions.question: Meandrina is the generic name of which Coelenterata animal having soft tube-shaped bodies that live together in large groups?
questions.explanation: Brain coral. Coelenterata (Phylum) : It is a multicellular and simplest group of invertebrate animals.

questions.question: Identify the animal that does NOT have bilateral symmetry.
questions.explanation: Cnidarian. Bilateral symmetry - When the body plan of an animal can be divided along a line that separates the animal's body into right and left halves that are nearly identical to each other. Examples - Flatworms, Common worms (ribbon worms), Clams, Snails, Insects, Spiders, Sea urchins, and Vertebrates.

questions.question: Which group of Kingdom Animalia has unsegmented, bilaterallysymmetrical, soft bodies, with a triploblastic construction (comprising three layers of cells) and a lacking coelom, skeleton and anus?
questions.explanation: Platyhelminthes (Tapeworms, Turbellaria, Planaria, Liver ﬂuk e).Bilateral symmetry means when one organism is cut, it divides into two equal halves from a single plane only.

questions.question: In which of the following animal phyla, is the body divided into head, thorax and abdomen?
questions.explanation: Arthropoda (largest phylum). The phylum included invertebrates with an exoskeleton and jointed legs; Examples - Spiders, centipedes, mites, crabs, ticks, lobsters, scorpions, shrimp. Chordata - Fundamentally characterized by the presence of a notochord, a dorsal, hollow nerve cord and paired pharyngeal gill slits; Examples -Lampreys, Sea Squirt.

questions.question: Identify an algae that undergoes anisogamous fusion of gametes.
questions.explanation: Eudorina. Anisogamy (Heterogamy) - A type of sexual reproduction in which two dissimilar gametes unite or fuse. Isogamy - The gametes are similar in shape and size. They are shown differences only in their physiology. They are rounded in shape, and ﬂagella are present at the end of the front. It is the ﬁrst stage of sexual reproduction, and found in algae, fungi, and lower plants. Oogamous - The female gamete is much bigger than the male. The female gamete is immobile, while the male gamete is mobile.

questions.question: The _____ is an embryonic midline structure common to all members of the phylum Chordata that serves as a source of midline signals to surrounding tissues and as a major skeletal element of the developing embryo.
questions.explanation: Notochord. Nerve cord - It is a vast bundle of nerve ﬁbr es that runs along the body's longitudinal axis and an essential component of the Central Nervous System.

questions.question: Balanoglossus belongs to which of the following phylums of the animal kingdom?
questions.explanation: Hemichordata. Types of phylum of Animal Kingdom : Porifera {(Examples : Sycon (Scypha), Spongilla (Freshwater sponge) and Euspongia (Bath sponge)}. Coelenterata (Examples - Aurelia (Medusa), Adamsia (Polyp)}. Ctenophora (Examples - Pleurobrachia and Ctenoplana). Platyhelminthes {Examples - Taenia (Tapeworm), Fasciola (Liver ﬂuk e)}. Aschelminthes (Example - Roundworm). Annelida {Examples - Nereis, Hirudinaria}.

questions.question: Which among the following is an example of Phylum Mammalia of Animal Kingdom?
questions.explanation: Rat. Mammals are warm - blooded animals that have mammary glands and give birth to live young. Fishes, amphibians and reptiles are poikilothermous (cold-blooded).

questions.question: Snails is an example of which of the phylum of the animal kingdom?
questions.explanation: Mollusca (Second-largest invertebrate animal phylum). Snails are invertebrates, belonging to the Eukaryota domain and Animalia kingdom. Protochordates - Group of primitive chordates that include tunicates, lancelets, and the extinct Pikaia.

questions.question: Which among the following pairs of ‘animal - phylum of animal kingdom they belong’ is incorrect?
questions.explanation: Liver ﬂuk e-Nematoda . Phylum : Porifera - Spongilla, Sycon. Platyhelminthes - Tapeworm, Planaria. Nematoda - Ascaris, Wuchereria. Annelida - Earthworm, Leech. Arthropoda - Spiders, butter ﬂ ies, Prawns and mosquitoes. Mollusca - Snails and octopus. Echinodermata - Sea urchins, starﬁ sh. Coelenterata - Hydra, Jellyﬁ sh.Q.414. Hydra is an example of which of the following phylum of the animal kingdom? SSC CHSL 20/03/2023 (1st Shift) (a) Platyhelminthes (b) Nematoda (c) Coelenterata (d) Porifera Sol.414.(c) Coelenterata. It is a group of aquatic, or marine organisms and usually found attached to the rocks at the bottom of the sea .

questions.question: Which of the following comes under the platyhelminthes classi ﬁ cation under the animalia?
questions.explanation: Tapeworm. Platyhelminthes - belongs to Kingdom Animalia also known as Tapeworm or Flatworms (due to ﬂattened Body), soft - bodied invertebrate, Hermaphrodites, triploblastic, acoelomate and bilaterally symmetrical. Classi ﬁ ed into 3 types - Turbellaria (Planaria, Otoplana), Trematoda (Fasciola hepatica, Diplozoon), Cestoda (Taenia, Convoluta).

questions.question: Which group of animals are named because of their spiny skin and have a peculiar water-driven tube system that they use for moving around?
questions.explanation: Echinodermata. Aschelminthes (roundworms) : They are a diverse phylum of unsegmented, bilaterally symmetrical worms with cylindrical bodies.

questions.question: Identify an example of organisms that are free-swimming and bottom - dwelling forms.
questions.explanation: Zooplankton are a type of heterotrophic plankton that range from microscopic organisms to large species, such as jelly ﬁ sh, larval crustaceans, krill, copepods, protozoans, etc. They are the primary consumers in lake ecosystems.

questions.question: Identify the organism that is NOT a pseudocoelomate.
questions.explanation: Scorpions {Kingdom (Animalia), Phylum (Arthropoda), Subphylum (Chelicerata), Class(Arachnida)}. Pseudocoelomates are the organisms that have false body cavities. The pseudocoelomates belong to the phylum Nematoda/Aschelminthes. Examples: Aschleminthes - Nematoda (Ancylostoma, Ascaris, Wuchereria), Rotifera (Asplanchna, Euchlanis, etc) .

questions.question: Identify an example of decomposers that are found in the bottom of a pond.
questions.explanation: Flagellates. The decomposers of the pond ecosystem are fungi, bacteria and ﬂagellates. Decomposers in different ecosystems: Soil (fungi, insects, earthworms, and bacteria), Oceans (Christmas tree worm, Crab, Granulated sea star, Hagﬁ sh, Sea urchin, Tube worm), Freshwater (Mildew, Trumpet snail, Water mold, Yeast), Forest (Beetle, Earthworm, Millipede, Mushroom, Pillbug, Saprobe, Slime mold, Slug), Desert (Dung beetle, Fly, Millipede, Saharan silver ant), Grassland (Acidobacteria, Termite, Turkey tail mushroom), Mountain (Bolete mushroom, Mountain pine bark beetle, Purple fairy ﬁngers).

questions.question: The body of the ______ is circular in cross-section, hence the name roundworms. They may be free living, aquatic and terrestrial or parasitic in plants and animals.
questions.explanation: Aschelminthes (roundworms) - An obsolete phylum of wormlike invertebrates, mostly of microscopic size. Body is elongated and cylindrical. Appear circular in cross-section.

questions.question: Which of the following cells line the spongocoels and canals in members of the phylum Porifera?
questions.explanation: Collar cells (Choanocytes, ﬂagellated cells) line the inner surface of the spongocoel and the canal of sponges. The beating of the ﬂagella fr om all choanocytes draws water into the sponge through the numerous Ostia, into the spaces lined by choanocytes, and eventually out through the osculum. The term somatic cells refer to any type of cells that contain a diploid number of chromosomes. Gametes are the scienti ﬁ c name for sex cells (egg or sperm).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a polar animal?
questions.explanation: Lemurs are a type of prosimian, which means they are primates that evolved before monkeys and apes. Polar Animals : Polar Bear, Arctic Fox, Antarctic Minke Whale, Brown Bear, Paci ﬁ c Salmon, Orca, Snowy Owl, Leopard Seal, Arctic Wolf,Penguin, Walrus, Narwhal, Arctic Hare, Beluga Whale, Pu ﬃ n, Reindeer, Musk Oxen.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is/are correct? I. Amoeba ingests its food with the help of pseudopodia. II. Amoeba constantly changes its shape and position.
questions.explanation: Only I. Amoeba is a unicellular organism that has the ability to change its shape. Amoeba reproduces asexually through binary ﬁssion. Examples : Entamoeba Histolytica, Amoeba Proteus, Chaos carolinense etc.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a characteristic of Kingdom Fungi?
questions.explanation: With chloroplasts. Fungi are eukaryotic organisms that include microorganisms such as yeasts, moulds and mushrooms. Characteristics of Fungi : They are non-vascular, non-motile and heterotrophic organisms, They may be unicellular or ﬁlament ous, They reproduce by means of spores, They exhibit the phenomenon of alternation of generation, They lack chlorophyll and hence cannot perform photosynthesis, They store their food in the form of starch, Biosynthesis of chitin occurs in them, The nuclei of the these are very small, etc.

questions.question: ________is commonly known as imperfect fungi because only the asexual or vegetative phases of these fungi are known.
questions.explanation: Deuteromycetes, commonly called molds, are “second-class” fungi that have no known sexual state in their life cycle and thus reproduce only by producing spores via mitosis. This asexual state is also called the anamorph state. Phycomycetes organisms are found throughout the world in soil, animal manure, and on fruits. Basidiomycetes are commonly known as club fungi. Ascomycetes are spore shooters, they are called sac fungi because their sexual spores, called ascospores, are produced in a sac or ascus.

questions.question: Which of the following is a group of primitive vertebrates having a large jawless sucking mouth, no limbs or paired ﬁns and a completely cartilaginous skeleton with a persistent notochord?
questions.explanation: Cyclostomata - Hag ﬁ shes and lampreys. Aschelminthes - Roundworm - Ascaris lumbricoides, Hookworm - Ancylostoma, Filarial worm - Wuchereria.

questions.question: Which group of animals has a body wall composed of both circular and longitudinal muscle ﬁbr es surrounded by a moist, cellular cuticle that is secreted by an epidermal epithelium?
questions.explanation: Annelids are coelomate and triploblastic. Their body is segmented. They respire through their body surface. Examples - Earthworm, Leeches, Lugworms, Polychaetes etc.

questions.question: The bodies of the animals of phylum Platyhelminthes show _____grade organisation.
questions.explanation: Tissue-organ. Protoplasmic is a mixture of water, amino acids, proteins, small molecules of ions, macromolecules such as nucleic acids, etc. Cellular respiration is a metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose and produces ATP . Adenosine triphosphate (ATP) is the source of energy for use andstorage at the cellular level.

questions.question: Which of the following characters are correct about Phylum Echinodermata ?
questions.explanation: Coelom present, bilateral symmetry. Phylum Echinodermata organisms (multi-cellular) are exclusively marine. Characteristics - Triploblastic and have a coelomic cavity, star-like appearance and are spherical or elongated, respire through gills, their skeleton is made up of calcium carbonate. Examples - a star ﬁ sh, a sand dollar, a brittle star, a sea urchin, and a sea cucumber. Q.430 . The body of animals of the phylum Protozoa, such as Paramecium, Amoeba, Euglena, shows ________ grade organisation. SSC CHSL 10/06/2022 (Afternoon) (a) tissue-organ (b) protoplasmic (c) cell-tissue (d) cellular Sol.430.(b) Protoplasmic. It is a mixture of water, amino acids, proteins, small molecules of ions, macromolecules such as nucleic acids, etc.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct with respect to chordates?

options.b: Heart is dorsal or laterally placed or absent
options.c: A post anal tail is absent

questions.explanation: The ﬁv e characteristic features of chordates present during some time of their life cycles are a notochord, a dorsal hollow tubular nerve cord, pharyngeal slits, endostyle/thyroid gland, and a post-anal tail. Examples of vertebrate chordates include ﬁshes, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals.

questions.question: ‘Hypnea Indica and Hypnea bullata’ are types of :
questions.explanation: Red seaweeds . "Seaweed" is the common name for countless species of marine plants and algae that grow in the ocean as well as in rivers, lakes, and other water bodies. Three types of Seaweed based on pigmentation - Brown Algae (Phaeophyta), Green Algae (Chlorophyta), Red Algae (Rhodophyta).

questions.question: How many eyes does a bee have?
questions.explanation: Five. The honey bee has ﬁv e eyes, two large compound eyes and three smaller ocelli eyes in the centre of its head.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered unicellular green algae ?
questions.explanation: Chlamydomonas. Unicellular green algae are single-celled, plant-like organisms containing chlorophyll. Chlamydomonas, with two ﬂagella, thriv es in water and soil, often turning water green. Chlorella is protein-rich and used as a food supplement. Volvox forms spherical colonies, showcasing unique colonial behavior.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms is used in bread and alcohol industries?
questions.explanation: Yeast, particularly Saccharomyces cerevisiae, is widely used in the bread and alcohol industries for fermentation, helping to produce carbon dioxide for leavening bread and ethanol for alcoholic beverages. Clostridium is a genus of anaerobic, Gram-positive bacteria. Nitrobacter is a genus comprising rod-shaped, gram-negative, and chemoautotrophic bacteria. Penicillium is a genus of ascomycetous fungi.

questions.question: Which of the following categories does Gonyaulax belong to?
questions.explanation: Dino ﬂ agellates. These organisms are mainly marine, photosynthetic organisms that can appear in various colors such as yellow, green, brown, blue, or red, depending on their pigments. Euglenoids include Euglena, Chrysophytes encompassdiatoms and golden algae, while Amoeba represents protozoans.

questions.question: Microbes like Rhizobium, Nitrosomonas and Nitrobacter are used for:
questions.explanation: nitrogen cycling. Nitrogen cycle is the biogeochemical cycle that describes the transformation of nitrogen and nitrogen-containing compounds in nature. Atmospheric nitrogen is the biggest source of nitrogen. Green plants absorb nitrogen in the form of nitrates and nitrites from the soil and water. Animals get nitrogen when they feed upon plants.

questions.question: The organisms that do not have a deﬁ ned nucleus or organelles are classi ﬁ ed into _______ Kingdom.
questions.explanation: Monera - It comprises unicellular, prokaryotic organisms, having no well-de ﬁ ned nucleus and no organelles. Bacteria are the sole members of the Kingdom Monera. Kingdom Monera is classi ﬁ ed into three sub-kingdoms- Archaebacteria, Eubacteria, and Cyanobacteria. Protista - The protistan cell body contains a well deﬁ ned nucleus and other membrane-bound organelles. Plantae - It includes all eukaryotic chlorophyll -containing organisms commonly called plants. Fungi - They are eukaryotic organisms that include microorganisms such as yeasts, moulds and mushrooms.

questions.question: Which of the following options indicates the size of PPLO (Pleuro Pneumonia Like Organisms)?
questions.explanation: About 0.1 μm. Pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO), or mycoplasmas, are among the smallest bacteria, ranging from 0.1 to 0.3 mm. Q.440 . Identify a spiral-shaped bacteria SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Bacillus (b) Spirillum (c) Coccus (d) Vibrio Sol.440.(b) Spirillum - A bacterium with rigid spiral (helical) structure (not easily band, not ﬂexible), thick, long, and move with ﬂagella, 6–15 μm long and spiral inshape. For example, Campylobacter jejuni and Helicobacter pylori. Bacteria are grouped into four categories based on their shape - Coccus: Spherical in shape, Bacillus: Rod-shaped, and Vibrio: Comma-shaped. Q.441 . Which bacteria have a thick cell wall with several layers of peptidoglycan and teichoic acid ? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Staphylococcus aureus (b) Pseudomonas aeruginosa (c) Salmonella enterica (d) Escherichia coli Sol.441.(a) Staphylococcus aureus is a gram - positive spherically shaped bacterium, a member of the Bacillota, and is a usual member of the microbiota of the body, frequently found in the upper respiratory tract and on the skin.

questions.question: Which of the following bacteria grow in milk and convert it to curd ?
questions.explanation: Lactic acid bacteria. This group of bacteria, which includes species like Lactobacillus, is responsible for fermenting lactose in milk to produce lactic acid, thereby converting milk into curd. Salmonella typhi - causes typhoid fever.

questions.question: Select the INCORRECT statement about Agar.

options.a: Agar is used to grow microbes.
options.b: Agar, one of the commercial products obtained from red algae, gelidium and gracilaria.
options.c: It is used as a nutrient and source of fat of bacterial culture.
options.d: It is used in preparations of ice-creams and jellies.

questions.explanation: Agar is not a source of fat for bacterial culture, but it is used as a solid growth surface to help feed and grow bacteria. Agar is a gelatinous heteropolysaccharide produced in the cell wall of marine red algae such as species of Gelidium, Gracilaria, Gigartina, etc.

questions.question: How many components do bacterial ﬂagella have ?
questions.explanation: 3. The bacterial ﬂagellum is a helical ﬁlament ous organelle responsible for motility. These are made up of the protein ﬂagellin and are a coiled, thread-like structure with a sharp bend and a rotary motor at the base.

questions.question: What is the diameter size range of the virus?
questions.explanation: 20-200 nm. Virus - It is much smaller than bacteria and most of it is microscopic. Viral diseases - Chickenpox, Measles, Rubella, Roseola, Polio.

questions.question: Which of the following can degrade detritus into simpler inorganic substances?
questions.explanation: Fungal enzymes. The process of breaking down complex organic matter in the detritus to simple organic or inorganic compounds is called Catabolism. Bacterial and fungal enzymes can degrade detritus into simpler inorganic substances. DNA polymerase is a catabolic enzyme which catalyses DNA synthesis.

questions.question: Which of the following is a kind of Xanthan?
questions.explanation: Microbial gum. Xanthan gum : A microbial exo-polysaccharide produced by Xanthomonas bacteria. It is an effective thickening agent, emulsi ﬁ er, and stabiliser that prevents ingredients from separating. Xanthan gum is produced by the fermentation of glucose and sucrose. Xanthan gum discovered by Allene Jeanes.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of microorganism - type is correct? I. Paramecium - Fungi II. Penicillium - Protozoa
questions.explanation: Neither I nor II. Microorganisms types : Algae (photosynthetic eukaryotic organisms, embryophytes and green algae), Protozoa (Paramecia, Amoeba, Euglena), Slime moulds (Stemonitis, Physarum, Dictyostellida, Lycogala, Tubifera, etc.), Fungi (yeasts, penicillium, rusts, smuts,mildews, molds), Bacteria (Escherichia coli, Spirillum volutans), Archaea (hyperthermophiles, methanogens), Viruses (In ﬂ uenza, HIV, Pneumon).

questions.question: Which aquatic microorganisms eat phytoplankton and then become food for ﬁsh, crustaceans and other large species?
questions.explanation: Zooplankton (eat phytoplankton and become food for other organisms) are small, free- ﬂ oating aquatic microorganisms including rotifers, jelly ﬁ sh, and open-water insect larvae.

questions.question: What kind of adaptation is seen in bacteria when they form various kinds of thick- walled spores.
questions.explanation: Suspend. Endospores are thick-walled structures formed in bacteria in order to survive unfavorable conditions such as extreme boiling and freezing temperatures and ultraviolet radiations. They protect and allow the bacteria to exist in “suspended animation”. They also formed lower plants like bryophytes, lichens, algae, and Fungi.

questions.question: Which unicellular organism acquires food by a process in which cells absorb external material by engul ﬁ ng it with the cell membrane?
questions.explanation: Amoeba is a unicellular organism that has the ability to change its shape. They are omnipresent and found in water bodies. Yeast (unicellular) converts sugar and starch into carbon dioxide and alcohol. It reproduces by budding.

questions.question: Which is the toxin-causing bacterium that spoils cream, cheese and milk and makes them taste bitter, sour or bitter?
questions.explanation: Bacillus cereus is a Gram - positive, rod-shaped, anaerobic, motile,beta-hemolytic, spore-forming bacterium commonly found in soil, food, and marine sponges. It can cause two types of gastrointestinal illness : emetic (vomiting) syndrome and diarrhoeal syndrome.

questions.question: What is a biotechnological process accomplished by yeast, some type of bacteria, or some other microorganism to convert sugar into ethyl alcohol and carbon dioxide?
questions.explanation: Alcoholic fermentation. Alcoholic beverages like beer, wine, brandy, whisky, etc are made using fermentation of grains, grapes, rice, etc by yeast. Pasteurization (heat-treatment process) destroys pathogenic microorganisms in certain foods and beverages. Glycolysis is the process in which glucose is broken down to produce energy.

questions.question: Identify the algae that is NOT a marine algae.
questions.explanation: Chlorella (Chlorella pyrenoidosa) is a type of algae that grows in freshwater. It's used for nutrition and as medicine as it is rich in proteins and B-complex vitamins. The algal cell is roughly spherical and features a cup-shaped chloroplast and numerous starch grains.

questions.question: What is the function of cytochrome P450 ?
questions.explanation: Detoxi ﬁ cation of xenobiotics. Cytochrome P450 is a family of heme-containing enzymes that are important for many physiological processes.

questions.question: Insu ﬃ cient levels of parathyroid hormone and low amount of calcium in the blood causes which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Hypocalcemia. Calcium-rich foods : Curd, cheese, milk, dark green vegetables, eggs, fatty ﬁsh and milk. Diabetes - When the pancreas does not produce enough insulin or when the body cannot effectively use the insulin it produces.

questions.question: Match the columns.Column-A (Enzyme/Protein)Column-B (Role in DNA replication) i. Helicase a. Joins the 3' end o the new DNA fragment to the 5' end of the previous one ii. RNA primase b. Nucleotide polymerisation iii. DNA polymerasec. RNA primer synthesis iv. DNA ligase d. Opens up the DNA double helix
questions.explanation: i-d, ii-c, iii-b, iv-a.

questions.question: Peeling, cutting or crushing onion tissue releases which enzyme that makes our eyes water?
questions.explanation: Allinases. Eating part of an onion is a stem and ﬂeshy leaves. Enzymes found in others : Chili - Capsaicin, Turmeric - Curcumin, Garlic - Alliinase. Xylanases are mainly produced by microorganisms. Examples : bacteria, fungi. Bordelaises a sauce consisting of stock thickened with roux and ﬂa vored typically with red wine and shallots. Pectinases are used to break down this pectin polymer into monomer sugars i.e. galacturonic acid.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about enzymes in the human body is/are correct? Statement A: Maltase is present in the saliva and breaks the sugar maltose into glucose. Statement B: Amylase is present in the saliva and helps change starches into sugars.
questions.explanation: Both A and B. Saliva acts as a digestive juice and softens the food, allowing for an easier digestion process. It contains a starch digestive enzyme, salivary amylase that digests the starch and converts it into maltose (disaccharide). Saliva also contains an enzyme called lingual lipase, which breaks down fats.

questions.question: Steapsin, the enzyme which converts fats into fatty acids and glycerol, is secreted by ________.
questions.explanation: Pancreas. Digestive enzymes : Pepsin - Released in the stomach's gastric juice along with HCI (Hydrochloric acid) and Mucus. HCI provides an acidic pH to activate the enzyme and breaks down proteins present in food to smaller molecules.

questions.question: Which among the following mineral is essential for the synthesis of thyroid hormones (thyroxine)?
questions.explanation: Iodine. The thyroid hormone is well known for controlling metabolism, growth, and many other bodily functions.

questions.question: Which of the following can degrade detritus into simpler inorganic substances?
questions.explanation: Fungal enzymes. Detritus : Dead and decaying organic debris. Lichens : A symbiosis of fungus and algae. Phytoplankton (microalgae) : They are microscopic, photosynthetic organisms that ﬂoat in aquatic ecosystems, serving as the foundation of marine food chains.

questions.question: Identify the function of the enzyme trypsin.
questions.explanation: Digesting proteins. Trypsin is secreted into the small intestine for the digestion of protein. It is a proteolytic enzyme produced in the pancreas in the precursor form of inactive trypsinogen.

questions.question: Identify the statement that is NOTtrue about ATP .
questions.explanation: Secretion of enzymes. Adenosine triphosphate (ATP) is an organic compound that provides energy to drive many processes in living cells, such as muscle contraction, nerve impulse propagation, condensate dissolution, and chemical synthesis.

questions.question: Amylase enzymes can be found in ______.
questions.explanation: Saliva. Amylase enzyme is a digestive enzyme that breaks down the complex chains of starch into simple sugars that can be digested and absorbed easily. Three types of amylases : alpha (found in humans, animals, plants, as well as in microbes), beta (found in microbes and plants) and gamma (found in plants and animals). Stomach (pepsin enzyme, digest proteins found in ingested food).

questions.question: Which antimicrobial enzymes are present in milk?
questions.explanation: Some of the native enzymes in milk are alkaline phosphatase, lactoperoxidase, lysozyme, lipase, proteinase, cathepsin D etc. Minerals found in milk are iodine, calcium, phosphorus, and potassium. It also provides some sodium, magnesium, zinc, and selenium but is not a reliable source of iron, copper, or manganese.

questions.question: Which enzyme is responsible for the oxidation reaction that occurs in some foods, mostly fruits and vegetables, that turns the food brown?
questions.explanation: Polyphenol oxidase. Bromelain is a group of enzymes found in the fruit and stem of the pineapple plant. Serrapeptase is a chemical taken from the silkworm. Papain is an enzyme found in the white ﬂuid (latex) that occurs in raw papaya fruit.

questions.question: Glucagon, a peptide hormone, is produced by the ______.
questions.explanation: Pancreas. Glucagon is a 29 -amino acid peptide hormone predominantly secreted from the alpha cells of the pancreas.

questions.question: Enzyme linked immuno-sorbent assay is a technique used in detection of which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation: Acquired immunode ﬁ ciency syndrome (AIDS). The enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) test is frequently used to identify HIV infection.

questions.question: Which of the following hormone is secreted by the brain that helps to regulate sleep-wake cycles?
questions.explanation: Melatonin. It is produced from serotonin (made from tryptophan), through a cascade of enzymatic reactions. Its production increases with evening darkness, promoting healthy sleep and helping to orient our circadian rhythm.

questions.question: Which of the following is an inactivated (killed) polio vaccine developed in 1952?
questions.explanation: Salk vaccine. The Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) developed by Jonas Salk and the Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) developed by Albert Sabin. Polio (poliomyelitis) is a highly infectious viral disease that enters the body through the mouth, multiplying in the intestine before invading the nervous system. Imvanex vaccine used to protect against smallpox. HDCV (Human diploid cell vaccine) is a rabies vaccine. TAB vaccine (Typhoid-paratyphoid A and B) is used for the treatment of typhoid.Q.472. Who developed the technique of preserving the quality of food by raising its temperature to prevent microbial growth in the food ? SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Antonie van Leeuwenhoek (b) Joseph Lister (c) Robert Koch (d) Louis Pasteur Sol.472.(d) Louis Pasteur. He was a French biologist who is often regarded as the father of modern microbiology. Scientists and their discoveries: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek - Microbiology, Charles Darwin - Theory of evolution, Robert Koch - Tuberculosis bacterium, Barbara McClintock - Jumping genes, Watson and Crick - DNA structure.

questions.question: Who described the algae Spirogyra in 1674 and named the motile organisms Animalcules, meaning ‘little animals’?
questions.source: SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Barthelemy Dumortier (a) Maurice Wilkins (c) Anton Van Leeuwenhoek (d) Robert Remak
questions.explanation: Anton van Leeuwenhoek, a Dutch scientist, was the ﬁrst to discover and describe microorganisms, including protists and bacteria, which he characterized as "animalcules." James Watson, Francis Crick and Maurice Wilkins discover the molecular structure of DNA. Robert Remak was the ﬁrst scientist to undertake successful research on fungal skin infections.

questions.question: Which of the following was discovered by GN Ramachandran?

options.a: Fluid mosaic model of a cell

questions.explanation: Triple helical structure of collagen. G.N. Ramachandran, an Indian physicist, is renowned for his work that resulted in the creation of the Ramachandran plot, which aids in understanding peptide structure. The collagen triple helix, a right-handed super-coiled structure, consists of three parallel α-chains, each adopting a polyproline II helical conformation.

questions.question: Around which year did Robert Brown publish a paper highlighting the presence of a nucleus in plant cells ?
questions.explanation: 1830s. Nucleus of the cell - First described by Franz Bauer in 1804 and in more detail in 1831 by Scottish botanist Robert Brown in a talk at the Linnean Society of London.

questions.question: Who explained the structure of protein ?
questions.explanation: Pauling and Corey. Linus Pauling and Robert Corey proposed the alpha helix and beta sheet secondary structures of proteins in 1951. Pauling was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1954 for their work on the structure of proteins.

questions.question: In 1873, who published the ﬁrst phot ograph of nerve tissue stained with the black reaction technique, describing a whole nerve cell ?
questions.explanation: Camillo Golgi (An Italian physician and scientist). Scientists and their Discoveries : Gunter Blobel - Proteins have signals that govern their movement and position in the cell. William Harvey - The function of the heart and the circulation of blood. Paul Ehrilich - Effective treatment for syphilis.

questions.question: Which bacteria was discovered by Barry Marshall and Robin Warren that colonises the human stomach and causes chronic super ﬁ cial gastritis ulcers?
questions.explanation: Helicobacter pylori. Campylobacter jejuni bacteria are found naturally in the intestines of poultry, cattle, swine, rodents, wild birds and household pets like cats and dogs. Neisseria gonorrhoeae infects the mucous membranes of the reproductive tract, including the cervix, uterus, and fallopian tubes in women. Entamoeba histolytica is well recognized as a pathogenic ameba, associated with intestinal and extraintestinal infections.

questions.question: Which cytologist demonstrated the role of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) in protein processing and sorting in a variety of cells in the 1960s ?
questions.explanation: George E Palade won the 1974 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his work on the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). Ralph M. Steinman was a physician and immunologist who won the 2011 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his discovery of dendritic cells in 1973. Nettie Stevens was an American biologist who discovered the sex chromosomes in 1905.

questions.question: Which of the following personalities is a well-known Indian plant physiologist and physicist ?
questions.explanation: JC Bose (Father of Indian Plant Physiology) invented the ‘crescograph’ for measuring plant growth. CV Raman was awarded the 1930 Nobel Prize in Physics for his discovery of the ‘Raman Effect’. CNR Rao - An Indian chemist who was awarded Bharat Ratna in 2014. JRD Tata (Father of Indian Civil Aviation) - The ﬁrst person in India to own a ﬂying licence.

questions.question: In which year did Rudolf Ludwig Karl Virchow formulate his famous aphorism 'Omnis cellula-e cellula' which became a part of the foundation of cell theory?
questions.explanation: 1855. Cell was ﬁrst discovered by Robert Hooke in 1665. Cell theory was proposed by Theodor Schwann in 1839.

questions.question: In which year did E Gorter and F Grendel make a breakthrough by examining the surface area of lipids and concluded that the lipid surface surrounding cells must be of two layers?
questions.explanation: 1925. Lipids - These are molecules that contain hydrocarbons and make up the building blocks of the structure and function of living cells. Example : fats, oils, waxes, certain vitamins such as (A, D, E and K), hormones and most of the cell membrane that is not made up of protein.

questions.question: In which year did an Americancytogeneticist named Joe Hin Tjio publish a research ﬁnding that deﬁ ned 2n=46 as the exact number of human chromosomes?
questions.explanation: 1956. They are responsible for the hereditary traits and passed from parents to offspring from one generation to another. 22 pairs of these chromosomes are called autosomes (identical in males and females). The 23rd pair of chromosomes are called Sex Chromosomes and they differ between the sexes. Males have XY while females have XX. This unique structure of the chromosome keeps DNA tightly packed with histone proteins to ﬁt inside the cell.

questions.question: In which year did Walther Flemming coined the term ‘chromatin’ for the stained substance found in the cell nucleus?
questions.explanation: 1879. Chromatin is a substance in the chromosome consisting of DNA and proteins, Consists of Histones which helps in compacting the DNA to ﬁt into the cell nucleus.

questions.question: Which ecologist is famous for studying plant life in the Indiana Dunes in 1896 ?
questions.explanation: Henry Chandler Cowles - American botanist and ecologist who inﬂ uenced the early study of plant communities. G Evelyn Hutchinson - American zoologist known for his ecological studies of freshwater lakes. Aldo Leopold - American environmentalist whose book is “A Sand County Almanac”.

questions.question: Which among the following are commonly known as blood thinners?
questions.explanation: Anticoagulants - Medicines that help prevent blood clots. Antibodies - Proteins produced by the body's immune system when they detect harmful substances, called antigens (Bacteria, fungi, parasites, and viruses). Anti-caking - Absorption of excess moisture or by coating particles to makethem more water repellant.

questions.question: Who explained the structure and reproductive system of algae in 1935 ?
questions.explanation: FE Fritsch - In his book “The Structure and Reproduction of the Algae” proposed a system of classi ﬁ cation of algae. He treated algae giving the rank of division and divided it into 11 classes. His classi ﬁ cation of algae is mainly based upon characters of pigments, ﬂagella and reserve food material. Parthasarathy Iyengar - Father of Indian Phycology.

questions.question: Which ecologist’s research provided revolutionary new insights into how energy and nutrients move through the ecosystems?
questions.explanation: Raymond Laurel Lindeman was an ecologist whose graduate research is credited with being a seminal study in the ﬁeld of ecosystem ecology, speci ﬁ cally on the topic of trophic dynamics.

questions.question: In 1857, who was the ﬁrst to experimentally demonstrate that the yeast responsible for making alcohol from sugar, and contaminating microorganisms found in normal air, Could sour fermentation?
questions.explanation: Louis Pasteur . He discovered that microorganisms cause fermentation and disease, the process of pasteurisation, and developed vaccines against anthrax and rabies. Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin. Fanny Hesse was the ﬁrst to propose the use of agar as a culture media for growing and isolating bacteria. Beijerinck was the ﬁrst t o recognize that viruses are reproducing entities that are different from other organisms.

questions.question: With whom did Camillo Golgi receive the Nobel Prize in 1906 for his work on the structure of the nervous system?
questions.explanation: Santiago Ramón y Cajal. Ettore Marchiafava (known for his study of Malaria). Cesare Lombroso (gave the biological theory of criminology).

questions.question: In 1838, who published an article discussing the structure and origin of plant cells?
questions.explanation: Matthias Schleiden and Theodor Schwann, co-founded the cell theory. In 1838 Schleiden de ﬁ ned the cell as the basic unit of plant structure, and a year later Schwann de ﬁ ned the cell as the basic unit of animal structure.

questions.question: In 1972, ________ coined the term ‘pyramid of numbers’ that represented the total numbers of individuals (population) present in each trophic level.
questions.explanation: Charles Elton. Eugene Pleasants Odum is known for his pioneering work on ecosystem ecology. Ernst Haeckel coined the term 'ecology' in 1866 to describe the “economies” of living forms. Tansley coined the term “ecosystem” to recognize the integration of the biotic community and its physical environment.

questions.question: For what discovery was Jan Evangelista Purkinje known in 1839 ?
questions.explanation: Coined the term protoplasm (1839), David Robertson - Proposed a lipid bilayer membrane.

questions.question: In 1879, who observed cell division in salamander embryos, where cells divide at ﬁx ed intervals?
questions.explanation: Walther Flemming was a pioneer of cytogenetics, a ﬁeld of science that analyses structures and processes in the cell nucleus under amicroscope. He also discovered animal chromosomes. Albert von Kolliker is best known for his contributions to histology, the knowledge of the minute structure of the animal tissues. Garth L. Nicolson made a landmark scienti ﬁ c model for cell membrane, known as the Fluid Mosaic Model.

questions.question: In which year did Rudolf Virchow published an essay titled ‘Cellular Pathology’ in which he famously declared that "every cell arises from another cell”?
questions.explanation: 1855 . Rudolf Virchow found cells in bone and connective tissue and described substances such as myelin. He was also the ﬁrst person to explain the mechanism of pulmonary thromboembolism. He was the ﬁrst person to recognize leukemia.

questions.question: Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG) is a vaccine for______
questions.explanation: Tuberculosis (TB). The vaccine was discovered by Leon Calmette and Camille Guerin. It is caused by a bacterium called Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Plague is an infectious disease that affects animals and humans. It is caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis.

questions.question: In the year 1925, who extracted lipids from an erythrocyte sample and found that lipid monolayers are good for measuring molecular surface area versus lateral pressure?
questions.explanation: Gorter and Grendel extracted lipids from red blood cells, dissolved them, and spread them into a monolayer on water.

questions.question: Who published Systema Naturae in 1735 classifying the three kingdoms of nature and outlining the sexual system for the classi ﬁ cation of plants?
questions.explanation: Carolus Linnaeus. He was a Swedish biologist and physician who formalised binomial nomenclature, the modern system of naming organisms. He is known as the "father of modern taxonomy”. Carl Woese : Developed the Three-Domain System of classi ﬁ cation (Archaea, Bacteria, Eukarya). Robert Whittaker : Proposed the Five Kingdom System of classi ﬁ cation (Monera, Protista, Fungi, Plantae, Animalia). Ernst Haeckel : Introduced the term "ecology" and contributed to evolutionary theory.

questions.question: Which of the following researchers observed densely stained reticular structures surrounding the nucleus (Hint: Figure)?
questions.explanation: Camillo Golgi. An Italian physician and biologist discovered the Golgi apparatus in 1898. He identi ﬁ ed densely stained reticular structures surrounding the nucleus using the silver nitrate staining technique, known as Golgi's method, along with light microscopy. William Harvey: Known for describing blood circulation. Louis Pasteur: Developed vaccines and pasteurization.

questions.question: In the context of DNA, which of the following principles governs the process of Transcription ?
questions.explanation: The principle of complementarity. This principle involves pairing adenine with uracil (instead of thymine) during transcription, where one DNA strand serves as a template for RNA synthesis. Transcription is the process of copying genetic information from DNA to RNA.

questions.question: In which year did Wilhelm Johannsen coin the term 'gene' to describe the Mendelian units of heredity
questions.explanation: 1909. A gene is a segment of DNA that contains instructions for making proteins or functional RNA molecules. Genes are made up of DNA, which is made up of nucleotides. Nucleotides can be adenine (A), thymine (T), cytosine (C), or guanine (G). The term "genetics" was coined by William Bateson, an English biologist, in 1905.

questions.question: In which year did a trio of scientists, Avery, MacLeod and McCarty, prove that except viruses, all living organisms have DNA as their genetic material ?
questions.explanation: 1944. DNA (Deoxyribonucleic acid) as an acidic substance present in nucleus was ﬁrst identiﬁ ed by Friedrich Meischer in 1869. He named it ‘Nuclein’. DNA is a long polymer of deoxyribonucleotides. In 1953 James Watson and Francis Crick proposed the Double Helix model for the structure of DNA. The four bases in DNA are adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), and thymine (T).

questions.question: In 1955, who published a comprehensive study of small particle constituents of the cytoplasm' (ribosomes) and correctly estimated their physiological importance?
questions.explanation: George E Palade. He demonstrated their role in protein synthesis and provided insights into their physiological importance, earning him the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1974. Pierre Joseph Pelletier: A French chemist known for his work in organic chemistry, particularly in the discovery of various alkaloids and other compounds. Albert Von Kolliker: A Swiss anatomist known for his work on muscle structure and the discovery of mitochondria.

questions.question: Which antibiotic is considered the ﬁrst miracle drug, used to treat throat infections, meningitis, syphilis and other bacterial infections?
questions.explanation: Penicillin was discovered by Alexander Fleming. Acyclovir is used for the treatment of herpes simplex virus infections, chickenpox, and shingles. Nifuratel is a drug used in gynecology, used in the treatment of leucorrhea, vulvovaginal infections, and urinary tractinfections. Metronidazole is used to treat trichomoniasis, amebiasis, in ﬂ ammatory lesions of rosacea, and bacterial infections and prevent postoperative infections.

questions.question: What is the cottony growth on stale and wet bread called?
questions.explanation: Fungi. The fungus that causes the cottony growth on bread is called Rhizopus, also known as common bread mould. The fungi constitute a unique kingdom of heterotrophic organisms.

questions.question: Calculate the Body Mass Index (BMI) of a person whose weight is 50 kg and height is 1.5 m.
questions.explanation: 22.2 kg/m2.BMI is a medical screening tool that measures the ratio of your height to your weight to estimate the amount of body fat you have. To calculate the BMI, we use the formula: BMI = = =𝑤𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡 (𝑘𝑔) ℎ𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡2 (𝑚2 )50 (1.5)250 2.25 = 22.2 kg/m2.

questions.question: The process by which a water body gradually becomes enriched with nutrients and minerals, mainly phosphorus and nitrogen, leading to enormous growth of algae on the surface of the water, thus decreasing the amount of dissolved oxygen in the water is known as:
questions.explanation: Eutrophication occurs when nutrient pollution from human activities leads to excessive algae growth in water bodies. This can cause hypoxia, a low oxygen condition that harms aquatic life. Biomagni ﬁ cation and bioaccumulation describe how toxins like pesticides and heavy metals accumulate in organisms and intensify up the food chain.

questions.question: Which speci ﬁ c chemical can be applied to achieve staining of chromosomes?
questions.explanation: Acetocarmine is a commonly used stain in cytology (study of cell) for visualizing chromosomes under a microscope. It binds to chromatin, making the chromosomes more distinct and easier to study during cell division.

questions.question: What do you call the body cavity that is lined by mesoderm?
questions.explanation: Coelom. A coelom is a body cavity completely lined by mesoderm, as seen in coelomates like annelids, molluscs, and arthropods. In contrast, a pseudocoelom is partially lined by mesoderm and is found in pseudocoelomates like roundworms. These body cavities play a key role in protecting internal organs and allowing movement.

questions.question: When the body is deprived of energy from food, which of the following tissues is used to feed on its own?
questions.explanation: Adipose tissue: Fat storing adipose tissue is found below the skin and between internal organs. The cells of this tissue are ﬁlled with fat globules. Storage of fats also lets it act as an insulator.

questions.question: Which of the following is a non - perishable food?
questions.explanation: Pulses. Non-perishable foods are items that can be stored at room temperature for extended periods without spoiling. Examples include beans, coffee, honey, powdered milk, rice, and wheat. In contrast, frozen foods are not classi ﬁ ed as non-perishable.

questions.question: What do we mean by Allen’s rule?

options.a: Mammals from colder climates generally have shorter ears and limbs to minimise heat loss.
options.b: Desert lizards lack the physiological ability that mammals have to deal with the high temperatures of their habitat.
options.c: Some plants have no leaves – they are reduced to spines – and the photosynthetic function is taken over by the ﬂattened stems.
options.d: The body compensates low oxygen availability by increasing red blood cell production, decreasing the binding a ﬃ nity of haemoglobin and by increasing the breathing rate.

questions.explanation: Allen's rule is an ecogeographical rule formulated by Joel Asaph Allen in 1877.
