It states that the body surface-area-to-volume ratio for homeothermic animals varies with the average temperature of the habitat to which they are adapted (i.e. the ratio is low in cold climates and high in hot climates).

questions.question: What kind of phyllotaxy was examined in the Guava plant?
questions.explanation: Opposite. Phyllotaxy refers to the arrangement of leaves on the stem or branch of a plant. In an opposite leaf arrangement, two leaves arise at the same point, with the leaves connecting opposite each other along the branch. If there are three or more leaves connected at a node, the leaf arrangement is classi ﬁ ed as whorled.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs is INCORRECTLY matched?.
questions.explanation: Starch : Egg Yolk. Starch is the main storage polysaccharide of plants. It is the most important dietary source for human beings. High content of starch is found in cereals, roots, tubers and some vegetables but not in egg yolk. It is a polymer of α-glucose and consists of two components— Amylose and Amylopectin.

questions.question: Match the terms in column A with their respective properties in column B. Column-A Column-B i. Glucose a. Intermediate substance in breakdown of glucose ii. Yeast b. Glucose is converted into pyruvic acid iii. Glycolysis c. Uses nutrients for fermentation process iv. Pyruvic acid d. Best organic substrate for respiration
questions.explanation: i-d, ii-c, iii-b, iv-a.

questions.question: Mendel proposed the law of independent assortment on the basis of
questions.explanation: dihybrid crosses. The Law of Independent Assortment (Mendel's second law) states that during a dihybrid cross (crossing of two pairs of traits), an assortment of each pair of traits is independent of the other. In other words, during gamete formation, one pair of traits segregates from another pair of traits independently. Monohybrid cross - When a cross is made between parents with one pair of contrasting characters. Gene - The fundamental unit of heredity. Alleles - Genes which code for a pair of contrasting traits.

questions.question: Which of the following sequences is correct, according to taxonomy ?
questions.explanation: According to taxonomy : Phylum - Broad group of related organisms (Example - Chordata). Class - More speci ﬁ c group within a phylum (Example- Mammalia). Order - Even more speci ﬁ c group within a class (Example - Carnivora). Family - Group of related genera (Example - Felidae). Genus - Group of related species (Example - Panthera). Species - Most speciﬁ c, a single type of organism (Example - Panthera leo, the lion).

questions.question: The phenomenon of the interaction between nonallelic genes at two or more loci resulting in one gene masking the phenotypic expression of another gene, is known as:
questions.explanation: Epistasis. Inheritance is the process by which genetic information ispassed from parents to their offspring. Incomplete inheritance, also known as incomplete dominance, is a pattern of inheritance where neither allele of a gene is completely dominant over the other. Linkage is a physical association of two genes.

questions.question: Which of the Mendel's laws states that a diploid organism passes a randomly selected allele for a trait to its offspring, such that the offspring inherit one allele from each parent ?
questions.explanation: Law of segregation. Mendel’s Law of Dominance, also known as the ﬁrst law of inheritance states that when parents with pure, contrasting traits are crossed, the trait appearing in the next generation is the dominant one, and the hybrid offspring will display only the dominant trait in their phenotype. Law of Independent Assortment : It states that when two pairs of traits are combined in a hybrid, the segregation of one pair of characters occurs independently of the other pair. This law is based on observations from dihybrid crosses.

questions.question: In which of the following is nicotine present in high quantity ?
questions.explanation: Tobacco. The average cigarette contains around 10–12milligrams (mg) of nicotine. Intake of nicotine either through smoking or chewing tobacco may lead to hypertension and should be avoided. Diseases caused by tobacco : Lung cancer, Oral cancer, Bronchitis, Atherosclerosis.

questions.question: In the energy ﬂow diagram of an ecosystem, the ﬂow of energy comes to herbivores from:
questions.explanation: Producers - They are Autotrophs, make their food by using Sunlight and are placed at ﬁrst trophic level. Producers are consumed by Herbivores, which are placed at the Second trophic level. Herbivores are Consumed by Carnivores. The Pyramid of energy which is upright re ﬂ ects that the energy ﬂow in a food chain is always unidirectional. Also, with every increasing trophic level, some energy is lost into the environment. This means Energy is maximum at the ﬁrst trophic level.

questions.question: Which of the following represents a visible biological hazard in food ?
questions.explanation: Caterpillars : The larval stage of moths and butter ﬂ ies. Some of these can be poisonous, and their hair can cause skin irritation. Viruses, protozoa, and yeasts are all microscopic organisms, and so cannot be seen by the naked eye.

questions.question: Which of the following is an invisible biological hazard in food ?
questions.explanation: Molds. Biological hazards are living organisms and include microbiological organisms. Those micro-organisms which are associated with food and cause diseases are termed as food-borne pathogens. Visible biological Hazards in Food - Worms, Cockroaches, Fly, Weevils, Caterpillars. Invisible biological hazards in Food - Bacteria, Yeasts, Protozoa, Viruses.

questions.question: When do the drugs used as medicines become potential poisons?

options.a: When doses are taken as recommended
options.b: When doses are taken at the recommended time and in the recommended quantity
options.c: When doses are taken higher than recommended
options.d: When doses are taken lower than recommended

questions.explanation: Pharmaceutical drug (medication or medicine) - A chemical substance used to treat, prevent, or diagnose a disease or to promote well-being.

questions.question: Why do pickles last longer?

options.a: The water content of the pickle protects the pickle from spoilage.
options.b: Bacterial and fungal cells get plasmolysed in high salt concentration of pickle.
options.c: Pickle is prepared in a vacuum so that no harmful bacteria can grow on it.
options.d: Only bene ﬁ cial bacteria can grow in the pickle.

questions.explanation: Plasmolysis is the process by which a plant cell loses water when placed in a hypertonic solution. Examples of Plasmolysis are : Shrinkage of vegetables in hypertonic conditions, Blood cells shrink when they are placed in hypertonic conditions.

questions.question: At what temperature (in degree celsius) is milk heated for 15 to 30 seconds to kill microbes in the pasteurisation method?
questions.explanation: 70 ℃. Pasteurisation : Process by which milk is heated to a speci ﬁ c temperature for a set period of time to kill harmful bacteria that can lead to diseases like Listeriosis, Typhoid fever, Tuberculosis, Diphtheria and Brucellosis. This process was discovered by Louis Pasteur.

questions.question: Which plant is considered a noxious weed that has a chemical defence mechanism to protect it from predators?
questions.explanation: Calotropis. It produces a compound called cardiac glycosides as a defence mechanism. Other plants with chemical defences : Poison Ivy (Toxicodendron radicans) - Contains urushiol, Poppies (Papaver) - Produce alkaloids such as morphine and codeine, Tobacco (Nicotiana) - Contains nicotine.

questions.question: Which of the soluble ﬁbr es found in fruits is used as a thickener in cooking and baking?
questions.explanation: Pectin. Food Thickener - A thickening agent that increases the viscosity of a liquid mix without interfering with its other properties. Other food thickening agents : Corn Starch, Xanthan gum, Gelatin, Potato Starch, Arrowroot and Agar-agar. Inulin - A type of prebiotic, a compound that encourages the healthy growth of gut bacteria.

questions.question: Which of the following is a tertiary consumer?
questions.explanation: Snake. Trophic levels in thefood chain : Producers/autotrophs ( ﬁ rst trophic level), consumers (second, third, and fourth trophic levels), and decomposers. Producers : Plants (Grass), phytoplankton, and plant-like organisms (algae). Primary Consumers : Herbivores (grasshopper, rabbit, horse, giraffe, human, deer, turtle). Secondary consumers : Dogs, Frog, Wolves. Tertiary Consumer : Lions, Tigers, Crocodiles, Polar bears, Jaguars. Decomposers: Bacteria, fungi.

questions.question: _____ percent can be taken as the average value for the amount of organic matter that is present at each step of the food chain and reaches the next level of consumers.
questions.explanation: 10. The 10% rule was introduced by Raymond Lindeman in 1942. According to this rule, only about ten percent of the biological food energy is stored in the organism's body when transferred from one trophic level to the next, while the remaining energy is lost in various activities and as heat. The remaining 90 % is lost during transfer, broken down in respiration, or lost to incomplete digestion by higher trophic level.

questions.question: What do you call the type of drugs that mimic the natural messenger by switching on the receptor?
questions.explanation: Agonist. Stimulants are a class of drugs that speed up messages travelling between the brain and body. Examples - Caffeine, nicotine, amphetamines, cocaine, etc.

questions.question: What do you call the drugs that bind to the receptor site and inhibit its natural function?
questions.explanation: Antagonists .Antidepressants are medications that help alleviate symptoms of depression and improve mood. Examples - Agomelatine, amitriptyline, citalopram, clomipramine, etc. Depressants are a type of drug that slows down brain activity, which causes the muscles to relax and calms and soothes a person. Examples - Diazepam, clonazepam, alprazolam, etc.

questions.question: Nutritional care during illness is an organised group of activities which consists of all of the following, EXCEPT:

options.c: planning and prioritising nutrition intervention(s) to meet nutritional needs

questions.explanation: Assessing psychological stress. The Nutrition Care Process (NCP) is a systematic approach to providing high quality nutrition care. The NCP consists of four distinct, interrelated steps : Nutrition Assessment, Nutrition Diagnosis, Nutrition Intervention, Nutrition Monitoring/Evaluation.

questions.question: Husk of a coconut is made of ______ tissue.
questions.explanation: Sclerenchyma tissue (provide strength to plants). Tissues of Plants : Dermal Tissues {epidermal cells, stomata, trichomes}, Ground tissues {Collenchyma (provide mechanical strength and elasticity to plants), parenchyma (to store food and provide turgidity to organ), sclerenchyma}, and Vascular tissue {Vessel elements, tracheids, companion cells and sieve tubes}. Xylem is a vascular tissue that transports water throughout a plant's body.

questions.question: Roquefortine C is found in :
questions.explanation: Cheese. Roquefortine C (C22H23N5O2) - Found in cheese. Although it is a potent neurotoxin at high doses, at low concentrations of 0.05 to 1.47 mg/kg that occur in domestic cheeses, it was found to be "safe for the consumer".

questions.question: Who among the following proposed the term ‘ecosystem’?
questions.explanation: A.G. Tansley (1935). The term “ecology” was coined by Ernst Haeckel. Turreson was a Swedish evolutionary botanist who made signi ﬁ cant contributions to ecological genetics, and coined the terms ecotype and agamospecies.Q.537. In ecology, is determined by dividing the biomass per unit area by the age of the ecosystem. SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Morning) (a) biomass density (b) biomass size (c) biomass energy ﬂow (d) biomass productivity Sol.537.(d) Biomass productivity. In ecology, the term productivity refers to the rate of generation of biomass in an ecosystem. Units of biomass are grams per metre square (g/m2).

questions.question: In an ecosystem, vertical distribution of different species occupying different levels is called _____.
questions.explanation: Strati ﬁ cation . Different types of the ecosystem : Terrestrial ecosystem - Forest ecosystem, Grassland ecosystem, Desert ecosystem, Tundra ecosystem. Aquatic ecosystem - Freshwater ecosystem, Marine ecosystem. The four main components of an ecosystem are : Productivity, Decomposition, Energy ﬂow and Nutrient cycling. The largest ecosystem in the world is the aquatic ecosystem.

questions.question: The green plants in a terrestrial ecosystem capture about _____ of the energy of sunlight that falls on their leaves and convert it into food energy.
questions.explanation: 1%. The rate of photosynthesis is maximum in Red light and minimum in green light. The only metal present in chlorophyll - Magnesium. The Chlorophyll (C55H72MgN4O5) helps plants to absorb energy from the sun as they undergo the process of photosynthesis.

questions.question: When the bread rises and bakes, ______ creates thousands of bubbles in the dough.
questions.explanation: Carbon dioxide. Bread rises because yeast eats sugar and burps carbon dioxide, which gets trapped by the bread’s gluten. The more sugar yeast eats, the more gas that gets formed, and the higher the bread rises.

questions.question: Which level of the food chainincludes millipede, springtails, woodlice, dung ﬂies and slugs that feed on the dead or decaying plants or animals?
questions.explanation: Detritivores - An organism (such as an earthworm or a fungus) that feeds on dead and decomposing organic matter.

questions.question: A balanced diet takes care of all the following aspects, EXCEPT one. Identify the aspect.

options.b: Meets the RDA for all nutrients
options.d: Includes a variety of food items

questions.explanation: Promotes a healthy mind. The 7 components of a balanced diet are Carbohydrates, Proteins, Fats, Vitamins, Minerals, Fibre and Water.

questions.question: What is a way in which adaptation does NOT take place?
questions.explanation: Emotional. Adaptations are of three types : Morphological adaptation is a structural change which gives an organism a greater chance of survival in its habitat. Behavioural adaptations are changes in behaviour that certain organisms or species use to survive in a new environment. Physiological adaptation is an internal change that animals and plants go through to ensure their survival in their environment.

questions.question: How do humans acclimatize at high altitudes where atmospheric pressure is low for normal breathing?

options.a: By decreasing red blood cell production, decreasing the binding aﬃ nity of hemoglobin and by increasing breathing rate
options.b: By increasing red blood cell production, decreasing the binding aﬃ nity of hemoglobin and by increasing breathing rate
options.d: By increasing white blood cell production, decreasing the binding aﬃ nity of hemoglobin and by increasing breathing rate

questions.explanation: During acclimatization (getting used to a new climate) over a few days to weeks, the body produces more red blood cells to counteract the lower oxygen saturation in blood in high altitudes.

questions.question: Which of the following plants is on the verge of extinction due to insensitivity to our environment?
questions.explanation: Madhuca insignis (Sapotaceae) is endemic to India. It had been declared extinct due to habitat loss, however, it has been rediscovered in Karnataka.

questions.question: A pyramid of biomass is a diagram that shows the population at each level of the food chain. Accordingly, ________ occupy the base with the highest biomass.
questions.explanation: Producers. A biomass pyramid is the representation of total living biomass and shows energy levels at different trophic levels in an ecosystem.

questions.question: Name a common ingredient made from the starchy part of corn kernels used as a thickening agent for gravies, marinades, sauces, soups and casseroles.
questions.explanation: Corn starch is the most common thickening agent used in the industry. It is mixed with water or juice and boiled to make ﬁllings and to give a glossy semi-clear ﬁnish to products. Potato starch is also used to thicken soups, sauces, and pie ﬁllings. Gelatin is a protein obtained by boiling skin, tendons, ligaments, and/or bones with water. It is usually obtained from cows or pigs. Pectin is aﬁber found in fruits.

questions.question: Which Act was enacted in India with the aim of curbing illegal trade in wildlife and derivative parts?
questions.explanation: Wildlife Protection Act 1972 provides for the protection of the country's wild animals, birds, and plant species, in order to ensure environmental and ecological security.

questions.question: Why are species of moss used as fuel?

options.b: Provide peat that have long been used as fuel

questions.explanation: Moss, (division Bryophyta) are small nonvascular spore-bearing land plants. They are distributed throughout the world except in salt water. Peat derived from Peat moss can be used as a fuel or as packing material for trans-shipment of leaving material because of their high water holding capacity.

questions.question: The foul smell from a body especially during a sultry summer is due to the action of ______ on sweat.
questions.explanation: Bacteria. Melanin is a substance in your body that produces hair, eye and skin pigmentation. Moisture - water in small drops on a surface, in the air, etc. A virus is a submicroscopic infectious agent that replicates only inside the living cells of an organism.

questions.question: Saccharomyces Cerevisiae is commonly used to make ______.
questions.explanation: Bread. It is known as “brewer's yeast” or “baker's yeast”. Saccharomyces cerevisiae, a type of budding yeast, is able to ferment sugar into carbon dioxide and alcohol and is commonly used in the baking and brewing industries.

questions.question: Which of the following does NOT belong to ‘Kingdom Fungi’ ?
questions.explanation: Euglena is a genus of single cell ﬂagellate eukaryotes. Euglena are unicellular organisms classi ﬁ ed into the Kingdom Protista, and the Phylum Euglenophyta. Fungi examples - Rhizopus, Penicillium and Aspergillus,Taphrina and Puccinia, Lichens and mycorrhiza, Mucor, Saccharomyces, Agaricus, Trichoderma.
